story:
About the Steps Ahead Summer Dance Intensive

As native of Miami, I wanted to do something very special to bring all the knowledge I’ve acquired over the years to my hometown. Out of this desire came the Steps Ahead Summer Dance Intensive. This is a two-day intensive in which students train in a variety of dance techniques in master classes taught by seasoned industry professionals, most of whom are also Miami natives. We're offering Ballet, Contemporary, Commercial Hip-Hop, Broadway Jazz, as well as Choreography and Moving on Purpose workshops. The intensive will culminate with the Steps Ahead industry seminar which covers the key components of working in the dance industry. This includes audition preparation, headshots, resume formatting, dealing with criticism, navigating time in between jobs, caring for your instrument(body), and marketing yourself effectively.

We all know that being a working artist isn't easy! But the smarter you are in your approach, the more successful you'll be. Preparation for the professional world is imperative for young artists. Very often I find that dancers are very well trained and excellent technicians however they lack many of the other tools necessary for life as a professional. My team and I would love to help bridge that gap and this intensive is a start. This will help dancers become sharp, confident, and in full understanding of what it takes to be a success.

The Steps Ahead programs are designed specifically for emerging professional dancers ages 16 and above. We aide dancers by preparing them to enter the market as well informed, business-minded artists.

Scholarship auditions will take place in Miami on May 21, 2016
The Intensive will take place August 13th-14th

*Please refer to the "updates" tab for more info on the instructors and facility!

About Me

Sharron Lynn is a proud native of Miami, FL, and high school graduate of New World School of the Arts, where she trained in all forms of dance. During her time at New World, she received a number of scholarships to attend the Alvin Ailey summer intensive and was eventually asked to join the 2nd company, Ailey II. She then went on to attend Florida State University and finished with two Bachelor’s degrees, one in Applied Economics and the other in Interdisciplinary Social Science. Upon graduation, Sharron became a member of Spectrum Dance Theater under Artistic Director and Tony nominated choreographer, Donald Byrd. Her diverse background and training has also afforded her opportunities such as being a principal dancer in Scary Movie 5, touring the US and Canada as a dancer/singer in Disney’s The Lion King, and working with recording artists such as Usher and Santigold. She played the role of Cinderella at Lincoln Center in the Little Orchestra Society's production of Cinderella and is also a featured dancer in the upcoming HBO series Vinyl as well as the Netflix Original Series The Get Down, which is slated for an August 2016 release.

What we need

The funds raised from this campaign will help with the following:

Full Scholarships for 50 students which covers all classes, lunch both days, and the industry seminar.

  • Facility rental for the intensive and the audition
  • A staff of 5 incredible artists
  • Full lunch & snacks for both days
  • Informational packets for the industry seminar (printing)
  • Marketing materials to disperse throughout the South Florida area

What you get for your contribution (all items are customized with the logo)

$10- A personal thank you note and updates on the program throughout the year

$25-A set of customized ink pens

$50-A set of customized ink pens and a tote bag

$100-A set of ink pens, tote bag, and sports bottle

$150(Sponsorship level)- Ink pens, tote bag, sports bottle, and a T-shirt

$500(Platinum sponsorship level)- Ink pens, tote bag, sports bottle, t-shirt, a framed photo of all the attendees, and a one-on-one career consulting with a seasoned industry professional and a young dancer of your choice either in person or via Skype.

Other Ways To Help

Sometimes it's just not in the cards to give and I totally understand that. Sharing also helps tremendously. Getting the word out via e-mail and social media would be a major contribution and I'd be just as grateful!

Feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools to do so.

Thank you so much for your time and support. It means a ton!

Much love everyone,

Sharron

story:
Strange Bird and the Cloud Spirits

About the Choreographer:

Kristen Demaree, grew up in a home that placed art as a medium for living.  She developed musical sensibilities from her father Dan Demaree (a talented jazz and classical musician), and dance sensibilities from her mother Barbara Demaree, whose training in the Royal Academy of Dance gave rise to Boulder’s first ballet culture as co-founder of both Boulder Ballet in 1982, and her dance school Ballet Arts Boulder.  As a dancer, Kristen grew up dancing in Boulder and performed with the Boulder Ballet in its early years.  As a violinist, Kristen was immersed and trained in the techniques and idioms of both folk and classical forms of music, and is still part of the music community in Boulder performing violin in gypsy jazz ensembles, Scandinavian folk music ensembles, and classical orchestras.

She is currently  on the faculty of Boulder Ballet and Longmont Dance Theater, where she teaches ballet, folk dance, and improvisation.  In addition to her position as a ballet instructor, over the last 2 decades her artistic palette has been continually developing and expanding, drawing on past experiences, and by asking new questions.  Before completing her MFA in dance at the University of Colorado in 2015, Kristen received her BFA in Film Studies, studying experimental film with Stan Brakhage and Phil Solomon.  While studying film, music, dance and design, Kristen has been deeply influenced by her mentors: Frances Charteris, Nada Diachenko, Michelle Ellsworth,  Robin Haig, Rennie Harris, Markas Henry, Erika Randall, and last but not least, her mother Barbara Demaree. As co-founder and co-director of Delusions of Grandeur Productions, she developed three shows over the last decade, the most recent of which (“Eternal Dialogue”) had a cast of no less than 30 musicians and dancers.

About the Ballet:
Derived from the second act of "Giselle", this work stems from a love of ballet, feminist theory, women's history during the French Revolution, and performance art.  "Strange Bird and the Cloud Spirits" re-imagines the birth of the ballerina as a product of revolutionary change.  This ballet is centered around the empowering ideas that gave rise to ballet and the romantic form known as “ballet fantastique”.  “Ballet fantastique” was a development of dance that dealt with the aftermath of the atrocities of the French Revolution.  The stories related to the common people, and had an element of fascination with the supernatural.  This was a time that many believe was the birth of modern western society.  Our experiences of living today, we are dealing with certain repercussions of those ideas: environmentalism, capitalism, human rights, and freedom.  Drawing ideas from the romantic era might seem like a nostalgic or outdated approach, yet people's concerns and struggles for equality and freedom at the time of the French revolution are still valid concerns for people all around the world today.  The balletic gestures, the romantic tutu, and the transition in women taking over the stage from the male aristocrat were meaningful symbols and events that embodied the society's change in values.

This ballet was created in remembrance of that era -- not only as a retelling of history, but as tool to redefine and re-perceive the modern ballerina.  Ballet's modern affinity for extreme athleticism and sensationalism can have a tendency to marginalize both the artistry and the societal meta-messages which a ballet's story was the vehicle to transmit.  The beauty and value in the art is at odds with the power structures, administration, and marketing ploys of a ballet company, which have become a singular voice dictating much of the future of ballet.  This work involves dancers from professional to novice abilities, of various ages, and encourages embodying ballet in a different way than that of the mainstream.  The limitless possibilities and meanings beyond tricks and kicks are what this ballet brings to the foreground.

Additionally, the Strange Bird ballet uses music that is not in the standard classical dance repertoire.  The performance is set to an album by Dreamers' Circus called "A Little Symphony," whose musicians won 3 of the top awards at the 2013 Danish Music Awards (Danish "Grammy"): Folk Talent of the Year, Folk Album of the Year, and Folk Artist of the Year to Nordic mandola player Ale Carr.  What makes the album unique (and perfect for Kristen's music and dance sensibilities) is its breathless integration of folk music's nature expanded and mixed with an orchestra.  With the music both classical and folk-sounding, the resulting sound is well-fitting to ballet, and encourages a broadening and integration of other influences.

About the Campaign:
This campaign is to raise funds to produce this ballet again to be performed at the Dairy Center on October 16, 17  and October 23, 24. 

Ideally, a budget of $15,000  would allow for paid directors, professional dancers, performance and rehearsal space, lighting design, set design and construction, costume, make-up and hair designers.   Paying for work means paying for the amount of time and energy that it takes to bring out the best in everyone.  However, a bare-bones budget of $5000 would secure the performance and rehearsal space, which would allow for the production to occur, and everyone's time would be in-kind.  The campaign is set to $5000 is because that is what is needed to get the show on the road: $5000 will go to rent performance and rehearsal space (which equates to roughly half of that amount), as well as for technical staff, lighting design, and costumes.   Anything over and beyond will allow for further support of all the artists involved.

About the Company

Delusions of Grandeur Productions was founded by Kristen Demaree and Elvira Stewart in 2005.  Delusions' shows have always been well-attended and have received grants from the Boulder County Arts Alliance for past productions.  Elvira will be creating new work for performances as well.  Her artistry stems from experience with Maurice Béjart in Switzerland, where she focused on ballet from the perspective of the male dancer rather than the ballerina.   Elvira's component will encompass her love for partnering and pas de duex, as well as a male solo performance.  Both of these works together seek to redefine, reconstruct, and redeem ballet and its dancers in a way that both honors and transforms the tradition.  Previous Delusions of Grandeur productions include:
  1. (2005) Pandora's Muse -- performed in Boulder
  2. (2010) Body of Sound -- performed in Boulder
  3. (2011) Eternal Dialogue -- performed in Boulder and Denver

("Compulse" [2011], choreographed by Michael Levy, and performed to the music of a Persian rhythmic piece set in 10 beats)

All three shows integrated musicians and dancers, with the latter (Eternal Dialogue) going a step further by utilizing poems and spoken word as a conceptual beacon or premise for the music and choreography.

story:
Who We Are

We are the first, second and third year students of Rosebud School of the Arts.  As part of our training, we go on an immersive theatre trip each year.  This year, our first year students are going to the West Coast and our second and third year students are going to London.  We would love it if you could help us make this happen!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise 15% of the cost of the trip for each of us students.

For the first years, this works out to approximately $200 each.

For the second and third years, this works out to approximately $500 each.

10 students x $200        =       $2,000    (20%)

14 students x $500        =       $7,000     (70%)

Indiegogo service fees  =       $    400       (4%)

Cost of perk delivery      =       $    500       (6%)

That's a total cost of                $9,900

Check out our perks on the right for ways we'd like to thank you for being involved. 

Or, if you prefer, you can make a donation of $25 or more that is fully tax receiptable.  If your donation is made on or before December 31, 2014, you will receive a donation receipt for a deduction on your 2014 Canadian tax return.

If we do not reach our goal, we will still split the funds raised between the students who are going.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to make a donation to our trips but believe in the training that we are doing, please consider passing a link to this website on to other contacts of yours who may be interested in supporting us.  Or tell your friends about the trip that we get to go on!

story:
About The Play

In ENTANGLED, as in life, our darkest secrets always find their way to the light. Sometimes this light disarms them, diffusing their potency. And sometimes the light catches the cracks and the dirty corners, breathing life back into those dormant memories. And no matter how much we try to rewrite history, the truth always finds a way to muscle through the lies. Two best friends, Ian and Scott along with Hillary, the woman Ian loves, find themselves trapped in an impossible predicament: un-knowing what they know. And so, on a stormy new year’s eve on the secluded Peaks Island in Maine, our characters find themselves trapped by the snow and the avalanche of horrible realities they’ve been trying to hide from one another over the years. Everyone’s secrets are revealed. No one is safe from blame. And someone will not make it off the island alive.

What We Need To Make It Happen!

In order to produce the play in it's highest quality, we have assembled a team of graduates from Carnegie Mellon University, NYU Tisch, and Yale School of Drama. As is the life of an artist, it is always difficult to make ends meet, and we would like to be able to fund the design fully so that we can pay the creatives and actors the money that they deserve. This team is INCREDIBLE. These artists are dedicated and extremely talented. This story will haunt you for weeks and months to come. 

We aim to raise $6,000 to go towards the costs of this production. Without you, this production would not be possible. 

We will repay you in gratitude, love, and recognition in the publicity. We have a bunch of nice sponsorship options on the side. We'd love for you to take a look! 

All of the money raised here will go directly to the funding the creation of this new production. Please feel free to spread the word! We would be grateful for any and all support. 

The Creatives

Leah Miles is a playwright, composer, and Teaching Artist based out of Brooklyn, New York. She holds a BA in Psychology from Salem State University and an MFA from the Graduate Musical Theatre Writing Program at New York University’s Tisch School Of The Arts. She is a member of ASCAP, Dramatists Guild Of America, The Directory of Contemporary Musical Theatre Writers, NOMTI (Boston, MA), and Three Act Theatre Company. Ms. Miles' produced works include Entangled (workshopped at Three Act Theatre, NY), Sunday Roaster Chicken (Ugly Rhino Productions, NY), Bronx Zoo (MuSE, NY), and Providence: A Musical Comedy (Write Act Eastside, NY). Her most recent work, Touching Loss (in collaboration with Clare Cook Dance Theater and composer Paul Castles), premiered in April of 2016 at the Acadiana Center For The Arts in Louisiana. As a Teaching Artist, Leah has worked for multiple years with ArtsConnection, The Metropolitan Opera Guild and The Brooklyn Youth Chorus. She is the 2016 recipient of ArtsConnection Linda LeRoy Janklow Teaching Artist Award for her ongoing work with ArtsConnection's Spectrum Musical Theater Program at P94M Spectrum Schools for Autism in New York. www.leahamiles.com

Nate Bertone hails from Salem, Massachusetts and holds a BFA in Drama from Carnegie Mellon University. Nate lives in New York City where he works as a director, playwright, and designer. In the last year, his work has been seen on the North Shore with his play Letters From War last season (BWW Best Drama), Shrek: The Musical, and Sister Act at North Shore Music Theatre. Nate will be working with Beowulf Boritt on the upcoming Broadway production of A Bronx Tale directed by Robert De Niro and Jerry Zaks. www.natebertone.com

The production team will include Incidental Music by Paul Castles, Scenic Design by Nate Bertone, and Costume Design by Jean Kim.The cast includes John Manning as Ian, Caroline Keeler as Hillary, and Lee Holmes as Scott.

and Lee Holmes as Scott.

story:
On June 14th, Quiet Events presents its biggest outdoor party yet! Party at sunset and under the stars with an incredible view of the Midtown Manhattan skyline at LIC Landing, one of NYC’s most spectacular venues. 

GET YOUR TICKETS NOW TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN! -------------------------------->

In 2015 we are taking the word “party” and elevating it to a whole new level. That's right - we're taking the club outdoors! Think music festival on the waterfront under the stars with the most amazing view of the city. Elegance meets nightlife. Crazy, right?

From 6pm-midnight, you will have 3 top DJs to choose from on one massive main stage - with some amazing surprises too!  

We need to sell $3,000 worth of tickets to kick this off. If we do, you know it will be a sick party.  If we don't, the event won't happen, and you get your money back!

LIC Landing is located at Hunters Point South, the brand-new waterfront park just steps from the East River Ferry terminal in LIC. 

Drinks & Amazing Food will be available for purchase by COFFEED. 

18+ to party, 21+ to Drink

story:
About Praxis

Back in September 2013, a novel theatre group was established by the Oxford University Greek Society. Our group’s vision is to introduce contemporary Greek plays performed in their original language to an English speaking audience, an element missing from Oxford’s vibrant international student theatre scene.  Starting with a bang, our inaugural production ‘Internal Affairs’ (Εσωτερικές Ειδήσεις) by Marios Pontikas, under the direction of Manos Tsotras was staged in May 2014 with great success (an independent review is available here)!  Since last June, the team has  evolved  and moved with both new and past members towards establishing its unique identity as ‘Praxis’ (Πράξις), a diverse group of theatre enthusiasts from the Oxford University Greek community.

The Building


Under the direction and guidance of Anastasia Revi, this year we aim to stage ‘The Building’ (To Κτίριο) written and translated in English by Peny Fylaktaki (ed. by David Connolly) published in 2015. This is a story of a building which narrates its turbulent life from the first day people raised it on its feet until today. Throughout a century the building constantly changes functions and habitants, gradually becoming a ’beacon of history’. The never ending alternation of existence, war, peace, birth, death of its tenants stands in stark contrast with the infinity of the building’s presence. Through immersive storytelling, the play reveals the cycles of history and the struggle of humans to make a mark and a standing impact over time.

About the Director

A voice moving between creative passion and questioning of everything, Anastasia Revi is the art Director of the Theatre Lab Company: A London based international team, founded in 1997, with a significant amount of productions and participation in festivals worldwide. Anastasia’s most recent project is Medea, a timeless ancient story staged in 2014 London.  Anastasia and PRAXIS started their joint journey in the magical world of theatre back in December 2014.

How you can help

If you wish to take part in materialising ‘The Building’ on stage in the UK, you’re curious about contemporary Greek art, culture and language or were simply dazzled by last year’s production and would like to see more of us, join our journey and contribute to our unique production with your donation. We aim to raise £1200 to meet our production costs including venue booking, equipment hire, costumes & stage design costs.

On the 11th of June 2015, ‘The Building’ will open its doors for 4 shows at the Pilch Studio in Oxford! Be there and spread the word!

story:
Who We Are

This is us! 


GREENHOUSE 2015 is San Francisco State University's Creative Writing Department and Theatre Arts Department’s annual showcase of 4 new plays by our MFA and undergraduate playwrights.

Since 1999 we have launched exciting new works and introduced new playwrights to the San Francisco Bay Area Theater community. Previous Greenhouse Playwrights have had work featured at major theaters across the United States. This year’s crop of outstanding new playwrights includes Adam Ambriz, Carson Beker, Conrad Panganiban, and Patricia Reynoso. 

GREENHOUSE 2015 marks the second year of our innovative partnership with Z Space, San Francisco’s hub for artists and audiences to revel in the creation, development and production of outstanding new work. Together with Z Space, we are bringing you undeniably hot theater.  

What We Have

  • Hot Playwrights - Four emerging playwrights whose work has appeared or is forthcoming at SFSU's Fringe Goes Long, Bindlestiff Studio, Gigantic Sequins, Detroit Fringe Festival, Two Muses Women's Playwrighting Festival, and the SF Olympians Festival;  
  • Hot Plays -  plays dealing with hot issues like murder, madness, abortion, beauty, opportunity, the American Dream, and what it means to be family; 
  • Hot Space - All staged readings will take place at Z Below, Z Space’s beautiful 88 seat theater, at 450 Florida Street, in San Francisco's Mission District;  
  • Local Sponsorship - Clare’s Delicatessen will be providing home-made traditional deli food to actors, audience, and crew;
  • Funds - to compensate our four professional theater directors and to cover part of our actors' budget.   

What We Need

  • $ 1300 to pay the 26 actors $50 for their time and talent;
  • $ 550 to pay for photocopying scripts for actors, posters, and theatre programs;
  • $ 150 for props; 
  • $ 250 to pay for printing cards for mailing;
  • $ 250 to pay for postage stamps and the unexpected.

The Impact

You will be helping emerging playwrights launch their careers, adding to the dynamic diversity of San Francisco's theater scene and beyond. 

We will be able to show future audience members, foundations, and the city that the theater scene in San Francisco is thriving and that San Francisco State University's Playwrighting program is a hot spot, helping the next generation of playwrights grow and reap the stories of our times. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come and see the show, pay full price for the ticket, tell a friend, tweet, like our facebook page, come visit us in real life or online, give a playwright a hug, and please share our campaign.

story:
The historic Powel House in Old City Philadelphia turns 250 years old in 2015! What better way to celebrate that than with a play? First performed in 1773, this hilarious Restoration comedy will come alive in this uniquely authentic setting. What's more, nearly 40% of the ticket sales will go directly to the upkeep of the house. But to make it work, we need funds to rent costumes, get props, and advertise the show! A little goes a long way so please donate today!

* Please note, the video at one point states that we are raising $1,000.  That was filmed before we realized how much it would take to advertise the show and we are actually looking to raise $1,500!

The Powel House Built in 1765, this elegant Georgian brick mansion was purchased by Samuel Powel in 1769 at the time of his marriage to Elizabeth Willing.  The Powels frequently entertained such notable guests as George Washington, John Adams, Benjamin Rush, Benjamin Franklin, and the Marquis de Lafayette.  Today the house is maintained by The Philadelphia Society for the Preservation of Landmarks, a non-profit organization. 

The Mechanical Theater  First established in 2013, this independent theater company's mission includes embracing Philadelphia’s rich history by developing theater projects tailor-made for its unique, historical settings.  In the past we have worked with the Powel House, the Physick House, and the Laurel Hill Cemetery.

"She Stoops to Conquer" by Oliver Goldsmith Charles Marlow is a perfect scoundrel with members of the fair sex...provided they aren't of the upper classes.  So when he meets Kate Hardcastle, the lady his father has arranged for him to marry, a stammering Charles can barely look her in the face let alone romance her.  But Kate decides that all Mr. Marlow needs is a lesson in confidence... and she will be his teacher!

story:
Keep in mind that I'm an Artist and I'm sensitive about my shit.-Erykah Badu

This is my very first time doing anything like this and I'm excited to share with you what I've been cooking up! 

It is my sincerest hope to support the artists that are making my dreams come true with their hard-work, inkling for mentor-ship, desire to collaborate with emerging artists and passion for the subject matter of this play. I'm beyond grateful for their time and efforts and would like to support them as well as cover production cost for prop and set needs. 


Short Summary

Black Bitch is a bold and exciting new work developed by actress, poet and emcee ShaVunda Horsley and directed by Shá Cage, writer and performer of , U/G/L/Y, Nword and co-founder of the Minnesota Spoken Word Association and Mama Mosaic Theater. Blending monologues, spoken word, film clips, music and and more, this deep-hitting yet comedic one-woman show explores the tools that black women use to access power, and their responses to social and political spaces carved “for us,” versus “by us.

I was inspired to create this work as a conversation piece between Mentors I've been blessed to have and young women struggling to find their voices amidst the chaos of social media, cultural identity conflicts and understanding power.

Your support makes this possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

I would appreciate any form of support whether that be snacks for the crew or volunteering time or advice.

story:
Short Summary

YA Novel: The Parody is a witty, light-hearted take on the super duper serious world of teen post-apocalyptic dramas, like The Hunger Games, The Maze Runner and Divergent. Set in a gritty world with a small cast, many characters and a choose-your-own ending, this show will have you laughing all the way to your heroic coming of age!

We decided to do something close to our hearts for Fringe Fest, and thought that taking a few light-hearted jabs at popular young adult novel tropes would be right up our alley. We wanted to do something like this at Fringe Fest because of the festival's encouragement of original and ridiculously fun content. 

Although we are doing a succinct 4 performance run, creating a post apocalyptic world from a black box isn't something that comes easy or for free--so in order to make this happen, we must rely on the kindness and support of everyone who realizes the importance of taking the chance to create something that is am absolute labor of love.

Who We Are 

Ashley Victoria Robinson is an actress and writer living in Los Angeles, originally from the great white north of Canada! Ashley can currently be seen internationally in the "Gamers" spot for Intel opposite The Big Bang Theory's Jim Parsons. She is best known for starring in the Star Trek parody webseries "The Red Shirt Diaries". Additionally, she co-starred in the Banco Film Group's debut horror feature film "Asmodeus" as Jane and recently wrapped shooting on Verse Films' horror feature debut "Watch Me". She has had various comic books published by Image Comics.

Leslie Ranne grew up on a ranch in small-town Texas before moving to California to get her MFA in Screenwriting from Chapman University. She was recently in the film "Murieron por encima de sus posibilidades" from Spanish director Isaki Lacuesta. Other recent credits include Ophelia/Tragedian in "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead" at the Barn Theatre, and Sicinius Velutus in Shakespeare's "Coriolanus" at the Archway Theatre.  She fell in love with theatre after studying Shakespeare with Armin Shimerman for the past year at Antaeus Academy. Leslie is also a DIY and cute animal expert. 

The rest of the cast includes:

Patrick McMillan - Patrick ran away to Los Angeles to be an actor. Ironically, he can be seen as a Citizen of the Capitol in THE HUNGER GAMES and feels that he brings a lot of credibility to his work on stage in this show. Patrick has also been featured in THE RED SHIRT DIARIES alongside co-star Ashley Victoria Robinson. Additionally, Patrick has appeared in  HOMELAND and THE SUGARS as Phil. He can be seen on stages all over Los Angeles and when he's not doing actor stuff Patrick is an avid comic book fan and a working candyman. He is presently developing a semi-autobiographical short film set to hit the festival circuits soon.


Rob Beddall- Rob first discovered his spark for acting in his high school drama class and his teacher and parents encouraged him to take it further. At 16 Rob was accepted into Kidderminster College and its well respected performing arts course, where he graduated with his National Diploma. It was here that he really discovered that acting was for him. At 18 and for the next 3 years, he toured up and down the British Isles performing shows to a variety of schools. Rob then moved to Los Angeles to study at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts where he received the prestigious Charles Jelinger award for distinction in acting. Since then Rob has  worked for top theatre companies in Los Angeles and Northern California including; A Noise Within, The Odyssey Theatre Ensemble and Shakespeare Santa Cruz. He is a current member of the multi-award winning Road Theatre Company. 

What We Need 

Here's the thing, it SEEMS like putting together a play for a fest like this would be an easy matter. Through some actors in some clothes, make them memorize a few lines, then let them have at it and entertain an audience, right? Oh, if only.  Unfortunately, we have yet been unable to materialize our play from thin air, and until our alchemy degrees come in the mail, we need money for things like:

Performance and Rehearsal Space Rental
Advertising
Costumes
Props and scenery (and the people who make them!)
The best stage manager in the business (who will keep us from going off the rails)
A lighting designer (so you can see us and stuff)
Promotional Materials
And probably a lot of stuff we will find out as we go along!

What You Get

Luckily, our prizes are cool enough that you'll want some of them even if you can't come see the play in person!

Here are a few of them!

Behind-The-Scenes Blog Access
A play ticket/food/beverage voucher 
A PERSONALIZED comic swag bag created especially for you!
Signed posters/t-shirtsA PERSONALIZED and unique autographed copy of Noelle Stevenson's NIMONA or Lumberjanes! (personalization done by Noelle, naturally)
Sweet headshots

OR YOU CAN BE A CHARACTER IN THE SHOW!

*Perks that involve free tickets will substitute a trade comic in lieu of a ticket after 6/28. 

Risks & Challenges

Unfortunately, we lost our original space (through no fault of our own) and although we were lucky enough to find a great new one, it also comes with a higher price tag. This means that we're going to have to really scramble in order to create a show in a new space (less than a month out) and hustle to get more funds, but luckily we secured a new space without any problems, and everything seems to be trucking along, since we have such a great team and supportive friends! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show!
Repost, retweet, re-whatever anything to help us spread the word!
Tell your friends about us!

story:
WHAT IS BLOODY AWFUL?
AND WHY SHOULD I GIVE A S#!T?

Good question, theoretical theatre producer! Bloody Awful is comprised of two short horror comedies conceived by award-winning playwright Leland Frankel. Together, these tales of desperation, violence, and sex form one unforgettable evening of entertainment. 

Check it out on the official Fringe website here: http://hff17.com/4535

Part one of our show is The Callback, a lurid glimpse into the underbelly of the entertainment industry. Aspiring actress Molly has been chewed up and spit out by showbiz too many times to count. But when she is denied a callback by snooty director Ashford, something inside of her just...snaps. Molly kidnaps Ashford and holds him hostage in an abandoned theater, subjecting him to bouts of physical, mental, and emotional torture in a crazed bid for the part. Hey, how far would you go for the life you think you deserve?

After that is Slaughterhouse, which is exactly as fun as it sounds. Kurt is a nervous wreck about his new relationship with beautiful, fun-loving Caroline. His self-conscious is compounded by the fact that, oh yeah, he lives in an apartment with three notorious serial killers! They all mistakenly believe him to be one as well, and Kurt would much rather not find out what happens if his roomies discover the truth. But when sweet Caroline pops by for a surprise visit, all hell (and then some) threatens to break lose. However, nothing is ever as it seems...especially in matters of the heart.

Two hilarious (and frightening) plays for the price of one? Who wouldn't want to throw a little money our way? Especially when you--the theoretical producer--take into account that beyond simple giggles and scares, Bloody Awful touches on timely, feminist themes of gender inequality and society's patriarchal structure. 

Show dates will be:
Saturday, June 3rd @ 5:30 pm (PREVIEW)
Saturday, June 10th @ 7:00 pm
Thursday, June 15th @ 7:00 pm
Wednesday, June 21st @ 10:00 pm
Saturday, June 24th @ 2:30 pm

All performances will be at Asylum @ The Stephanie Feury Studio Theatre (5636 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles CA 90038). 

WHO ARE YOU GUYS? AND AGAIN, WHY SHOULD I GIVE A S#!T?

Fond of swearing, aren't ya?

Well, our production team is currently comprised of...

  • Leland Frankel, award-winning playwright 
  • MJ Watz, director
  • Jonny Perl, associate producer
  • Kiri Schawalder, assistant director
  • Akeira Ndas, production designer
  • Brittany Cobb, lighting designer
  • Mallin Alter, costume designer
  • Myla Kellerman, hair/make-up designer

And our talented cast, of course...

Dennis Woullard

Kelly Ohanian

Joey Rich

Soren Royer-McHugh

Alex Elliott

JD Zelman

Jonny Perl

All of us are experienced, LA-based creative professionals with credits with dozens of local theatre companies and venues, from tiny black boxes to The Geffen, Center Theatre Group, and beyond. Our mutual passion for creating unique, invigorating, and socially-charged art is what brings us all together - the same reasons that we hope you will support our project. 

SO WHAT DO YOU NEED MY MONEY FOR?AND WHY SHOULD I GIVE A S--

Okay, okay, we get it. 

What we are raising funds for with this campaign are the most basic requirements of a Hollywood Fringe production. All the artsy-fartsy stuff is on us and (unless this campaign wildly exceed our expectations) coming out of our own pockets. These essential costs laid out here are what our team, at this moment, is already on the hook for.

  • $250 to officially register for the 2017 Hollywood Fringe Festival
  • $750 for five performances at Theater Asylum's Stephanie Feury Studio. 
  • $150 for venue insurance, even though we promised we wouldn't burn the place down!
  • $250 for stage management services, to cover our five performances and tech. 

That comes to a grand total of $1,400, a percentage of which has already been paid in advance to the venue. Other costs (props, costumes, set, promotion, etc.) will hopefully be covered by our ticket sales -- though of course, if we go over funding here, your generosity will contribute to these other essential costs, plus marketing. With your support, we won't have to worry about whether or not our team will be going into debt trying to make Bloody Awful a reality. 

I GUESS THAT SOUNDS OKAY.

Gee, thanks. 

ANYTHING ELSE I SHOULD KNOW?

This is a passion project in every sense of the word. We cannot promise big-time celebrities or elaborate special effects or even a happy ending. But what we can promise is a rollicking, sexy, woke-as-hell performance that you won't regret being a part of. 

So come on, give a few bucks, and make Bloody Awful a reality.

God help us all.
story_txt:
WHAT IS BLOODY AWFUL?AND WHY SHOULD I GIVE A S#!T?
Good question, theoretical theatre producer! Bloody Awful is comprised of two short horror comedies conceived by award-winning playwright Leland Frankel. Together, these tales of desperation, violence, and sex form one unforgettable evening of entertainment. 
Check it out on the official Fringe website here: http://hff17.com/4535Part one of our show is The Callback, a lurid glimpse into the underbelly of the entertainment industry. Aspiring actress Molly has been chewed up and spit out by showbiz too many times to count. But when she is denied a callback by snooty director Ashford, something inside of her just...snaps. Molly kidnaps Ashford and holds him hostage in an abandoned theater, subjecting him to bouts of physical, mental, and emotional torture in a crazed bid for the part. Hey, how far would you go for the life you think you deserve?After that is Slaughterhouse, which is exactly as fun as it sounds. Kurt is a nervous wreck about his new relationship with beautiful, fun-loving Caroline. His self-conscious is compounded by the fact that, oh yeah, he lives in an apartment with three notorious serial killers! They all mistakenly believe him to be one as well, and Kurt would much rather not find out what happens if his roomies discover the truth. But when sweet Caroline pops by for a surprise visit, all hell (and then some) threatens to break lose. However, nothing is ever as it seems...especially in matters of the heart.Two hilarious (and frightening) plays for the price of one? Who wouldn't want to throw a little money our way? Especially when you--the theoretical producer--take into account that beyond simple giggles and scares, Bloody Awful touches on timely, feminist themes of gender inequality and society's patriarchal structure. 
Show dates will be:Saturday, June 3rd @ 5:30 pm (PREVIEW)Saturday, June 10th @ 7:00 pmThursday, June 15th @ 7:00 pmWednesday, June 21st @ 10:00 pmSaturday, June 24th @ 2:30 pm
All performances will be at Asylum @ The Stephanie Feury Studio Theatre (5636 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles CA 90038). 
WHO ARE YOU GUYS? AND AGAIN, WHY SHOULD I GIVE A S#!T?
Fond of swearing, aren't ya?
Well, our production team is currently comprised of...


Leland Frankel, award-winning playwright 

MJ Watz, director

Jonny Perl, associate producer

Kiri Schawalder, assistant director

Akeira Ndas, production designer

Brittany Cobb, lighting designer

Mallin Alter, costume designer

Myla Kellerman, hair/make-up designer

And our talented cast, of course...

Dennis Woullard

Kelly Ohanian

Joey Rich

Soren Royer-McHugh

Alex Elliott

JD Zelman

Jonny Perl
All of us are experienced, LA-based creative professionals with credits with dozens of local theatre companies and venues, from tiny black boxes to The Geffen, Center Theatre Group, and beyond. Our mutual passion for creating unique, invigorating, and socially-charged art is what brings us all together - the same reasons that we hope you will support our project.

story:
The Project 

(in)dispensable is a new work choreographed by emerging artist Madison Burgess in collaboration with her 7 dancers. Through solos, duets, trios and an ensemble piece the cast of (in)dispensable explore various feelings of want, and find themselves determining whether or not these desires are actually necessary, or if in fact they may be dispensable.

The Team

Choreographer - Madison Burgess 

Dancers - Robyn Bedford, Victoria Gubiani, Raine Kearn, Brianna Salmon, Paige Sayles, Tianna Therriault & Emily Rapley

Stage Manager - Shannon Farrel

Outside Eye - Corynne Bisson

Photographer - Sidonia Cole

OUR GOAL

Our goal is to raise $1500! The money will assist with expenses including costumes, marketing and promotional costs, stage crew/technician fees, venue fees and so much more. Any little bit helps!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, no worries! Word of mouth is just as helpful and if possible, we would love for you to share our fundraiser page through your social media - Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc. Use the share links to make it easy. Also, join us for the show! We would love to see you there. 

Venue-

The Commons - 587a College St, Toronto.

Performance Dates - 

Friday February 15th - 8pm

Saturday February 16th - 8pm

Sunday February 17th - 8pm

story:
Short Summary

Sides is a show dedicated to the universality of love, family, and friendship. 8 professional musical theatre performers will play multiple characters and share the stories written and composed by Matthew Capurro. Musical director, Jeffrey Michael Kauffman, will lend to the work his trained eye and skills as a pianist as he guides performers through the music and accompanies each performance. It is important to us that these artists receive proper compensation for their time and dedication to the work. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The project needs funding to help pay the cast and creative team for their time and effort devoted to the work. As a supporter, your name will be in the program, and we are offering an audio recording of the song cycle, performed by the workshop cast, as a thank you for providing a donation of $50 or more.

Your contribution supports local artists and allows them to continue to provide audiences access to their talent and craft.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that funds are often in short supply, and if you're interested in this project but are unable to give monetarily, you can still help us out by:

  • Sharing this campaign 
  • Talking to people about the show
  • Coming to see our performances!

story:
Our Story       

(Photo: Michigan Dance Project company, Credit: Ken Hornak)

Michigan Dance Project was founded in 2006 by Kathy King in an effort to offer local dancers more opportunities to perform and continue training in a professional atmosphere.  Since our inception, MDP has performed throughout Southeast MI, including such places as the University of Michigan-Flint Theatre, Wayne State University, Riverside Arts Center, Howell Opera House, and the Brighton Center for the Performing Arts.  


Currently, MDP is working on their new project "SoulMates", an evening length work choreographed by director Kathy King and assistant creative director Travis Staton-Marrero.  This work has already been a life-changing experience for the 16 dancers involved, and we're on a mission to share that experience with you!


Who are we?  Michigan Dance Project is still under the direction of Kathy King, and this season she is joined by assistant creative director Travis Staton-Marrero.  We have seven company members and seven apprentice members.  We are also very lucky to work closely with two incredibly talented photographers, George Petersmarck and Ken Hornak, and we welcome lighting designer Jessica Back to the team this season.  Our rehearsal home is in Brighton, MI at Michelle's Academy of Dance & Performing Arts Center (MADPAC), and we are forever grateful to studio owner Michelle Marzejon for her generous donation of space since the beginning!



   The Impact

(Photo: Assistant Director Travis Staton-Marrero and Director/Founder Kathy King, Credit: Ken Hornak)

Passionate people inspire passion in others and make this world a better place!  By pursuing our intense passion for dance and the human soul, we are on a mission to spread that love to the world, but we can't do it alone!


The money raised through this campaign is vital to not only the survival of "SoulMates", but also to the growth of the Michigan Dance Project organization.  We work hard every weekend, beginning in September, training and rehearsing (without pay) to bring you the best show possible.  It's all a labor of love!  Without this funding, we will not be able to afford the theatre rental costs and will have to cancel our currently booked shows at the UofM-Flint Theatre (Jan. 22, 2012 - Flint, MI) and the Brighton Center for the Performing Arts (Feb. 18, 2012 - Brighton, MI)  That leaves 16 dancers, and over a dozen technical staff members out of work!


  What We Need & What You Get

(Photo: Michigan Dance Project Company Dancer Emily Turner, Credit: Ken Hornak)

$5,200 - that's what we need to make "SoulMates" a reality.


Where is it going?  Theatre rental ($75 - $150 per hour), technical crew ($10-$15 per hour), costuming ($30 - $100 per costume X's 14 performers), program/flyer printing ($100-$300 per show), plus dancer salary. 


What do you get if you donate?  Well, for starters, a giant hug (an electronic hug if you can't make it to the show in person), and an even bigger THANK YOU!  But, we know you'd probably appreciate more than just a hug, so we're offering various perks at various levels of donation.  Perks include meet & greet with the company, free tickets, your name listed in the program, MDP swag, and more!


Plus, you can feel great knowing that you're helping to support the arts community right here at home in Michigan, and trust us, there is some mighty fierce talent here that needs to be seen!


Other Ways You Can Help   

(Photo: Michigan Dance Project Apprentice Dancer Brett Zeuner, Credit: Ken Hornak)

Talk about us!  Tell your friends and family!  Get your students excited about the arts by telling them about our project!  Come to the show!  Check out the social media share tools that we have on this page... it only takes a second, but can make all the difference!

story:
Welcome to The Welcome Revolution's crowdfunding page!

 

The Welcome Revolution was born because we want to make the UK a more welcoming place; it is a retaliation to the negative attitudes towards migration; it celebrates diversity and multiculturalism; and hopes to inspires change. It exists because we believe small acts of kindness do make a difference.

 

Who are Feat.Theatre?

 

This show is about communities, made with communities and by communities. As a company, we are passionate about presenting diverse voices and experiences on stage, especially those often excluded from theatre. We create work that can be performed in almost every space, and find ways of telling stories that include everyone. We are constantly attempting social and political feats through performance (like starting revolutions to make the world a kinder place).


Our first show won multiple awards at the National Student Drama Festival in 2017 (The Stage UK Directors Award and the Camden People’s Theatre Award). Since then we’ve been developing The Welcome Revolution, which is our first show we’ll be taking up to the Edinburgh Fringe.

 

What is The Welcome Revolution?

 

We hosted many tea parties around the country, talking to people about their opinions and experiences of welcome and community. And most importantly, it gave us an opportunity to meet new people and spread kindness. The Welcome Revolution tells their stories, with humour, chocolate biscuits, the help of the audience, and includes the messy but refreshing honesty that voices of children can bring. It also tells the story of a woman who wants to make the world a better place. The show includes real-life responses from community events we have hosted and features new content every performance. But one thing stays the same - it will bring people together, and inspire people to make a change and join our revolution.

 

Kind things audience members have said about the show so far…

 

“Left The Welcome Revolution with a huge smile on my face and lots to think about. Beautiful show.”

 

“Really enjoyed The Welcome Revolution last night. Great to hear community voices on the act of welcoming, feeling welcome, and having a cuppa.”

 

“Really love the message… It made you feel part of the idea to be more friendly to people you don’t know. Amazing generosity.”

 

Why do we need your help?

 

We really believe that this is an important show that should be seen at the Edinburgh Fringe, with the diverse range, and size, of audience that it brings. However, this amazing opportunity comes at a huge cost.

 

As a young company that is concerned with community engagement and outreach, we are relying on our own company funds as well as the generosity of others to help us get to Edinburgh. We wouldn't be doing this if we didn't think it was worth it!

 

Therefore, we are asking your help to raise £1500, which will help us massively towards our overall cost of the show.

 

Where will the money go?

 

Community

 

Our community engagement events are vital for the existence of The Welcome Revolution.  They are always free to anyone who attends, and we want to be as generous as possible with tea, coffee and arts & crafts. Of course, this comes at a price and your contributions will be going to a great cause.

 

Marketing

 

A lot of the money raised will be going towards making sure that as many people know about The Welcome Revolution as possible. We will be launching a huge campaign with flyers, posters, mugs and t-shirts - so that everyone can join the Revolution. It is a huge cost for us to sustain this over the month long run at the fringe.

 

Venue

 

With help from our funding campaigns and work-in-progress sharings earlier this year, we have been able to cover most of the venue hire cost. However, a successful crowdfunding campaign will provide the final push towards raising the money to give to ZOO, so we can perform at their wonderful and welcoming Cabaret Bar.

 

On top of this - the money will also help towards the extra costs of insurance, licensing and hiring technical equipment for the show.

 

Thank you!

 

If you have read this far, we want to thank you already. We can't express it enough, but every little helps and a little amount will go a long way for us. Any donations you give will make a tangible difference for us as an emerging new company and our journey to Edinburgh this Summer. We are so grateful for your support and generosity. To say thanks, we have a whole array of exciting gifts for those of you who can donate - from personal letters to a home cooked meal!  

 

If you can't contribute personally, there are still ways to help, such as sharing our Indiegogo page with friends and family, Facebook, or just good old fashioned word-of-mouth.

 

And of course, we hope to see many of you in Edinburgh - where we can promise you a free hot drink if you come to our show. Buy tickets here.

 

Much love,

 

Josie, Stella and the Feat.Theatre team xo

 

 

Show information at the Edinburgh Fringe Festval

The Welcome Revolution

ZOO Southside, Cabaret Bar, 4pm, 3 - 27 August 2018

Show information at the Edinburgh Fringe Festval
The Welcome Revolution
ZOO Southside, Cabaret Bar, 4pm, 3 - 27 August 2018

story:
A rarely seen early work by one of Americaâ€™s most beloved contemporary playwrights

Sarah Ruhl, the MacArthur â€œGeniusâ€ Grant recipient, has delighted audiences in theatres throughout America with her fantastical and singularly off-kilter view of the world. Her plays A Clean House and The Vibrator Play were Pulitzer Prize finalists and have won her international renown.

Melancholy Play is one of her earliest full length works, not seen in Chicago since it premiered at Piven Theater in 2002. Described by Ruhl as a â€œcontemporary farceâ€, Melancholy Play is both a wildly fun and deeply moving look at the mysteries of human happiness and sadness, currents of emotion which prove powerful enough to leave us entirely transformed (and not only in the metaphorical sense...).

Our production will run at Chicagoâ€™s Viaduct Theatre April 20 - May 13, 2012.

And how are we feeling today?

â€œI am feeling - melancholy...
I would like to die and be reborn as a mushroom.
I would like to stay warm and slightly damp.
I will release spores now and again when it suits my mood.â€

Who are we?

Grey Ghost Theatre is a new storefront theatre company in Chicago, dedicated to productions of contemporary plays, original works, and new adaptations of classic texts.

Our founding members come from various backgrounds in theatre, film, radio, improv, and music. Past projects of our members have included works produced by Redmoon Theater, Collaboraction Theater, WBEZ Chicago, and at the New York Independent Television Festival.

We hope to raise enough funds for this project that we can apply our all of our ticket sales to more projects in the future! Possible future productions include Mikhail Bulgakovâ€™s Heart of a Dog and an original translation and adaptation of Karl Mayâ€™s Winnetou.

What does the money go to?

By donating, you help provide us the means to bring this unusual and heartwarming play back to Chicago. You will also be a vital contributor to the birth of a new theater collective, bringing a distinctive and exciting new voice to the Chicago theatre community.

Hereâ€™s how the money will be used:

  • Legal rights to produce Melancholy Play - $2,000
  • Rental of the theatre and rehearsal spaces - $4,000
  • Costumes, scenery, props, and lighting- $1,500
  • Stipends for actors and musicians - $800
  • Marketing (website design, posters, etc) - $600
  • Robert, our stagehand - the rest

Who's Robert?

Robert is Grey Ghost Theatre's stagehand. Your contributions will ensure that Robert can keep doing menial tasks behind the scenes so that we don't have to. When you sponsor Robert, you will receive updates and letters from him thanking you for your gift

Sarah Ruhl, the MacArthur â€œGeniusâ€ Grant recipient, has delighted audiences in theatres throughout America with her fantastical and singularly off-kilter view of the world. Her plays A Clean House and The Vibrator Play were Pulitzer Prize finalists and have won her international renown.
Melancholy Play is one of her earliest full length works, not seen in Chicago since it premiered at Piven Theater in 2002. Described by Ruhl as a â€œcontemporary farceâ€, Melancholy Play is both a wildly fun and deeply moving look at the mysteries of human happiness and sadness, currents of emotion which prove powerful enough to leave us entirely transformed (and not only in the metaphorical sense...).
Our production will run at Chicagoâ€™s Viaduct Theatre April 20 - May 13, 2012. 
And how are we feeling today?
â€œI am feeling - melancholy...
I would like to die and be reborn as a mushroom.
I would like to stay warm and slightly damp.
I will release spores now and again when it suits my mood.â€
Who are we?
Grey Ghost Theatre is a new storefront theatre company in Chicago, dedicated to productions of contemporary plays, original works, and new adaptations of classic texts.
Our founding members come from various backgrounds in theatre, film, radio, improv, and music. Past projects of our members have included works produced by Redmoon Theater, Collaboraction Theater, WBEZ Chicago, and at the New York Independent Television Festival.
We hope to raise enough funds for this project that we can apply our all of our ticket sales to more projects in the future! Possible future productions include Mikhail Bulgakovâ€™s Heart of a Dog and an original translation and adaptation of Karl Mayâ€™s Winnetou.

What does the money go to?
By donating, you help provide us the means to bring this unusual and heartwarming play back to Chicago. You will also be a vital contributor to the birth of a new theater collective, bringing a distinctive and exciting new voice to the Chicago theatre community.
Hereâ€™s how the money will be used:

Legal rights to produce Melancholy Play - $2,000
Rental of the theatre and rehearsal spaces - $4,000
Costumes, scenery, props, and lighting- $1,500
Stipends for actors and musicians - $800
Marketing (website design, posters, etc) - $600
Robert, our stagehand - the rest
Who's Robert?
Robert is Grey Ghost Theatre's stagehand. Your contributions will ensure that Robert can keep doing menial tasks behind the scenes so that we don't have to. When you sponsor Robert, you will receive updates and letters from him thanking you for your gift

story:
Thousands of Footsteps. One Believer. 


Mother Jones and the Children's Crusade with Book, Music and Lyrics by Cheryl E. Kemeny will have its world premiere this July at the New York Musical Festival! 


She won't quit and she won't stay quiet! It's the turn of the century and aging Mary Harris 'Mother' Jones is on a tireless crusade for justice as she leads ragged mill children on a march to end child labor. Inspiring, heartbreaking and hopeful, this thrilling new musical following 'the most dangerous woman in America' will captivate audiences of all ages with its vibrant score blending period infused melodies with powerful contemporary anthems to deliver an uplifting message of human dignity that transcends time.


A Note From Benjamin Simpson, Producer:

I’ve had the pleasure of calling Crystal Theatre in Norwalk, CT my “home away from home” for almost fifteen years.  Not only was this the place that helped shape my career path as a professional actor, but this is the place that I have made my lifelong friends.  Most importantly, this is the place where I fell under the spell of Cheryl Kemeny, the theater's founder.  Through her love, dedication, non-stop work around the clock, and immense knowledge of the arts, Cheryl has given thousands of children the gift of the performing arts.   

Twelve or so years ago, I was in Cheryl’s Mother Jones and the March of the Mill Children.  The story follows legendary Mary Harris “Mother Jones” and a group of ragged mill-children as they march for human dignity and to end child labor.  The show’s universal theme of hope and standing up for what you believe in has stayed with me all of these years.  As I grew older, continuing to perform in countless shows at different theaters throughout high school, college and post-graduation, I would constantly think about just how special Mother Jones and the March of the Mill Children was, and I made it my goal to bring this show to a wider audience.

This past fall, I contacted Cheryl with the idea of reworking her show for a broader audience—an enormous task involving drastic changes that focus the story and its central characters.  Cheryl was up for the challenge, and before we knew it, I was directing a cast of Broadway performers that fell just as in love with the piece as I had, with two successful presentations that got us to a very special next step. 

Perhaps one of the proudest moments of my career thus far was receiving the phone call that the prestigious New York Musical Festival had selected Mother Jones and the Children’s Crusade to be a part of their summer 2014 festival as a Next Link selection, one of ten hand-selected scripts by a committee of some of the most important and influential individuals in the industry- ranging from Tony nominated actors, directors, and writers to world-renowned regional theater Artistic Directors. 

The limitless opportunities and exposure this festival will bring to the show is something so vital to the show’s future life. Investors, producers, New York newspaper reviewers, theater owners world-wide and everyone in between attend this festival with the same goal: to fall in love with a show and bring it to the next level- and I’m confident this is their show.

Here’s where I need your help. To mount a full production of the show with a full team of professionals, we’re looking at a price tag of $47,000 at the very least. We began our fundraising earlier this month and have made baby steps to our goal, but we still have a long way to go. Your contribution to our production is fully tax deductible through Crystal Theatre Inc's not-for-profit 501 (c) (3) tax status.  

While working on our campaign, I stumbled across a quote by G.T. Smith- “Donors invest in ideas and people in whom they believe” and I hope my belief in Cheryl and her show will inspire you to join this journey with me.

Sincerely,

Benjamin Simpson


             Follow Our Show! 


  • Official Show Site:

www.motherjonesmusical.com


  • NYMF Site: 

http://www.nymf.org/tickets/2014- events/motherjonesandthechildrenscrusade/


  • "Like" us on Facebook!

www.facebook.com/motherjonesmusical


  • Follow us on Twitter!

www.twitter.com/MJmusical


  • Follow us on Instagram!

www.instagram.com/MJmusical


Press Releases of Our Show!

NYMF Press Release via Playbill.com

Press Release of Fall '13 NYC Presentation via BroadwayWorld

story:
Help Dimensions Celebrate 40 Years  of Dance and Community!

Dimensions Dance Theater is a dance company and school that serves as a beacon of creativity and a model of artistic excellence for a low-income, inner city, urban community with little access to the arts.  Our audience totals 10,000 per year: 70% comes from Oakland; 65% are African American; and 80% are low-income.

On October 5, 2013, Dimensions will present The 40th Anniversary Celebration, an evening-length retrospective of four decades of great African and African-derived choreography, including the full premiere of Down the Congo Line, a work that explores the huge influence of Congolese culture in the living traditions of Brazil, Cuba, and New Orleans.  These dances will knock your socks off!

Celebration 40 will be presented at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco and will mark a momentous occasion in our company’s history, affirming and acknowledging the huge contribution that Dimensions has made to the cultural life of the Bay Area, as the company looks forward to our next phase of artistic creativity and activism. 

But we need your help!  To ensure the success of this great celebration, we must raise  $15,000 to cover the cost of the production at YBCA.  Your contribution will go toward artist fees for more than 30 professional Bay Area artists who will be performing that night – and the show can’t go on without them! Every dollar counts.  Please know that if we do not raise the entire amount, funds raised will still go to support the artists for this event. If we exceed our goal, which we hope to do, those additional funds will support the expansion of our programs in our 5th decade.

Details:

What: 40th Anniversary Retrospective and full premiere of Down the Congo Line

When: Saturday, October 5, 2013 – 8pm

Where: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts/Forum - 701 Mission St., San Francisco, CA

Collaborating Artists: Hervé “Makaya” Kayos (Congo), Isaura Oliveira (Brazil), José “Cheo” Rojas (Cuba), and Latanya d. Tigner (New Orleans)

Please share this campaign with those who you think would like to support this momentous occasion.


For more info: www.dimensionsdance.org

story:
About the Play

Text taken directly from the novel A Crack Up at the Race Riots by Harmony Korine. Set in a desolate American wasteland, this darkly absurdist and non linear comedy will feature a troupe of 7 actors who will perform a series of vaudevillian vignettes that will collide head on with themes of dysfunctional childhood, mental disorders, racism, homophobia, drugs and poverty while simultaneously constructing their demise right before the audience’s eyes.

Become a part of the theater giving community

We are hard at work developing A Crack Up at the Race Riots, but to bring the novel from page to stage, we need your help! Have you ever wondered what it would be like to write a play, rehearse it, produce it, and put it up on stage in New York City? We invite you to join us on this exciting creative journey and participate in the process! By supporting our project, you are joining the Crack Up family, and becoming a patron of the arts. 

There are many expenses involved in producing a show, and every amount given is so important to the success of the play. Here is what your contribution will go towards:

Dream Up Festival Submission Fee

Rehearsal Space

Artistic Team/Actor Stipends

Scenery and Props

Marketing Materials

Script Making and Misc. Administration Expenses

Writing, producing, and acting in a show is a lot of work, but we look forward to bringing you the finished product at Theater for the New City's, Chrystal Field (Artistic Director) Presents, Dream Up Festival.

About the Dream Up Festival

Theater for the New City will present a lineup of wide-ranging and original theatrical visions embracing drama, poetry, music, and dance. Dream Up Festival will consist of performing artists representing theater and performance companies in our theater complex in downtown New York. In 2010, the inaugural Dream Up Festival offered 25 shows consisting of 23 World Premieres and 2 American Premieres.

With its Dream Up Festival, Theater for the New City (TNC), which customarily presents new work by local artists, opens itself up to theater from the country at large and to artists from overseas. Its founders, Crystal Field and Michael Scott-Price, feel this is especially needed now in a time of declining donations to the arts, grants not being awarded due to market conditions, and arts funding cuts on almost every level all across the country and abroad.

TNC has consistently been the most inexpensive theater of its caliber and the institution continues its commitment to affordable tickets with this festival. Dream Up Festival ticket prices will range from $12-$20 for the participating productions. Most of the productions will be staged at least five times. 

Theater for the New City (TNC) maintains a distinctive commitment to high artistic values and community service. In an effort to make theater accessible to all, TNC presents an assortment of distinct, exceptional events each year, including the Lower East Side Festival of the Arts, which celebrates the artistic and cultural diversity of TNC's Lower East Side community; an annual Village Halloween Ball and an annual summer Street Theater tour that presents a free, live, original musical in thirteen neighborhoods in all five boroughs. Most of these are free of charge to the public.

Theater Background
Theater for the New City (TNC) Selected Awards: TNC has won over 42 VILLAGE VOICE OBIE AWARDS for excellence in for excellence in every theatrical discipline. TNC has won 5 ASCAP AWARDS. Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Sam Shepard’s BURIED CHILD, premiered & commissioned by TNC.

Theater for the New City is located at 155 First Avenue, at the corner of East Tenth Street, in the heart of Manhattan's East Village. For more info on the summer festival and the entire organization: www.theaterforthenewcity.net.

 

Dream Up Festival is a proletarian collective work that happens over a year but is only seen for 3 weeks. Many folks have put their donkeywork and talents into this Theater for the New City summer event. Dream Up Festival is eternally grateful to everyone involved with the festival both past and present. We’re honoured to be a part of the New York City artist landscape. Thank you

BIOS

Director/Adaptor:

Toney Brown is a creative artist residing in Astoria, Queens. He has worked on productions at Abrons Arts Center, HERE, TNC, The Brick and with Target Margin Theater and Dennis Yueh-Yeh Li. He is a graduate of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst where he was a recipient of the Rand Scholarship for Directing. He just joined The Living Theater.

The Author:

Harmony Korine is an internationally acclaimed filmmaker, writer, and artist who became the youngest credited screenwriter at age 19 for his screenplay Kids (1995). His directorial debut, Gummo (1997), is one of the most controversial and influential films of independent cinema. He has written and directed the award winning films Julien Donkey-Boy, Mister Lonely, Trash Humpers, and Spring Breakers. His novel, A Crack Up at the Race Riots, was first published in 1998. He currently lives in Nashville, Tennessee with his wife Rachel and their daughter Lefty. He gave the rights to Toney over a phone conversation and told him to send him pics and vids on the smart phone. Also, his uncle or second uncle is Joe Chaikin. On his moms side.

story:
Short Summary

DANIEL FETECUA SOTO, a native of Bogotá, Colombia, holds a BFA from Folkwang-Hochschule, Germany, and has appeared as a guest artist in Pina Bausch’s masterpieces, Rite of Spring and Tannhaeuser. He became a member of the LIMON DANCE COMPANY in 2006 and he's currently a soloist with the company.
In 2003 he founded Pajarillo Pinta’o, a dance company that combines Colombian traditional dances and modern dance, that is now based in New York and Germany.
He is currently guest choreographer and board member of ID Studio Theater, a not-for-profit organization led by German Jaramillo. In Spring 2008, he was commissioned to create a new piece by Dancing in the Streets with funding from Harlem Stage and in 2010 he was awarded another grant from Harlem Stage for a new group work.
In 2012 Daniel very proudly received his first grant from NALAC (National Association of Latino Arts and Culture) for the creation of BELLA VISTA, a new dance work dedicated to commemorate the massacre of 2002, of Bella Vista, Bojaya, in the Pacific Region of Colombia.

The Bella Vista Project is meant to be a week of events in NYC in commemoration of the 10th anniversary from the massacre of Bella Vista, Bojaya, in the Pacific Coast of Colombia. 

After 3 years of research,  study, and creation process, we have received a partial grant from the National Association of Latino Arts and Culture and we have found a presenting partner, the Flushing Town Hall, in NYC where we will be premiering this nw dance work on October 3rd and 7th. http://www.flushingtownhall.org/events/event.php?id=935

 

 What We Need & What You Get

To complete the project and to be able to pay for all the production expenses we need to raise more money.

The project includes live performances, with live music and an original score composed by Sebastian Cruz; but also workshops, conferences , talk backs and Q&A with Lubin Valencia, a direct victim and a survivor of Bojaya and with Camila Orjuela, a social worker of the Natonal University of Colombia. We have to pay for their travels and housing for the weeek they will spend wit us, sharing their stories with our audience, teaching dance workshops and moderationg conferences.

We need your help to pay for the technical expenses, costumes and the expenses for our two guests coming form Colombia: their housing, per-diems, plane tickets and us-visas fees. Their presence is vital for this project.

Bella Vista is a unique project that involves exceptional dancers and top musicians.

WHILE HELPING US YOU CAN GET AMAZING REWARDS: We brought back some amazing art crafts from our last trip to Colombia that you will be receiving as soon as you make your donation!! 

The Impact

WE HOPE TO BE ABLE TO LET MORE AND MORE PEOPLE KNOW ABOUT THE TRAGIC HAPPENING IN BELLA VISTA, BOJAYA, IN HOPE THAT THIS WILL BE OPENING SPACE FOR A CHANGE. THE PROBLEM ABOUT THE WAR IN COLOMBIA IS THAT PEOPLE NOT INVOLVED IN IT DON'T REALLY KNOW ABOUT WHAT HAPPENS. MEDIA DON'T TALK ABOUT IT AND THERE IS NO SPACE FOR A  REAL DIALOGUE. 

ALSO, WE WISH TO SHARE INFORMATION AND TO LET PEOPLE KNOW ABOUT THE AFRO-COLOMBIAN CULTURE OF THE PACIFIC COAST OF COLOMBIA, THEIR HISTORY, THEIR DANCE, MUSIC and TRADITIONS.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE THIS WITH YOUR FRIENDS. Bring people to the shows and SPREAD THE WORD!

story:
What/Who are the Near Misses?

You're probably asking yourself "Okay, but are you a band? Or an opera?" We're both.

The Near Misses is an opera manifesting as an all-female electropop band. The show will feature original music, text and choreography inspired by near-death stories we've collected from community members and friends. Our band members will animate stories of trauma, grace, and recovery--and the role of personal and collective memory. These are heavy themes to be sure, yet what arises in all of these stories are exquisite recollections of beauty, humor, and hope. This is also our human legacy.

The Near Misses interweave music, storytelling, movement, and visual art in a subversive performance that will kick off with several performances in Charlottesville and then tour. Our producing artists include composer/performer Paige Naylor, stage designer Bolanle Adeboye, and Jennifer Hoyt Tidwell as instigator, director, and writer. Band members (in addition to Paige) include Katie Schetlick, Kara McLane Burke, and Catherine Monnes.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Producing, writing, composing, and rehearsing a new experimental opera with an ensemble requires a substantial commitment of time and expense. Paige, Bolanle, and Jennifer have spent 5 months so far planning the project, writing music, and designing prototypes of the portable set which will also serve as musical instrumentation. 

Your donation will go towards fully developing the piece for premiering in June. Our expenses are:

  • Artist Stipends
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Costumes & Set 
  • Marketing & Promotion

We are excited to make an ambitious, innovative collaboration in our community and to share the process with you along the way. If you're curious about the way we are making something like this, we will hold open rehearsals and a collaboration workshop as we get close to our premiere in June.

We will also be offering free tickets to our preview show at the Southern at the end of May.

 

The Impact

We are devoted to amplifying the voices and stories of women especially the underrepresented including our own. Just amongst the three of us producing artists, we have an immigrant woman of color, a queer solo mother and widow, and a female electronic music composer in a genre heavily dominated by men. Our opera focuses on other women's stories, but it contains ours and many other women's stories of trauma, grace, and recovery. It also acknowledges the near-death moment we're facing with our environmental degradation.

Some of us making The Near Misses have deep experience in collaboration and a track record of co-producing successful interdisciplinary performances such as CLAW, Shentai, A Charlottesville Wunderkammer, NO WAKE, now/now, and Ghost in Reverse, 

A thriving and diverse local arts culture depends on a community that supports its working artists and welcomes experimentation and collaboration amongst artists. It creates a connected  and healthy ecosystem and takes us one step closer to making Charlottesville a viable home for its artists. By investing in this project and others like it, you are helping Charlottesville grow into the community we want it to be. And then we get to share the magic we made as we travel.

Thank you so much for considering donating. We look forward to updating you as we embark on this journey!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your Story: Whether you're able to support us with money or not, we would love for you to contribute your story. All the stories we collect are making their way into our piece. Whether through movement, audio-sampling, or lyrics. Contact us at info@nearmissesband.com to submit a voice recording of your story or make other arrangements to record. Here's the prompt:

Recall an event that changed the course of your life-- a pivotal moment of near physical or spiritual death. Describe the event in either 1st, 2nd, or 3rd person, your experience immediately following, and what the longer term consequences have been for your life. We're interested specifically in events that have been catalysts for dramatic change in your life. 

Please Like, Follow, Friend us on Facebook and Instagram and Share this Campaign!

story:
Remember the first horrible date you went on? Remember the LAST horrible date you went on? Remember the time you swore off dating for good, then fell madly in love with the girl from 5A? Remember the time the girl from 5A turned out to be your long lost cousin?


Yikes. 


It's a tough, unforgiving (and kind of sticky) world out there for love, but for some crazy reason...we keep trying. One man, Rich Orloff, begs to answer the question "Why?" and has more than one unhinged answer in, Romantic Fools. From the oddly primitive to the honestly insane, Orloff doesn't miss a beat in this vignette style boy-meets-girl-meets-boy-meets-you-get-the-picture comedy.


Here's what others are saying about the show!

ï¿½A side-splitting new comedy. Youï¿½ll ache from non-stop laughing.ï¿½

Show Business Weekly

ï¿½Hilarious!  Rich Orloffï¿½s play takes romantic situations over the top in this comedic look at the battle between the sexes.ï¿½

Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel

ï¿½The perfect date play.  Even if you're married, you might enjoy a date with your spouse for this.ï¿½

Akron News


THIS SHOW HAS NEVER BEFORE BEEN PRODUCED in Kansas City, and promises to be one night you and your date or spouse or...cousin, won't soon forget.


The show will star the handsome Jeff Smith from 'The Outsiders', the hysterical 'A Very Joan Crawford Christmas' and the immensely popular 'Pride and Joy'. and quirky Katie Karel from the charming 'Seusical, the farcical 'Evil Dead' and the classic 'Evita', with Shea Coffman directing,


Romantic Fools will run at the Fishtank Theatre in February; February 2-18th with an additional performance on Valentine's Day.


The Impact

Through humor, this play reminds us that all relationships can be difficult - but that love, true love, is what compels us all. Humor is a perfect forum to remind us all of its importance, not only in relationships, but throughout society.

If we don't make this goal - WE WILL STILL PERFORM!  We have the actors, the Fishtank rented from Feb. 2-18th (performance times TBA), however, we will have to produce the show at a lower quality than we originally planned and will need to take loans out for payment of the project.

Here are our performance times!  And even if you can't contribute, at least come see the show!! You can order tickets online at
http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/221986




February 2012

        Romantic Fools  8:30 Romantic Fools   8:30 Romantic Fools   8:30

19 20 21 22 23 24 25


Again, in true celebration of Valentine's Day, and spirit of love, we pledge to donate 20% of all Ticket Sales to the American Heart Association.

What We Need & What You Get

Help us reach our goal of $3000.  These funds will go directly to the production for the venue (The Fishtank), production rights (16 performances total), props, costumes and set materials.  

PLEASE help us reach our goal. With your generosity, we hope very much to make something really wonderful happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

 
SPREAD THE WORD!  Share us on Facebook, Twitter, MySpace, Xanga, Jenga, Yatzee...whatever the kids are doing these days!

If you love what you see, tell your friends, if you don't...tell your friends. We really appreciate every effort. 

Have an organization, business, or group looking to contribute? Email us! We're ready and willing to work with you!
