story:
Premiere of Kerouac's Gift

The duet is set to a recording of Jack Kerouac’s 1958 free-form poem “The Bowery Blues”. By identifying the rhythm, imagery, meter, and cadence in Kerouac’s prose, I then translated those elements to the body with the intention of creating a visual poem. I chose to have two women perform the work because although women were often the subject in Kerouac’s and his fellow beatnik’s work, there were not any women in the circle partaking in the creation process. The two women in Kerouac’s Gift are storytellers of sorts — casual bystanders of the transgressions taking place in Kerouac’s prose.


I generated material through improvisation, collaboration with my partner, Sheila Klein, and was inspired by the rich and descriptive language Kerouac used to paint the city of New York and its idiosyncratic characters for his readers. My partner and I experimented with the juxtaposition between rhythm and melody, and explored what it is like to create gestures based on the text verses creating on the abstract.

The work will premiere on Sunday, April 15 at 8pm at Green Space in Queens. Tickets are $15.

http://www.greenspacestudio.org/

The funding will go towards paying my dancer, Sheila Klein, for the time she put in for rehearsals and performance, for the rehearsal studios, and paying Philadelphia-based artist, Vincent Finazzo, for his work on creating digital projections that will accompany the piece.

story:
'Absolute' was written by Brett Steinberg over the past two years. It will be put on live June 26-28 at 7:00pm at Toquet Hall in Westport, CT (tickets: http://bit.ly/1CXWL2n). It began as something that had to be written - a burning desire to get something onto the page. It's turned into a community of theater-loving friends with a mutual dream of originating this production, together. 

We have been hard at work and have already built a team of committed creatives, booked the venue, written the script and music and laid out the set designs. This show will happen, but we need funds in order to pay for lighting (i.e. LED light fixtures/spotlights), sound (i.e. body mics) and set design materials (i.e. wood, tools, scenery, props) to bring it to the next level. 

Every dollar counts when it comes to putting on the best production possible. Nobody in the cast or crew is guaranteed making any money out of this. We're doing this because we have a huge amount of passion towards musical theater and we want to make our mark...but we can't do it alone.

It's a show about love and community not only within the show, but for the whole cast and greater Connecticut theater community around it. Be a part of our community.

Thank you in advance for your contributions and see you at the show!


Get $5 tickets to see the show *bring friends*: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/absolute-a-new-musical-by-brett-steinberg-tickets-16303002720


Follow us for updates:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AbsoluteMusical

Twitter: https://twitter.com/absoluteshow

Instagram: https://instagram.com/absoluteshow

Tumblr: http://absolutemusicalposts.tumblr.com/


LISTEN TO SONGS FROM THE SOUNDTRACK HERE:

story:
QUI SOMMES- NOUS ?

De ses origines italiennes, la Compagnie Soleluna puise une vitalité flamboyante et l’art de marier les genres, humour et sensible… soleil et lune !

Elle a croisé dans sa folle course d’autres aérolithes du genre, tels Michel Heim, dont elle a repris l’œuvre presque intégrale, Pierre Bianco, qui a signé nombreuses mises en scène, ou encore les inclassables Fabio Marra, Luca Franceschi…
Évoluant entre théâtre, musique et danse, Soleluna met l’énergie et le talent de sa constellation de comédiens-chanteurs, musiciens et danseurs, à la portée de tous, et même des plus petits !
Fondée en 2003, la Compagnie a établi son camp de base dans l’aéronef de l’Étoile Royale Théâtre, à Lyon.

Tous nos spectacles et dates de tournées sont sur http://www.compagnie-soleluna.net
Et vous pouvez suivre en temps réel l'actualité de la Compagnie sur Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/cie.soleluna

Depuis 2009, la compagnie s'emploie à mêler théâtre, musique et danse..
Travaillant en étroite collaboration avec des musiciens et danseurs, elle a monté trois comédies musicales écrites par Michel Heim, auteur connu et reconnu pour ses comédies, parodies et comédies musicales. 


On ne présente plus Michel HEIM !

Roi du divertissement parodique et pape du théâtre privé parisien, il a expérimente avec la Compagnie Soleluna un nouveau genre, en écrivant pour elle sa première comédie tragique, "Le maître et le chanteur" dont la création a pu voir le jour grâce au soutien de nos spectateurs et amis, en 2013. 

Souhaitant continuer à explorer cette facette plus dramatique de l'auteur, dans laquelle il excelle autant que dans le registre comique, nous lui avons commandé une nouvelle pièce dans le même registre et de là est née ADIEU BERENICE, qui nous plonge cette fois au coeur du théâtre contemporain et sera donc présenté en alternance avec LE MAITRE ET LE CHANTEUR au Festival d'Avignon Off 2016.


POURQUOI FAIRE AVIGNON ?

Le Festival d'Avignon est devenu un "passage obligé" pour faire connaître notre travail, développer la compagnie et contribuer à la faire vivre à travers la vente des spectacle et les tournées. 

La Compagnie Soleluna s'autofinance et ne bénéficie d'aucune subvention.
C'est grâce à votre soutien et votre générosité (même les petits montants sont précieux !) que nous pourrons affronter sereinement cette nouvelle aventure avignonnaise ! 

Aidez-nous à financer la somme qui nous manque pour permettre de boucler le budget total "FESTIVAL AVIGNON OFF 2016 de 20000€ (salaires, logement et nourriture et déplacement pour 7 personnes, frais de création du spectacle, affiches, tracts et autres frais de communication et diffusion).

On compte sur vous, et d'ores et déjà, MILLE MERCIS !!


Les fonds collectés serviront à financer :

  • une partie des frais de location du logement pour toute l'équipe à Avignon (2000€ pour les 3 semaines de festival)
  • les 600€ de frais d'inscription au catalogue du Off (catalogue qui répertorie tous les spectacles présents au festival, publicité indispensable !)
  • la commission d'Indiegogo.

Il n'y a pas de petite contribution ! 
Et si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement, mais que vous souhaitez soutenir notre projet, n'hésitez pas à faire passer le mot et à faire de la publicité pour notre projet. Plus il y aura de personnes au courant, plus on aura de chances de réussir notre collecte !


EN SAVOIR PLUS SUR ADIEU BERENICE

LE PITCH
Depuis qu’ils sont sortis du Conservatoire où ils se sont rencontrés, Paul et Julie n’ont cessé de jouer ensemble.
Or voici qu’ils ont été choisis par Luchino Scontirelli, un metteur en scène de renommée internationale, elle, pour le rôle de Bérénice, lui pour celui de Titus, dans la pièce de Jean Racine. Une chance pour ces jeunes comédiens ! Cependant, issus d’une formation des plus classiques, Paul et Julie sont quelque peu déroutés par l’approche non conventionnelle de Bérénice que leur propose Scontirelli, assisté de Freddy, un garçon pour le moins prosaïque. Il faut dire que, jusqu’à présent Scontirelli n’a pas monté d’œuvre du répertoire classique.
A le voir travailler avec son assistant, on peut se demander s’il sait vraiment où il va avec Bérénice ?
Et jusqu’où, Paul et Julie sont prêts à le suivre ?  


GENESE DE LA PIECE
"Je n’avais écrit que des comédies jusqu’au jour où Giorgio Carpintieri m’a commandé une pièce non nécessairement comique, où il jouerait le rôle d’un chanteur lyrique raté. Ainsi est née Le Maître et le Chanteur, comédie tragique sur des airs d’opéras. Le succès de cette pièce l’a conduit à me demander d’écrire un drame parallèle qui se situerait cette fois dans le milieu du théâtre et non plus de l’opéra. Dans Le Maître et le Chanteur, l’œuvre sur laquelle les deux personnages travaillent est Macbeth, l’opéra de Verdi ; dans Adieu Bérénice, c’est Bérénice, la tragédie de Racine, que j’ai choisie comme base de travail. Comme le Chanteur qui vient demander conseil à un Maître, je fais se confronter un couple de jeunes comédiens à un personnage de référence ; mais là s’arrête le parallèle, car, contrairement au Maître, ce personnage est un homme célèbre, reconnu pour son talent et apparemment sans problèmes."

Michel Heim


DISTRIBUTION

Michel Heim : Texte
François Tantot : Mise en scène
Giacomo Anastasi : Musiques originales (jouées en live)

Jeu :
Aude Carpintieri - Julie, comédienne, compagne de Paul
Giorgio Carpintieri - Luchino Scontirelli, metteur en scène de renom
François Tantot - Paul, comédien, compagnon de Julie
Giacomo Anastasi - Ennio, musicien, ami de Luchino Scontirelli
Stéphan Meynet - Freddy, assistant de Luchino Scontirelli


Milena Carpintieri-Tusa : Costumes
Stéphan Meynet : Création lumières


L'EQUIPE

Michel HEIM - Auteur

Michel Heim est né à Paris en 1945.
Il débute au théâtre dans la compagnie Les Caramels fous. Comédien et chanteur, il écrit, pour la célèbre troupe de gays militants, une dizaine de spectacles musicaux cocasses et débridés, dont Les Dindes galantes, qui obtient un Molière du Théâtre Privé, en 2006. Auteur d’une vingtaine de comédies pastiches, pseudo-littéraires ou historiques, il excelle en virtuose du détournement, poussant l’art du stéréotype pour en révéler les dessous plus complexes, plus humains. 
En 2012, Michel Heim écrit pour la compagnie Soleluna, Besame Macho, qui rencontre le succès la même année en Avignon. Il aborde pour la première fois le registre tragique avec Le Maître et le Chanteur, composé en 2013, en exclusivité pour la compagnie Soleluna.


François TANTOT - Metteur en scène / Paul

Formé au Conservatoire de Chambéry et au sein de la Cie U gomina, François Tantot enchaîne depuis 1997 les créations avec différentes compagnies de la région lyonnaise : U Gomina, Andante Casimollo, Les affamés (Les pavés de l'ours  de G. Feydeau, Variations énigmatiques d’E.E. Schmitt, L’île des esclaves de Marivaux, Jacques le Fataliste de Diderot) , Persona (Roméo dans Roméo et Juliette  de W. Shakespeare en 2002), La Pèlerine, Soleluna (Le maitre et le chanteur, Orgie romaine, Cosi son tutte), Swingthéâtrois (  L’Ecole des Femmes  de Molière en 2005),  Combats absurdes (Music-Hall de Jean-Luc lagarce, La maison et le zoo d'Edward Albi, Vertiges de Jon Fosse), Cie Carnages (Si ce n'est toi d'Edward Bond… Il participe à de nombreuses créations de la compagnie Les Désaxés Théâtre :La Barbe de bouc  de Yordan Raditchkov, Andrea del Sarto  d'Alfred de Musset, Des Couteaux dans les poules  de David Harrower, Falaises  de Jean-Yves Picq, Le Moche de Marius von Mayenburg, Eva Peron de Coppi. Son expérience du théâtre et du chant de rue lui permettent d’aborder des rôles joués et chantés dans Shweyk dans la deuxième guerre mondiale  de Bertolt Brecht, Le Médecin malgré lui  de Molière et Charles Gounod ou encore dans le spectacle musical Y' a des zazous de Lionel Armand.

Il adapte et met en scène le premier roman d’Amélie Nothomb Hygiène de l’assassin pour la cie Les Affamés, se spécialise dans l’écriture de spectacles jeune public et concrétise sa passion pour la musique en composant les musiques de divers spectacles théâtraux.
Il continue en parallèle l’animation d’ateliers théâtre et intervient auprès d’enfants dans des écoles, des collèges et des quartiers mais également auprès des personnes âgées en maisons de retraite.


Aude CARPINTIERI - Julie

Titulaire d’un Bac Théâtre et d’une licence de Lettres et Arts du spectacle, elle se forme au théâtre classique et contemporain avec Roland Chalosse et Pierre Bianco et à la commedia dell’arte avec Gérard Dubuis, Alberto Nason (théâtre des Asphodèles — Lyon) et Antonio Fava (SIAC – Reggio Emilia, Italie).

Elle suit divers stages de danse (africaine, tango, danses de la Renaissance), chant (C. Spranger, Centre de la Voix), théâtre (Racine et la versification avec Jean-Marc Avocat), voix off (studio Pilon) et s’initie à l’escrime de spectacle avec la compagnie Scaramouche.

En 2003, elle fonde la Compagnie Soleluna avec laquelle elle enchaîne les créations et explore de plus en plus le théâtre musical. En 2008 elle participe, en tant que comédienne bilingue franco-italienne, à une tournée à Rome sous la direction de Claude Carmelli, et travaille régulièrement depuis 2010 sous la direction de Gilles Droulez (Cie les Affamés) et Thierry Vincent (Compagnie Petit Théâtre). 
Elle a joué dans une vingtaine de spectacles d’auteurs contemporains et classiques : R.Obaldia, J.Romain, J-M.Ribes, O.Chiacchiari, Marivaux, H.Levin, P.Minyana, K.Gibran, A.Genovese, M.Heim, C.Veltchéva, C.Carmelli, G.Feydeau, D.Fo, V.Compagnon, K.Valentin, J-M. Avocat, H.Caillaud, L. Pirandello et R. Toriel.
Avec « Thavmata », elle signe sa première mise en scène pour Soleluna. 



Stéphan MEYNET -  Création lumière / Freddy

Il a rencontré le théâtre au lycée aux côtés de C. Damidaux et de S. Mongin (Cie Les 3 Huit). Comédien et metteur en scène autodidacte au sein de la troupe étudiante Arthémis dès 1994, il crée le festival universitaire Les Arthémiades en 1997 et se forme au théâtre de l’Oseraie à Lyon pendant 3 ans, aux côtés de M. Dufour, C. Tarry et S. Puel. 

Il anime en parallèle, dès 1995, différents ateliers à l’Université Lyon1, puis rejoint la Cie Bath’art en tant que comédien et éclairagiste. Il travaille comme régisseur plateau du théâtre Tête d’Or puis abandonne ses études scientifiques pour une licence d’études théâtrales (suivie d’un master), avant d’être engagé comme régisseur général puis directeur technique du Théâtre de l’Astrée. 
Il se perfectionne aux côtés de P. Clément, H. Daguin (Théâtre de l’Iris), F. Maimone, participe au bocal (Cie la Hors De), et multiplie les rencontres théâtrales. Il suit divers stages (clown, mime, voix) et crée parallèlement la Cie, Kapibara, un festival sur les pentes de la Croix-Rousse, puis récupère la direction du Théâtre de l’Anagramme. Il y encadre depuis 2004 les ateliers de formation.
Il rejoint enfin, en 2007, Nicolas Guépin, au sein de Broutille et compagnie, sous les différentes casquettes de comédien, metteur en scène, formateur, et technicien. Stéphan est également éclairagiste de G. Maimone, F. Maimone, A. Lopez.
En 2013 il rejoint la Compagnie Soleluna en tant que régisseur lumière et comédien, et signe la création lumière d’Espérance, Thavmata, Le maître et le chanteur, Cosi son tutte et Si grande… si petite !


Giorgio CARPINTIERI - Luchino Scontirelli

Giorgio Carpintieri est né à Palerme en 1951.
Formé “dans la rue”, c’est au cabaret Il Ridotto de sa ville natale qu’il commence le théâtre dans les années 1970, donnant vie à des poèmes satiriques et des textes politiquement engagés.
Émissions de radio et de télévision, animation de spectacles, production de concerts jazz sont autant d’activités qu'il exerce pendant dix ans. À la fin des années 1970, une autre vie commence en France, celle de l’architecte. Après cette “parenthèse” de 25 ans, Giorgio Carpintieri revient à sa première passion en intégrant la compagnie Soleluna, en tant que co-directeur artistique, comédien et metteur en scène. 
Parmi ses interprétations on compte La Nuit des Reines, Néron la Romaine, Tante Olga et Besame macho de Michel Heim, L’impromptu de Vénissieux, Schisme, Quelque part dans cette vie de Israël Horovitz et La Vie de Paroisse d’Andrea Genovese. Il a mis en scène Idylle d’Andrea Genovese, L’aveugle / Le Fou / Lazare et sa bien-aimée trilogie de Khalil Gibran, Néron la romaine, Tante Olga, Besame Macho et Orgie romaine de Michel Heim et Espérance de Catherine Veltchéva.



Giacomo ANASTASI -  Musiques originales / Ennio

Né à Messina en Italie. 

Après 10 ans passés dans un groupe historique de musique traditionnelle, « il melograno » à Messina (Sicile), il a créé le projet ZANCLE en 2001 à Lyon, à partir de la rencontre avec trois autres musiciens unis par la volonté de faire découvrir quelques-unes des plus belles traditions musicales du sud de l’Italie. 
Depuis 11 ans, il participe avec ZANCLE, à nombreux festivals et événements organisés par des associations culturelles Italiennes ou des municipalités, des maisons de quartiers, des écoles de musiques, ainsi que dans des soirées privées. 
En 2008, il crée MUSICA CRUDA QUARTET avec lequel il explore le répertoire des auteurs-compositeurs italiens des années 50’ à nos jours.
Grand passionné des traditions musicales de Sud de l’Italie, il choisit de proposer un répertoire traditionnel napolitain, et en 2010 naît VOCE ‘E NOTTE.
Parallèlement à cet engagement dans la musique traditionnelle, Giacomo Anastasi est un remarquable guitariste, un compositeur et arrangeur. Ses différents registres lui confèrent une riche palette d’interprétations.
C’est grâce à cette richesse qu’il a été repéré par la Compagnie Soleluna en 2010 pour intégrer le spectacle de commedia dell’arte Voir Naples et mourir en tant que guitariste, mandoliniste et chanteur. Depuis, il est la « pièce musicale maîtresse » de la Compagnie Soleluna qui produit désormais ses concerts, et participe à tous les spectacles musicaux de la compagnie.


Milena TUSA-CARPINTIERI -  Costumière et accessoiriste

Milena Tusa-Carpintieri, après des études de lettres, a commencé à voyager : Palerme, Turin, Palerme, Les Carroz d’Arâches, Annecy, Usinens et… Lyon. Ces nombreux déplacements lui ont permis de connaître des hommes et des femmes, des cultures, des coutumes diverses. Elle est passionnée de mythologie, de traditions populaires, d’artisanat d’art. Ce riche patrimoine jumelé à une subtile maîtrise et la grande passion pour l’artisanat l’ont amené, dans le sillon familial, à la réalisation des costumes de théâtre et des décors de scène. 
Depuis elle est régisseuse plateau de la Compagnie et costumière-décoratrice. Elle est la pièce maîtresse de nos coulisses !
story_txt:
QUI SOMMES- NOUS ?

De ses origines italiennes, la Compagnie Soleluna puise une vitalité flamboyante et l’art de marier les genres, humour et sensible… soleil et lune !
Elle a croisé dans sa folle course d’autres aérolithes du genre, tels Michel Heim, dont elle a repris l’œuvre presque intégrale, Pierre Bianco, qui a signé nombreuses mises en scène, ou encore les inclassables Fabio Marra, Luca Franceschi…Évoluant entre théâtre, musique et danse, Soleluna met l’énergie et le talent de sa constellation de comédiens-chanteurs, musiciens et danseurs, à la portée de tous, et même des plus petits !Fondée en 2003, la Compagnie a établi son camp de base dans l’aéronef de l’Étoile Royale Théâtre, à Lyon.
Tous nos spectacles et dates de tournées sont sur http://www.compagnie-soleluna.netEt vous pouvez suivre en temps réel l'actualité de la Compagnie sur Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/cie.soleluna
Depuis 2009, la compagnie s'emploie à mêler théâtre, musique et danse..Travaillant en étroite collaboration avec des musiciens et danseurs, elle a monté trois comédies musicales écrites par Michel Heim, auteur connu et reconnu pour ses comédies, parodies et comédies musicales. 


On ne présente plus Michel HEIM !
Roi du divertissement parodique et pape du théâtre privé parisien, il a expérimente avec la Compagnie Soleluna un nouveau genre, en écrivant pour elle sa première comédie tragique, "Le maître et le chanteur" dont la création a pu voir le jour grâce au soutien de nos spectateurs et amis, en 2013. 
Souhaitant continuer à explorer cette facette plus dramatique de l'auteur, dans laquelle il excelle autant que dans le registre comique, nous lui avons commandé une nouvelle pièce dans le même registre et de là est née ADIEU BERENICE, qui nous plonge cette fois au coeur du théâtre contemporain et sera donc présenté en alternance avec LE MAITRE ET LE CHANTEUR au Festival d'Avignon Off 2016.

POURQUOI FAIRE AVIGNON ?
Le Festival d'Avignon est devenu un "passage obligé" pour faire connaître notre travail, développer la compagnie et contribuer à la faire vivre à travers la vente des spectacle et les tournées. 

La Compagnie Soleluna s'autofinance et ne bénéficie d'aucune subvention.C'est grâce à votre soutien et votre générosité (même les petits montants sont précieux !) que nous pourrons affronter sereinement cette nouvelle aventure avignonnaise ! 

Aidez-nous à financer la somme qui nous manque pour permettre de boucler le budget total "FESTIVAL AVIGNON OFF 2016 de 20000€ (salaires, logement et nourriture et déplacement pour 7 personnes, frais de création du spectacle, affiches, tracts et autres frais de communication et diffusion).
On compte sur vous, et d'ores et déjà, MILLE MERCIS !!

Les fonds collectés serviront à financer :


une partie des frais de location du logement pour toute l'équipe à Avignon (2000€ pour les 3 semaines de festival)

les 600€ de frais d'inscription au catalogue du Off (catalogue qui répertorie tous les spectacles présents au festival, publicité indispensable !)
la commission d'Indiegogo.



Il n'y a pas de petite contribution ! Et si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement, mais que vous souhaitez soutenir notre projet, n'hésitez pas à faire passer le mot et à faire de la publicité pour notre projet. Plus il y aura de personnes au courant, plus on aura de chances de réussir notre collecte !

EN SAVOIR PLUS SUR ADIEU BERENICE
LE PITCHDepuis qu’ils sont sortis du Conservatoire où ils se sont rencontrés, Paul et Julie n’ont cessé de jouer ensemble.Or voici qu’ils ont été choisis par Luchino Scontirelli, un metteur en scène de renommée internationale, elle, pour le rôle de Bérénice, lui pour celui de Titus, dans la pièce de Jean Racine. Une chance pour ces jeunes comédiens ! Cependant, issus d’une formation des plus classiques, Paul et Julie sont quelque peu déroutés par l’approche non conventionnelle de Bérénice que leur propose Scontirelli, assisté de Freddy, un garçon pour le moins prosaïque. Il faut dire que, jusqu’à présent Scontirelli n’a pas monté d’œuvre du répertoire classique.A le voir travailler avec son assistant, on peut se demander s’il sait vraiment où il va avec Bérénice ?Et jusqu’où, Paul et Julie sont prêts à le suivre ?  
GENESE DE LA PIECE"Je n’avais écrit que des comédies jusqu’au jour où Giorgio Carpintieri m’a commandé une pièce non nécessairement comique, où il jouerait le rôle d’un chanteur lyrique raté. Ainsi est née Le Maître et le Chanteur, comédie tragique sur des airs d’opéras. Le succès de cette pièce l’a conduit à me demander d’écrire un drame parallèle qui se situerait cette fois dans le milieu du théâtre et non plus de l’opéra. Dans Le Maître et le Chanteur, l’œuvre sur laquelle les deux personnages travaillent est Macbeth, l’opéra de Verdi ; dans Adieu Bérénice, c’est Bérénice, la tragédie de Racine, que j’ai choisie comme base de travail. Comme le Chanteur qui vient demander conseil à un Maître, je fais se confronter un couple de jeunes comédiens à un personnage de référence ; mais là s’arrête le parallèle, car, contrairement au Maître, ce personnage est un homme célèbre, reconnu pour son talent et apparemment sans problèmes."
Michel Heim

DISTRIBUTION
Michel Heim : TexteFrançois Tantot : Mise en scèneGiacomo Anastasi : Musiques originales (jouées en live)
Jeu :Aude Carpintieri - Julie, comédienne, compagne de PaulGiorgio Carpintieri - Luchino Scontirelli, metteur en scène de renomFrançois Tantot - Paul, comédien, compagnon de JulieGiacomo Anastasi - Ennio, musicien, ami de Luchino ScontirelliStéphan Meynet - Freddy, assistant de Luchino Scontirelli
Milena Carpintieri-Tusa : CostumesStéphan Meynet : Création lumières

L'EQUIPE

Avocat, H.Caillaud, L. Pirandello et R. Toriel.Avec « Thavmata », elle signe sa première mise en scène pour Soleluna.

story:
Fairmount Center for the Arts faces closure this fall without your help.

For more than 40 years, Fairmount Center has been a place where students could discover their artistic talents and enjoy all the benefits that art can bring: creativity, self-esteem, friendship, mentorship, passion, healthy living, and even lifelong career opportunities. Fairmount Center's goal is to help all people - regardless of their age, ability, or training - explore themselves as creative and artistic beings.

After years of financial struggles, Fairmount is facing its most significant challenge yet: if we are not able to raise $50,000 in the coming weeks, Fairmount will be forced to close its doors this fall.


The goal of this online campaign is set at $20,000 from individual donors. However, we are seeking an additional $30,000 from foundations, corporations, and major gift donors, too.

 
Our Challenge

As you may know, Fairmount Center has faced significant financial challenges over the past five years, including the accumulation of credit card debt and the extension of its line of credit. This summer, the Board authorized a special campaign to let the community know about our dire financial situation and ask for its support to help us make up our cash shortfall. That effort yielded about $8,000 in support; a modest sum compared to the $35,000 we needed to cover expenses.

We saw a small infusion of cash in August from fall registrations which gave us reason to believe we might be able to overcome our challenges without significant outside support. However, we noted at that time that we did not know if the money we received was from new registrations and new money or merely early registrations from existing students. It now appears it was early registrations and not new. Our fall registration is only up about 5% over last year.

Moving forward, we will not have sufficient funds to make our next payroll or any payroll through the year end.  It is an understatement to say that this a dire situation for Fairmount. We cannot operate without paying our faculty and staff.

What We Have Done

In the last year, we have done the following to try to help turn things around for Fairmount. We believe these steps have prolonged the life of Fairmount but time has not been on our side and without signficant financial support we have not been able to significantly improve our situation. Since summer 2011, we have:

  • Cut operating expenses by 15%
  • Engaged an accountant and began forecasting, created an operating budget, established a process for collecting on payments, and identified areas for savings 
  • Began regular finance committee meetings with the Board of Directors to examine Fairmount's finances
  • Reduced debt spending and ceased using credit cards to make payroll
  • Began a plan for debt reduction and examined/re-negotiated credit cards and leases to try to save money and avoid interest and penalties
  • Cut programming that had resulted in major cash losses, including the elimination of professional theatre
  • Created new programming - particularly in the areas of dance and art and including events like Paint Nite; Sunday evening cafes; an enhanced tap program; dance mini-sessions; early childhood art workshops; PlopArt; mini-sessions and more.
  • Began meeting regularly as a staff which has strengthened our program offerings and fostered several cross-collaborations
  • Wrote proposals for more than $150,000 in foundation support
  • Planned and executed a large-scale benefit with $10,000 in revenue
  • Made significant changes to our building - nearly all by 100% donation - and made our facility more functional and welcoming
  • Hosted two community open house events to engage our public
  • Created Friends of Fairmount, an auxiliary group designed to provide support for Fairmount Center and its activities
  • Implemented Legally Addicted, a programming effort that has yielded terrific publicity for Fairmount and resulted in many new community relationships
  • Significantly increased our marketing efforts, resulting in several feature stories in local papers, an enhanced website, and Clear Channel radio spots
  • Explored ways to make our programs more profitable and reduce outside rental costs, particularly in the area of music
  • Began renting Fairmount for parties and events as an additional revenue stream

Further, we are in the process of implementing on-line registration and a database program that we believe would take us to a new level in terms of accessibility for our students and new ways to reach our audiences.

The Bottom Line

Time is not on Fairmount's side. Despite our best efforts, unless something drastic happens in the next week, the Board of Directors anticipates we will close our doors this fall in what is called a "wind down." The details of this possibility are still being worked out and the Board will meet this Saturday, 10/13, to determine next steps.

If you value the arts - if you love Fairmount - if you believe our community is made stronger by having a place like Fairmount to gather and learn - please help. Any amount helps.

story:
Blue Ceiling dance

Blue Ceiling dance has been creating, commissioning and producing contemporary dance, dance theatre and multi-disciplinary works in the Toronto area for over 10 years. We are an independent company, working project-by-project to create intimate, unforgettable performances with physical virtuosity and emotional depth.

Our campaign centres on our newest production dead reckoning which will premiere at Theatre Centre January 13-17, 2016. 

This is our most ambitious work, staged in the round in the incredibly unusual Incubator Space at Theatre Centre. Our show seamlessly combines choreography by artistic director Lucy Rupert and internationally renowned ballet choreographer Peter Quanz in his experimental, contemporary vein. 

This new production explores the power of the mind to produce what we need in times of great distress. Inspired by the mystical experiences of many extreme explorers -- Everest mountaineers and most significantly Sir Ernest Shackleton in his ill-fated Antarctic expedition of 1914 -- the choreographers perform with Toronto dance dynamos Elke Schroeder and Sky Fairchild-Waller for a unforgettable romp through images, sensations, stories and exquisite physicality.

What We Need & What You Get

We are fundraising in two ways, first through our presenting partner DanceWorks where donations of $25 or more which are earmarked for Blue Ceiling dance will be issued a charitable donation tax receipt. (www.danceworks.ca)

Our second route of fundraising is Indiegogo. Through Indiegogo you can donate any amount and know that it has big impact on a small company like us. 

Donors of $150 or more will receive two tickets to the dead reckoning performance of their choice and invites to future sneak peek events with Blue Ceiling dance.

Donors of $75-$149 will receive one ticket to the dead reckoning performance of their choice and invites to future sneak peek events with Blue Ceiling dance.

All donors will receive recognition in our program and on our website and invite to our sneak peek events.

You can, of course, opt out of public recognition if you want to remain anonymous. We respect that. You won't be added to any fundraising database, only to Blue Ceiling's mailing list.

The Impact

We are aiming for just $500 which would cover the costs of our props (vast rolls of transforming paper!) and lighting equipment rentals (lights that will become people!).

$500 could also cover about 20 hours of rehearsal for one of our dancers or the per diem from our visiting choreographer Peter Quanz, or insurance for our time in theatre, or 20 hours of marketing and administrative support! 

Blue Ceiling places the greatest value on the human resources that go into every show. Our budget is first and foremost for the artists, designers and crew that make it all happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for volunteers to assist at shows, distribute flyers or help at other Blue Ceiling dance events. If you can't donate but would like to get involved email me, Lucy, at blueceiling@sympatico.ca

story:
Short Summary

Jerry, an uptight stoner, takes a toke on his favorite holiday and wakes up in the Land of 420, where the only way to get home is the find the elusive Mighty High. Along his journey, he discovers the true meaning of the number 420. 

420: The Musical was written by John Kehoe with music by Laura Lonski. © 


We appreciate any and all donations! No amount is too small. 


The money raised through this fundraising campaign will be used to offset the costs of the following:

  • Theater Rental 
  • Musicians/Actors
  • Set Design
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Choreography
  • Marketing
  • Merchandise
  • Photography/Filming Show 
  • Sound/Light/Tech
  • Transportation costs 
  • Rehearsal space rental

The Impact

This musical is a (pun intended) grass roots theatrical production that is now an annual tradition. 420: The Musical proudly supports local musicians and gives work to actors, singers, and stage hands, while providing a positive message and association with the number 420. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are plenty of other ways to help 420: The Musical besides a monetary donation! Here are some ways you can get involved:

Give us a shout out or like us on social media!

Twitter: @420themusical

Facebook: www.facebook.com/420themusical

Instagram: @420themusical

Tickets: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2500142

You can help us advertise with posters in your neighborhood and by word of mouth to friends

You can volunteer your time and skills by joining our 420 Team! Send an e-mail with a description of your skill set to 420themusical@gmail.com 

You can always share our Indiegogo page with your friends using the Indiegogo share tools

story:
Short Summary

Acting Innocent Theatre Company was created by a group of ambitious teens from Tucson, Arizona. This group of talented individuals all share the same passion for theatre. They all met while performing in a national competing one act "Boys Next Door". This show sparked their flame to create a theatre company. The mission of this company is to put on provocative shows, that evoke emotions in the audience, as well as promote discussion within the community about modern social issues that are not heavily addressed in our day to day lives.

What We Need & What You Get

All of the funding that we obtain from you goes straight into the company. The money will  be used for renting theaters, rehearsing plays, and building sets. This money, if raised, will help us keep the company afloat and make sure we keep putting on high quality plays! Check out our perks to see the benefits you will receive from donating to our cause!

The Impact

Our ultimate goal in this company is to make our community feel something. We want our audience to see things in a new light. Every play we choose will have a topic or underlying theme that people need to be more aware of. At the end of every show there will be a discussion, in which the audience is encouraged to give a candid opinion. Art motivates individuals to embrace their community, and to respect the modern challenges faced by many. 

Risks & Challenges

A strong risk we run into when creating a theatre company is failure to satisfy our community. We believe to have some of the most talented actors in the city. Yet we cannot fulfill our dreams of acting if we do not have the funds to put on these shows. One of the advantages we have is that there are no other provocative theatre companies in Tucson. We also believe our repertoire could come off as vulgar and crude but we believe our target audience will appreciate us bringing to light several important themes.

Other Ways You Can Help

You don't have to donate to help us out! You can also share the campaign on your social media! And lastly you can come support us directly at our shows in Tucson, visit our website for more information, acting innocent.com. Spread the word about our company!

story:
For her graduate solo performance thesis in May of 2016, Jess Otterbine created and perfromed an original theatrical piece entitled Ophelia that investigates Shakespeare's Hamlet’s young woman through a feminist lens. The piece came to explore this character in the context of positive female sexuality and abortion rights. 

After a powerful reception of the piece, Jess decided to embark on a project to create a series of 5 solo-ish performances that would each use a different Shakespearean woman to interrogate contemporary feminist topics. Over the last year, Jess wrote a new piece entitled Ravished which follows Shakespeare's Lavinia of Titus Andronicus as she navigates rape culture and trauma.  

These pieces honestly, bravely, and openly discuss subjects that are deeply linked to the female experience. There is a deep need for these stories. That's where you come in. Produced in conjunction with Mz. Initiative and their Mz. Perspective series, Jess and her collaborators will mount a repertory of both Ophelia and Ravished in January of 2018.  

What We Need & What You Get

How can you help us? Putting together theatrical productions is no easy feat. The artists have been working hard to bring this project into fruition. Your contribution will provide:

  • Monetary support for all of the artists and collaborators working on this piece.
  • Props, sets, and costumes.
  • Intermission experience for patrons, including food, drink, and an in-theme art exhibit. 

The Impact

With this project we hope to engage the local Philly community in a discussion and dialogue of these difficult but necessary topics. 

For more information on Mz. Initiative, please visit their website at https://www.mz-initiative.org/. And to get to know more about Jess Otterbine as an artist, please visit her website at http://jessotterbine.com/.

story:
Accepted to the National Black Theater Festival! 

August 7th and 8th, 2015

Dear supporters, we want to thank you for following this project, which has been a true "labor of love!"

  • If you didn't know already, The Clothesline Muse collaborators are also family Maya Freelon Asante, who created the set design is Kariamu Welsh’s daughter-in-law; Kariamu is the choreographer and Nnenna Freelon who plays the lead role as Grandma Blu, is Maya's mother. Nnenna also created the original music for the production. All three are producers and writers. 
  • We are thrilled with the honor of performing The Clothesline Muse, at the National Black Theater Festival, but we need your help to get there!
  • We need to raise $15,000.00

What will $15,000.00 do?

  • Raising $15,000.00 will help us bring the revamped production and our entire cast and crew to the NBTF in Winston Salem, NC. The cast and crew are based in Durham, NC, Philly and New York.
  • We also plan to create exciting new costumes!
  • New projections, new music and dance
  • WE want to bring our best to this NATIONAL Festival
  • We need to pay for studio time, rehearsals and technical consultations 
  • Hotel and travel alone has maxed out our bank account, so we really do need your help!
  • We have some fun perks lined up for your support!
  • Every penny will go to making this the best Clothesline Muse performance yet!
  • Consider donating in honor of your grandmother, or great-grandmother

Intergenerational Dialog

The impact of sharing TCM with the world is huge! For a new production company to be included in The National Black Theater Festival  is almost unheard of. TCM is an evening of stories- intergenerational stories we need to hear, especially today when the noise of pop-culture threatens to drown out the voices of the past. We need safe spaced to talk about things that are hard like...  

  • Race, class and gender
  • Sacrifices made by our ancestors
  • How to "connect" with today's youth

TCM does this through song, dance and imagery. Let us listen, truly listen to each others stories, help us hang them all on the line!

Please help us spread the word!

  • Forward this campaign to your friends and family!
  • You can copy the link into an email OR use Indiegogo share tools!
  • More info about The Clothesline Muse on our website www.theclotheslinemuse.com
  • Join us at the National Black Theater Festival

Thanks again for your support!

story:
KERA radio & expanded review THE ALIENS by Jerome Weeks

" ... this production is amazingly meticulous..."

http://artandseek.net/2013/08/12/review-upstart-productions-the-aliens/

DALLAS MORNING NEWS review THE ALIENS by Lawson Taitte

Theater Jones Review of THE ALIENS by Kris Noteboom

"...Denson and his cast have found a companion in the text that they, in turn, give a deafening, yet ultimately unheard, voice to."

http://www.theaterjones.com/reviews/20130810080610/2013-08-14/Upstart-Productions/The-Aliens

DALLAS MORNING NEWS review THE ALIENS by Lawson Taitte

"I'm finally starting to get Annie Baker's Work."

http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/columnists/lawson-taitte/20130810-the-aliens-proves-that-annie-baker-is-the-real-thing.ece

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS

  • Upstart Productions was formed to usher in the next generation of local artists by providing them with the opportunity to showcase their talents and develop their craft on and off stage.  We are dedicated to the ideal of contributing to the local community by giving these artists an avenue for the production of exceptional contemporary, classical, and original works.  It is our conviction that the theater should foster growth for artist and audience alike and should be accessible to individuals from all walks of life.

     

EVERY CENT YOU DONATE WILL GO DIRECTLY TO CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ARTISTS TO SHOW THEIR STUFF AND KEEPING TICKET PRICES AFFORDABLE FOR AUDIENCES.

What We Need & What You Get

  1. It all costs money. Every screw, every drop of paint; from the progams you read to the electricity bill for the lights, IT ALL ADDS UP.

    AND WE HAVE FAITH IN OUR COMMUNITY TO HELP.

    For your contribution, you will recieve anywhere from our thanks to show tickets to invites to exclusive events AND MORE!

     

The Impact

Upstart Productions has a proven track record of producing quality works, bridging the gap between established and unestablished artists and creating opportunites for artists (both on and off the stage) to be noticed.

http://www.upstarttheater.com/honors/

http://www.upstarttheater.com/press/

It's a tough game, this theatre stuff.

With financial support for the arts dissappearing more every year and arts organizations circling the wagons, it's important to value a place where NEW artists are given a chance.

Creating quality theater is a team effort!  You can make a big difference by directly contributing to the growth and development of DFW's up-and-coming theatrical talent.  Your tax-deductible contribution will ensure that Upstart Productions can continue to produce exceptional plays and keep fresh faces working in the local theater community.  As a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, Upstart relies on support from Dallas theater lovers like you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Tell your friends!

Post a link to this page on your Facebook & Twitter! Not just once, but everyday thoughout the campaign! We'll be adding new content throughout.

Post how Upstart Productions has enriched your life & why YOU believe people should donate!

Upstart Productions was formed to usher in the next generation of local artists by providing them with the opportunity to showcase their talents and develop their craft on and off stage.  We are dedicated to the ideal of contributing to the local community by giving these artists an avenue for the production of exceptional contemporary, classical, and original works.  It is our conviction that the theater should foster growth for artist and audience alike and should be accessible to individuals from all walks of life.
 


EVERY CENT YOU DONATE WILL GO DIRECTLY TO CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ARTISTS TO SHOW THEIR STUFF AND KEEPING TICKET PRICES AFFORDABLE FOR AUDIENCES.



What We Need & What You Get


It all costs money. Every screw, every drop of paint; from the progams you read to the electricity bill for the lights, IT ALL ADDS UP.
AND WE HAVE FAITH IN OUR COMMUNITY TO HELP.
For your contribution, you will recieve anywhere from our thanks to show tickets to invites to exclusive events AND MORE!
 





The Impact
Upstart Productions has a proven track record of producing quality works, bridging the gap between established and unestablished artists and creating opportunites for artists (both on and off the stage) to be noticed.

story:
I’m primarily a playwright, but I also direct, dramaturg, act, teach, and design sets, sound, and lights. I’ve written nine full-length plays and a bunch of shorter ones; my works have been performed in venues from Arizona to Florida to Ohio to Brooklyn, NY. I also wrote a book called Workshopping the New Play: A Guide for Playwrights, Directors, and Dramaturgs for students and professionals, especially those new to the important process of workshopping.

I'm asking for help to workshop my own latest play, The Viking Suicides. The idea behind workshopping is to take the rough draft of the play through a process involving seasoned theatre folks. After that, we’ll perform two staged readings where I’ll get all-important audience feedback that will help me ready the play to send out to potential producers. 

Your help will enable me to make this happen.

What we need:

We have to rent rehearsal and performance space for a total of $450. Our director, stage manager, and seven actors will be compensated with small honoraria that total less than the minimum hourly wage (total of $1,485 for about 185 hours of work).

While most of our advertising will be through social media (which costs nothing but time), we still need to print posters, quarter cards, scripts, and programs, which together will run about $100. We’ll be using minimal sets, costumes, and props, for a total of $250.

That totals $2,285.

At the public staged readings we’ll suggest a donation of $10 per person, although what they actually give will be up to the attendees. We hope to earn $1,100 this way.

That leaves $1,185 to raise, which is what we’re hoping you can help with! Any overage will compensate the playwright, whose work is usually just a labor of love. And if the fundraising falls short, I’ll pay the costs out of pocket—alas, also not an uncommon occurrence in this business.

What you’ll get:

$50 donation includes a reserved seat at the show, your choice of Friday, April 27 or Saturday, April 28.

$100 donation gives you a juicy speaking part in the show (which you can give away to someone else if you are too shy)!

All donors will receive an official thank you in the program, and our deepest gratitude.

This play takes more of a social risk than my previous plays. My aim is to highlight the way many people follow the crowd and ultimately sacrifice their capacity for independent thought.

It would be great to have your support in this project as a donor and as someone who can help get the word out. And please try to come to the performances; we'll have talkbacks after each show and I'd love to hear your thoughts and impressions.

story:
The Blue Dog Project

We are Blue Dog Project. For the last year we have been training in Rose Bruford's Master's in Ensemble Theatre programme, and we are pouring what we have learned into a new production. The four of us have come from three continents and four very different backgrounds to study theatre here in London, and our style of performance and production reflects and channels where we have come from. We will be performing in Summerhall, Upper Church, and are eager to share these powerful stories with the wider Edinburgh Fringe audience. 

Sylum is a product of our training together and our differences. It was devised and premiered with the MA Ensemble Theatre class, and contains distillations of each of us.  It is a production about a safe place outside the rules of society, where you can shed your everyday skin and expose the real you, if only for a time. It is a space of brutal words and tender thoughts, of violence and vulnerability. Since the premiere, we four have adapted Sylum for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, focusing in on the stories of each  character and creating a work that is at once both drawn from the premiered production, and also a wholly new piece of theatre. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The goal for this fundraiser is to raise £2000 for this production. Edinburgh is an expensive undertaking, but we are already being supported in kind by Rose Bruford College, who have provided us with a venue at the Fringe and rehearsal space to develop and prepare. 

This funding will primarily go to cover the costs of housing all four of us and a student lightning and sound technician, and to the registration and transport costs that putting up a show in Edinburgh incurs. Each of us is paying for two weeks' lodging in Edinbrugh. Registration fees for the Fringe Festival are several hundred pounds, and the costs of marketing and transport are also factored into the £2000 sum. We have chosen Indiegogo for this because we can raise funds flexibly; even if we do not hit our goal, we can use what funds we do raise to mitigate the personal costs of producing Sylum. 

The benefits for you the contributor are many and varied! In addition to the benefit of helping us to create new and exciting theatre to share with the world, Blue Dog Project has a lot to offer you personally! We have all traveled different paths to this point, and picked up a wide variety of skills. From dance lessons to paintings and the songs of our production, you can earn some truly unique rewards from our unique skill set.

 

What Does It Mean For Us?

This is a one-of-a-kind opportunity for us as actors and theatremakers. The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is a place for taking risks and showing the theatrical world what we've got, and the possible benefits are endless; from awards and reviews to the possibility of having work produced, Edinburgh is a chance for bringing our work to a wider audience and taking it further in our careers. Your support helps us to focus solely on making the best work we can, without the nagging worry behind us of what the financials look like. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Edinburgh itself is in many ways a risk. There are 3,000 shows going on during the festival, and while we have a huge advantage in the Summerhall venue, a known and recognized venue for good works, it's still a challenge to get people in the door. We are a new ensemble, and have not collaborated with each other in such a focused way before, and the production is mostly an untested work, having only had a couple of showings and being modified heavily now for this new run. The financial risks for us are, however, significantly less for us since we are not covering the costs of booking the venue. We are confident in the production and in our abilities, and we really looking forward to putting this work on its feet during the Festival. 

 

Want to Help?

Share this campaign, and share the links to the show event. We're on Twitter, Facebook, and Instragram. Like we said above, one of the big challenges of Edinburgh is getting an audience through the door: the more people who know about us, the better.  

 

Production photos courtesy of Michael O'Reilly.

story:
Short Summary

The Places You'll Go is a somewhat cheeky show inquiring about the balance between success and happiness.  It is the maiden production of Lama Theater Company, created by playwright/director Hila Ben Gera and director Noel MacDuffie.  For us, this is a time of anxiety and excitement as we pull together the money at the same time as we are casting, rehearsing, and doing rewrites. Financial support at this time would go a long way toward helping ease the pressure and let the artistic work take front and center.

This production is our first step in bringing this show to a longer run and an even wider audience!

Erez Drigues has come all the way from Israel to direct the show with his interest in honesty and theatrical clarity.  Shai Fishman, the composer and musical director of the Off Broadway show The Voca People,will compose the music. Jack Hofsiss, the Tony Award winning director of The Elephant Man, is the Creative Adviser for the project.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $3500.  This will go toward rehearsal space, costumes, sets, publicity materials, and props - as well as the many little things (tape, postage, photocopying) that add up. 

We have some great perks for our contributors: Production photos (so you can remember the show forever), a drink with the cast (a priceless memory), and best of all: a homemade dinner with the artistic directors (YUM)!

The Show

The Places You’ll Go is a lighthearted look at the desperate need for success and the ... um... unusual ways some attempt to achieve it. Two existential Postmen and a cast of colorful characters invent and reinvent themselves in a crazed attempt to fill a need they can't ... quite ... define.

The always current issue of struggling to get ahead is especially vital right now. As our economics change drastically and our ability to move up financially in the world seems to be decreasing, we need to ask ourselves where we fall in the balance of success and happiness. What is left for the rest? 

Your contribution helps bring a little humor to this fraught topic and maybe get some minds working!

Plus we have been tapped as the Best New Company of 2014!  Ok, basically by our friends, but we have some really smart friends!


Other Ways You Can Help


If you can contribute, Adam Smith will bless you! 

If you cannot contribute, you can share our campaign with your friends!

Or just come on down to Dixon Place on July 1 at 7:30 and enjoy the show!

story:
Family… 

Changed lives… 

I wanted a place where these two goals could be achieved. I believe I am achieving these goals as we speak. 

I retired from the sheriffs office 18 months ago to open a dance fitness studio with Zumba as the core. 

I retired after 18 years of working mostly the worst areas of the county for Contra Costa County Sheriffs Department. I am also a disabled veteran of the United States Army. I found Dance Fitness (Zumba) and it changed my life. I lost 30 pounds and gained a confidence I didn't know was possible.

After two years of Zumba in a gym, I discovered a Brazilian instructor, Raquel, who taught some of her classes in a night club. 

That summer, Raquel had three months of free classes for men. In the middle of one of her classes, Raquel stepped off the stage, found me in the middle of a class of more then 40 women and pulled me onto the stage to dance. Wow, that had never happened to me before. 

Because of Raquel, I have been a licensed Zumba instructor for the last four years.

The club was quite the dive, but her classes were always packed to over capacity. Each of Raquel's classes and master classes in this place were always special. 

I realized these ladies wanted to dance in a bar like atmosphere without the bar type hassles (drunks and pick up lines). I loved the lights and stage but hated the smell of puke on the floor and the way the owner treated the instructor. 

I thought they deserved a better place to dance and started dreaming of such a place. I started looking on behalf of Raquel. However, about that time, Raquel announced she was moving out of the country with her family. 

I wanted a dedicated space that had all the attributes of a dance club but dedicated to dance fitness. I started thinking I could open such a place myself. The studio would need to be able to make enough money to support itself and I would need to find an instructor as popular as Raquel. 

Those attributes would be a proper dance floor that would be easy on the knees and ankles and still look great, a great stage with easy access, a lighting and sound system, sound proofing and bathrooms (women judge you by your bathrooms). 

My first indication a dance fitness studio could make a profit was  when Raquel told me she would have made $20k the last month she was in California. 

I knew the only way I would have the money to open such a dance studio would be to retire. This was needed to get to my deferred compensation and retirement money. 

A year ago March 2013, the first location fell through because of unforeseen damage to the property. Another deal in a large shopping center fell through in May 2013. 

I did not find an appropriate location until September and due to licensing and construction delays, opened as Studio 925 Dance and Fitness in January 2014. 

I/we opened with several excellent instructors. Each class was like a party and grew every month from January to April. 

In addition to Zumba we offered U-Jam, Dance Fitness, kids dance and martial arts fitness classes.  We held several charity events, master classes and hosted two local college student events (Diablo Valley College, DVC).

The charity events in part were for Hurricane victims in the Philippines and for a juvenile organ transplant recipient.  

The music student union at DVC held a day of concerts that was awesome to behold.  The Chinese student union held a talent show. 

Some of the master classes and training classes have been over the top with some of the biggest names in the dance fitness world (PepperVon, Joy Smith, the Padia family and others) and we have more on line. 

We just finished a special summer class for kids with Down Syndrome from the George Miller Institute. This and the previously mentioned activities are where my heart is. 

Some of the reoccurring comments I hear from customers and visiting instructors alike are, "we love the vibe here", "this place is so special", "there is no place like this", "photos don't do it justice", "we love Studio 925", " we love you (Dana and Michael), please don't go away", even "magical".

In April we had 1,200 people sign in. Not bad for a January opening. Unfortunately summer killed us with several city  (including the various cities surrounding us)  sponsored events like beer and wine festivals to vacations.  

June was the worst but by the end of August we held our biggest events and have started our comeback. 

September and October are looking positive as well. With our number on the incline once again I have no doubt that it can only get better from here.   

With this in mind, I need to mention a few of the challenges I did not have or know I/we had when this adventure started.   

In September 2013 my partner quit the day before I received the keys, leaving me without a lead instructor and partner. 

I took a full time job in San Francisco to help support the studio and my fiancée took over daily operations. We did this because I expended all my operating funds. In fact I spent all my retirement and savings to keep the studio operating. 

These monies were expended partly because we opened ten months later then I anticipated and the construction and labor costs were three times what was quoted. 

Also, Studio 925 is located in a somewhat secluded end of a shopping center off a main road in Pleasant Hill. I often hear locals say they didn't even know we were here.  

This is why, beside rent, our most important need is an experienced professional promoter who is conversant with modern social media. 

After this is the need for an overhead sign to our building so people can find us. 

These are our most pressing needs. We are starting to gain momentum.  It would be very sad indeed if such a "wonderful special place" went away for the lack of operating funds.  

Therefore, I am requesting $55,000 for three things:

• 3 to 6 months of rent (triple net + rent) = $22,500 to $45,000

• Overhead building sign = $4000

• promotion and advertising = $500 month

I have short, medium and long term goals but I have taken to much time already.  I thank each and every person who visits this post and contributes. All I have to offer to contributors at this point are classes. 


Michael Commiskey

Owner Studio 925 Dance and Fitness

925-687-0925

Www.studio925dance.com

This is why, beside rent, our most important need is an experienced professional promoter who is conversant with modern social media. 
After this is the need for an overhead sign to our building so people can find us. 
These are our most pressing needs. We are starting to gain momentum.  It would be very sad indeed if such a "wonderful special place" went away for the lack of operating funds.  
Therefore, I am requesting $55,000 for three things:
• 3 to 6 months of rent (triple net + rent) = $22,500 to $45,000
• Overhead building sign = $4000
• promotion and advertising = $500 month
I have short, medium and long term goals but I have taken to much time already.  I thank each and every person who visits this post and contributes. All I have to offer to contributors at this point are classes. 

Michael Commiskey
Owner Studio 925 Dance and Fitness
925-687-0925
Www.studio925dance.com

story:
YOU CAN STILL

DONATE TO OUR PAYPAL:

https://www.paypal.com/us/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_flow&SESSION=lHGTC2WrMxWfWHDdgCDGOWtXH0ej2Nb40zYAG-_u7JiJ9djFZZPNTaA-mgO&dispatch=5885d80a13c0db1f8e263663d3faee8d0b7e678a25d883d0fa72c947f193f8fd

 

LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS

(DONATIONS CAN BE MADE IN ANY AMOUNT)

November 30, 2012 | 10pm • December 1, 2012 | 7pm & 11pm • December 2, 2012 | 2pm

The Jan Popper Theater

The Schoenberg Music Building at UCLA

445 Charles E. Young Drive East | Los Angeles

 

Co Directed by Alex Wolf & Charlotte Hook

Choreographed by Jane Papageorge

Music Directed by Jason Hong

Vocal Directed by India Carney

Produced by Phoebe Stanton

Assistant Produced by Megan Fitzgerald & Cameron Bird

Stage Managed by Isabella Bolognini

Costume Design by Breanna Rae Murillo

Assistant Costume Design by Shany Albalak

Set Design by Norah Houtz

Prop Design by Keara Birmingham

Assistant Prop Design by Jeff Pielago

Lighting Design by Wyatt Bartel

Sound Design by Daniel Tator

 

Book & Lyrics by Douglas Howard Ashman

Music by Alan Menken

Based on the film by Roger Cornman

Screenplay by Charles Griffith

 

 

Featuring:
SEYMOUR: Coby Getzug

AUDREY: Kayla Parker

MUSHNIK: Elan Kramer

ORIN: Adam Cropper

RONNETTE: Kimberley Moore

CHIFFON: Aliysa Shareef

CRYSTAL: Jane Papageorge

PLANT #1 / INTERVIEWER / MARTIN: Kyle Compton

PLANT #2 / MRS. LUCE: Michael Starr

PLANT #3: Austin Vaziri

 

One of the longest-running Off-Broadway shows of all time, Little Shop of Horrors tells the story of Seymour Krelbourn, a struggling florist working on skid row. When he acquires a mysterious, alien plant he must choose between a simple, happy life with his true love, or fame and fortune at a very high price.

Little Shop of Horrors will be free of charge for participants and audiences alike. Act III aims to provide access to theatre for as many students as possible - but we need your help. Again, donations can be made for any amount.

This production would not be possible without your generosity.

 

ABOUT ACT III

Act III is dedicated to providing opportunities for creative expression and exposure for the UCLA student body through professional-level, quality student-run theatre.

This mission is especially important on the UCLA campus, due to the limited opportunities for theatrical involvement on campus. The UCLA Department of Theatre produces one musical each year, with participation restricted to theatre students only. Act III stands out amongst other campus theatre organizations in its professionalism and its policy encouraging students of any major to participate—at no cost.

Little Shop of Horrors will be Act III’s ninth production since our inception in 2008. Past productions have included the Wild Party, Sweet Charity, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead, I Love You, Because and Xanadu.

In addition to our productions, Act III hosts a yearlong musical cabaret and offers special master classes. We also produce two fundraising events: Bruins Care, a musical revue supporting Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, and 24 Hour Musical, a fully-staged musical mounted in 24 Hours to benefit No Limits, an organization that provides theatre programs to deaf children.

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Unfortunately, reaching our $5,000 goal will not close the gap in our budget. The statewide deficit has caused a continuing decrease UCLA organization funding. This is especially problematic for mounting a theatre production, as university funding sources already do not cover many of our expenses. With this limited institutional funding and without charging admission or membership fees, we rely on the generosity of individuals like you.Your contributions will help offset costs that include theater rental, equipment, performance rights, sets and costumes.

You can make a big difference. Anything helps.  

  • $85 covers the cost of royalties for one performance
  • $275 covers half of the rental cost for scripts and scores.
  • $460 covers the the theater rental fee for one day.
  • $805 covers the cost of performance rights & materials.
  • $1,550 covers all labor and equipment costs for one performance

 

There is no way to fully show our gratitude for any and all contributions.

So, please accept the heartfelt appreciation of everyone at Act III, the satisfaction of contributing to the arts and the perks of the Little Shop of Horrors-themed packages listed on this page.

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Your support can come in many forms. Tell your friends about us - share our campaign linkand spread the word!  Give us a thumbs up by liking our Facebook page or mention us when you blog, tweet or tumblr.

Last but not least, come to our show!

story:
The Project:

Having worked for over 2 years to mount this powerful play, we have the theatre rented, rehearsals are well under way, and we are so close to bringing a really brilliant piece of important theatre back to the NY stage.  We are so close to our fundraising goals, we need your help to finish the remaining fundraising so we can present this play the way it deserves. This play hasn't been staged in the US in 80 years, and we want to make sure it is done correctly.

Who We Are:

The Regroup Theatre Company was created in 2010 with the mission to produce "great plays" as defined by The Group Theatre as plays which are "propaganda for a better life." The ReGroup believes that entertaining the audience is not enough; the audience must also have a personal experience. By focusing on theatre's unique gifts - heightened dialogue, creative movement, controlled speech, stylized visuals and communion with a live audience - they hope to blow the years of dust off these plays and make them "awake and sing" once again.  In turn, they hope to inspire new playwrights to write material in this surging larger-than-life nature that will have social impact and relevance. Members of the company’s Board of Advisers include Angelica Page, Estelle Parsons, Austin Pendleton, Molly Regan, Susan Rowland, José Angel Santana, Lois Smith, Wendy Smith and Frances Sternhagen, among others.
 

What We Need

We need to raise the remaining 14% of our budget. We are so close! Even with a volunteer company, the costs of putting on such a complex production is exorbitant. 
With 25 rapid scene changes and over 60 characters, the design budget to make the show soar is not that of your usual off-off Broadway show.  We have things very streamlined, but in order not to skimp on the quality, we need to raise the extra funds.
Anything over the amount we absolutely need will go toward advertising so we can make sure people see the quality work we have been doing.  This is a work that needs to be seen.

What You Get!


Receive our eternal thanks along with other goodies! All donors will receive a thank you in our program, and different donor levels receive tickets, merchandise vouchers, advertising space in the program, and even associate producer credits.

ALL DONORS GET ACCESS TO EXCLUSIVE BEHIND-THE-SCENES REHEARSAL PHOTOS, ETC

 

The Impact

Help us bring powerful, meaningful theatre to the public at a very affordable price.  When we've performed this piece in the past as a one-night-only staged-reading, it had a profound effect on the audience. Help us share it with a wider audience as a full length production.

In this politically devise ore-election time, this play helps show that we are all in this together.  It provides insight and compassion into the plight of the unemployed and the struggling. While the comparissons to the modern day are quite eerie, there is comfort in knowing that we've been here before and have found our way out of the dark.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a donation, you can still help. Please spread the word about our production, volunteer to be on our guerilla marketing team, or pass this donation page on to someone who might be able to donate.  Your kindness is very much appreciated.

story:
THE UNRESERVED TOUR RATIONALLE

In June of 2012 I taped my very own one hour standup comedy special for CBC TV called, "Ryan McMahon - UnReserved." In doing so I became the FIRST Native Comedian to ever tape a one hour special for CBC TV - not bad for a kid that grew up in the bush in Northwestern Ontario. Also, this past summer I was invited to perform at the prestigious Just For Laughs Festival in Montreal - a childhood dream come true. While there I was named to the "New Faces List." This list is an high profile Industry list that gets published in Rolling Stone Magazine, SPIN and other Industry magazines and online blogs as the list identifies "the next crop" of "can't miss, up and coming comedy stars" that people in the Industry should be on the lookout for. Incredible.

So.

In celebration of the most successful (relatively speaking) and rewarding summers of my life - I booked a tour. It began as a modest undertaking - 10 cities, 10 shows, during the month of October. Word got out that the tour was happening and the demand was incredible - people in places that didn't make the tour wanted the show to roll into their city. This was an incredibly humbing and exciting time for me. Quickly, the tour grew to 26 cities, 30 shows and I have 6 weeks to pull it off.

In general people are excited about what I've been able to accomplish in comedy. This is more than a dream come true for me. With art - all you can ever hope for is that people pay attention. Well, they are. And they have. And, so, here we are.

WHY CROWFUNDING, WHY INDIEGOGO?

As the tour was announced it got too big - many requests for shows in towns & cities that I've never played in started to come and I really wanted to extend the tour to those fans that wanted to see the live show for the first time.

So here we are - the dates are booked, the cities are booked and work is well underway to make this tour the amazing success that I know it can be.

WHAT WE NEED FOR THE TOUR

Here is what we need to make the tour a success:

We're asking for a minimum of $15 000 to help offset a majority of the venue bookings costs & the cost of paying technicians to help run the sound & lights at the venues. While $15 000 might seem like a lot of money - it really isn't considering we're doing 30 shows in 26 cities in just under 6 weeks.

We'll also being using some of the funding to help with travel. Most of the tour will be done in ground transportation and the money is NOT being used for First Class airtravel or anything ridiculous. We're travelling humbly and modestly in the most economically reasonable way possible.

WHAT YOU'LL GET FOR SPONSORING

We've set up some awesome "perks" that you'll get for helping to sponsor the tour:

$25 Sponsorship OR the HIGH FIVE & AN NDN HEAD NOD LEVEL: For donating at this level you'll get a ticket to the tour show in your city, a pass to a post show meet & greet, a high five & an ol' fashioned NDN head nod!

$50 Sponsorship or the GIMME A SMOKE ANYWAYS LEVEL: For donating at this level you'll get a ticket to the tour show in your city, a pass to a post show meet & greet, a high five & an ol' fashioned NDN head nod, and a signed limited edition tour poster.

$100 Sponsorship or the FEELING PRETTY CHIEF-EE LEVEL: For donating at this level you'll get 2 tickets to the tour show in your city, passes to a post show meet & greet, a high five & an ol' fashioned NDN head nod, a signed limited edition tour poster & a limited edition tour tshirt.

$500 Sponsorship or the BORROWED THIS FROM MY GRANNY LEVEL: For donating at this level you'll get 10 tickets to the tour show in your city, passes to a post show meet & greet, a high five & an ol' fashioned NDN head nod, a signed limited edition tour poster, a limited edition tour tshirt & a funny recorded voicemail message for your phone.

$1000 Sponsorship or the YOU THINK YOU'RE BETTER THAN ME LEVEL: For donating at this level you'll get 10 tickets to the tour show in your city, a pass to a post show meet & greet, a high five & an ol' fashioned NDN head nod, a signed limited edition tour poster, a limited edition tour tshirt, a funny recorded voicemail message for your phone & a guest co-host spot on my podcast - Red Man Laughing.

$5000 Sponsorship or the JUST REAL FUGGIN' GOOD, YOU LEVEL: For donating at this level you'll get 20 tickets to the tour show in your city, passes to a post show meet & greet, a high five & an ol' fashioned NDN head nod, a signed limited edition tour poster, a limited edition tour tshirt, a funny recorded voicemail message for your phone, a guest co-host spot on my podcast - Red Man Laughing & we'll shoot a sketch comedy vid'yo for you to star in.

$15000 Sponsorship or the STOLE THIS FROM A WHITE GUY LEVEL: For donating at this level you'll get 40 tickets to the tour show in your city, passes to a post show meet & greet, a high five & an ol' fashioned NDN head nod, a signed limited edition tour poster, a limited edition tour tshirt, a funny recorded voicemail message for your phone, a guest co-host spot on my podcast - Red Man Laughing, we'll shoot a sketch comedy vid'yo for you to star in AND we'll throw a live comedy show in your community AND we'll host a Youth Workshop/Speaking Engagement in your community!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Share this campaign on your Facebook and Twitter pages!
  • Share the tour website on your Facebook and Twitter pages!
