story:
HELP GENIUS FOR MEN TO RAISE MONEY TO VIDEOTAPE OUR ANNUAL PRODUCTION.

GFM Honors fosters community between men and women, celebrates male high achievement, and men who transcend professional barriers.

What is Genius for Men?

Genius For Men brings honor and innovation to DC through a men’s empowerment forum that fosters community between men and women, celebrates male achievement, and honors men who seek to transcend the limits within their professions. GFM honors was started by two sisters who would like to showcase the ways in which men meet the mark in our communities. The Genius for Men Honors is a full production in which we recognize men who are meeting the mark in our communities. Genius for Men is unique in that men and women attend and facilitate the entire event.  We tell their stories through tributes that feature emerging performing and visual artists. 

Genius for Men is pleased to announce 2012 Honorees: Boys and Girls Club of Greater DC, Maestro Darin Atwater of Soulful Symphony, Impact Your World, Activist and Journalist Jeff Johnson, Rev. Otis Moss III, of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago, IL, Byron Nichols of BNFit Personal Fitness, Designers Bruce and Glen Proctor of BruceGlen, and Educator and Arts Activist Lamman Rucker of Black Gents of Hollywood.

With the 2012 theme of social justice and direct action, Genius For Men Honors (GFM) will take place at THEARC, Washington, DC on October 13, 2012 from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. This program is birthed out of the philosophy that a stronger community is partly dependent on the growth and success of our boys and men. We hold this event at THEARCDC.org to join in their efforts to bring quality performing arts and uplift to southeast DC. We have been recognized by entities such as Washington, DC's WKYS FM and the Lady Diva Corporation for our efforts over the last four years.

Why was Genius for Men Started? Check out this interview video click here.

From the Founder:

Dear Contributors,

Genius for Men is a project near and dear to my heart because I became frustrated about the narratives that say that black women are overly educated and that black men are overly incarcerated. I was tired of media coverage on men that praised their physical attributes but not their thoughtfulness and conscious inclusion of us in their work. I KNOW AMAZING BROTHERS WHO HAVE HELD MY SISTERS AND I DOWN. This is my way of modeling the sort of hospitality, research, and curiosity that we desire from men. Each year I receive emails and letters from men and women who confess that they began to see each other differently, after this event. Though I may be a graduate student, with student resources, I submit this work as a prayer for the fathers, brothers, sons and friends who should have positive models of men who know how to be there for, with, and beside us.

Thank you all for your kind consideration and contributions. Together we can do anything!

Alisha Lola Jones, Founder

INTENTION

This GFM fundraising campaign will help us to make sure that we can record the production. We have received invitations from agencies to offer this recording to public schools, athletic programs, rites of passage programs, fatherhood initiatives, and youth empowerment programs. GFM will be an opportunity for people between ages 11 – 18 to gain information on succeeding in fields such as the music industry, law, hard sciences, and business. Your donations will go to the set design, space for the tech rehearsals of the artists, videography and DVD processing, technical needs for our 12 - piece band, artists, instrument rental, and we would like to compensate the personnel that make this event happen.

Should we be unable to reach our goal of $10,000, we would like for contributions to go toward the recording of the amazing show that we are crafting.

 

Past Honoress

Past honorees have included neurosurgeon Dr. Ben Carson, Edgar Brookins of Afro-American newspaper, composer Richard Smallwood, motivational speaker Willy Jolley, A. B. Spellman, music critic, poet, and former administrator of the National Endowment of the Arts, jazz and classical musician Tony Walker who is the music director for Ledisi, Chick-Fil-A, businessman and philanthropist Michael Melton, Congressman John Lewis, VP and Editor-at-Large of Black Enterprise, Alfred Edmond, The Institute for Responsible Citizenship, Rev. Tony Lee of Community of Hope AME and CBS Radio Personality, photographer Bill Lee,  the 100 Black Men of Greater Washington, DC, Daniel Moore of the Mo’nique Show, Brandon Camphor and One Way, Mentoring Male Teens in the Hood, Elder Jimmy Grant, and Good Ground Good Life. 

TARGET GROUPS

The men participating at GFM as facilitators, panelists and/or honorees are people who see the urgent need  to inspire and empower other young men. The women who are spearheading the conference’s development share that urgency. We would appreciate your help in making sure the Genius For Men Conference provides the best resources to our attendees.

We are looking to raise $10,000 to make sure that we can pass on the synergy that is cultivated at the GFM Honors production to deserving youths!
story_txt:
HELP GENIUS FOR MEN TO RAISE MONEY TO VIDEOTAPE OUR ANNUAL PRODUCTION.GFM Honors fosters community between men and women, celebrates male high achievement, and men who transcend professional barriers.
What is Genius for Men?
Genius For Men brings honor and innovation to DC through a men’s empowerment forum that fosters community between men and women, celebrates male achievement, and honors men who seek to transcend the limits within their professions. GFM honors was started by two sisters who would like to showcase the ways in which men meet the mark in our communities. The Genius for Men Honors is a full production in which we recognize men who are meeting the mark in our communities. Genius for Men is unique in that men and women attend and facilitate the entire event.  We tell their stories through tributes that feature emerging performing and visual artists. 
Genius for Men is pleased to announce 2012 Honorees: Boys and Girls Club of Greater DC, Maestro Darin Atwater of Soulful Symphony, Impact Your World, Activist and Journalist Jeff Johnson, Rev. Otis Moss III, of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago, IL, Byron Nichols of BNFit Personal Fitness, Designers Bruce and Glen Proctor of BruceGlen, and Educator and Arts Activist Lamman Rucker of Black Gents of Hollywood.
With the 2012 theme of social justice and direct action, Genius For Men Honors (GFM) will take place at THEARC, Washington, DC on October 13, 2012 from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. This program is birthed out of the philosophy that a stronger community is partly dependent on the growth and success of our boys and men. We hold this event at THEARCDC.org to join in their efforts to bring quality performing arts and uplift to southeast DC. We have been recognized by entities such as Washington, DC's WKYS FM and the Lady Diva Corporation for our efforts over the last four years.
Why was Genius for Men Started? Check out this interview video click here.
From the Founder:
Dear Contributors,
Genius for Men is a project near and dear to my heart because I became frustrated about the narratives that say that black women are overly educated and that black men are overly incarcerated. I was tired of media coverage on men that praised their physical attributes but not their thoughtfulness and conscious inclusion of us in their work. I KNOW AMAZING BROTHERS WHO HAVE HELD MY SISTERS AND I DOWN. This is my way of modeling the sort of hospitality, research, and curiosity that we desire from men. Each year I receive emails and letters from men and women who confess that they began to see each other differently, after this event. Though I may be a graduate student, with student resources, I submit this work as a prayer for the fathers, brothers, sons and friends who should have positive models of men who know how to be there for, with, and beside us.

Thank you all for your kind consideration and contributions. Together we can do anything!Alisha Lola Jones, Founder

INTENTION
This GFM fundraising campaign will help us to make sure that we can record the production. We have received invitations from agencies to offer this recording to public schools, athletic programs, rites of passage programs, fatherhood initiatives, and youth empowerment programs. GFM will be an opportunity for people between ages 11 – 18 to gain information on succeeding in fields such as the music industry, law, hard sciences, and business. Your donations will go to the set design, space for the tech rehearsals of the artists, videography and DVD processing, technical needs for our 12 - piece band, artists, instrument rental, and we would like to compensate the personnel that make this event happen.
Should we be unable to reach our goal of $10,000, we would like for contributions to go toward the recording of the amazing show that we are crafting.
 
Past Honoress
Past honorees have included neurosurgeon Dr. Ben Carson, Edgar Brookins of Afro-American newspaper, composer Richard Smallwood, motivational speaker Willy Jolley, A. B. Spellman, music critic, poet, and former administrator of the National Endowment of the Arts, jazz and classical musician Tony Walker who is the music director for Ledisi, Chick-Fil-A, businessman and philanthropist Michael Melton, Congressman John Lewis, VP and Editor-at-Large of Black Enterprise, Alfred Edmond, The Institute for Responsible Citizenship, Rev. Tony Lee of Community of Hope AME and CBS Radio Personality, photographer Bill Lee,  the 100 Black Men of Greater Washington, DC, Daniel Moore of the Mo’nique Show, Brandon Camphor and One Way, Mentoring Male Teens in the Hood, Elder Jimmy Grant, and Good Ground Good Life. 
TARGET GROUPS
The men participating at GFM as facilitators, panelists and/or honorees are people who see the urgent need  to inspire and empower other young men. The women who are spearheading the conference’s development share that urgency. We would appreciate your help in making sure the Genius For Men Conference provides the best resources to our attendees.
We are looking to raise $10,000 to make sure that we can pass on the synergy that is cultivated at the GFM Honors production to deserving youths!

story:
Red Snow 红雪

Play Synopsis:
Inspired by the stories of survivors of the Rape of Nanking, the production marks the 75th anniversary of this forgotten holocaust of WWII. RED SNOW is a story of love and the struggle to reconcile the past with the present in the search for peace and healing.  Isabel’s recurring nightmare of her grandparents’ favorite Chinese opera drives her to search for their silenced story. On her journey she falls in love with Jason, a man who is connected to the same forgotten holocaust. Their love unleashes three generations of guilt and pain perpetuated by a massacre still denied by the perpetrators today. When their lives collide they struggle to reconcile the past with the present - for themselves and their families, shaken from their lifelong silence by Isabel’s pilgrimage to uncover the secrets of her grandmother’s history ... and her own.

Red Snow是一个关于爱情的故事，同时也是一个在过去与现在之间挣扎调和，以追寻平复与疗伤的故事。伊莎贝尔的祖父母最爱的京剧剧情不断出现在她的梦魇中，驱使她踏上去寻找他们那些沉默的故事的旅程。旅途中，她与杰森堕入情网。而把杰森和她联系在一起的却是同样的那一场被遗忘的大屠杀。

Support our Canadian production of Red Snow in Shanghai, China:

Be part of the collective of individuals pooling together resources around the world in supporting this important and beautiful story on an international stage, a story honoring the survivors and victims of the Rape of Nanking, on its 75th year of remembrance.

 

We are very grateful to the Canada Council for the Arts and TAPA for their support, which will cover some of the travel expenses for the crew and cast to go to Shanghai for Red Snow's international premiere.

Even with this generous support in travel expenses, we still need your help to raise funds for the rest of the production's budget.

Every dollar you can offer, and every friend with whom you can share this, will bring us closer on our journey.

Thank you for your generosity and time and for being part of this important story.

For your support we are offering unique and beautiful gifts from artwork of our Canadian production to an unforgettable experience in Shanghai & Nanjing with our artists.

You may support our project by making a donation on this website.

请支持加拿大制作Red Snow在中国上海的演出：
 
请加入我们的行列，在全世界范围内共同筹集资金来支持这个在南京大屠杀75周年祭之际，纪念幸存者和受难者的故事，让这个极具价值而又美丽动人的故事呈现在国际舞台。
 
对于您的慷慨支持，我们将给予您从独特而精美的加拿大制作插图艺术品，到现场上海南京观看演出并和演员见面等的回馈。

您可以直接在此网站捐款来支持我们的项目。

Red Snow had its world premiere at the Theatre Passe Muraille in Toronto, Canada, in January 2012.  We are the only Canadian theatre company (among the ten countries  chosen for 2012 festival) to be invited to the ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival in November. This will be our international premiere, opening up opportunities for our thirteen artists and crew in a forum of artistic and cultural exchange.  The ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival was founded in Japan in 1999, to showcase theatre productions from across Asia.  Since relocating to Shanghai, China, in 2005, the theatre festival's showcase has expanded internationally, to include Europe, the United Kingdom, the Middle East, Canada, and the United States.  Shanghai is one of the major Asian cities for culture and the arts, drawing artists and audiences from around the world.  Red Snow's international premiere presentation is especially important and poignant for both the production and the local Chinese audience, for the presentation of Red Show in China will commemorate the massacre and the horrors and the injustice committed in Nanjing in 1937.

Our contacts we will be making at the ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival we give us opportunities in new collaborations and other presentation of Red Snow in other countries and other arts and theatre festivals.

我们是这次11月间举行的ACT上海国际当代戏剧节上唯一获邀演出的加拿大戏剧演出团体（2012年戏剧节共邀请的十个国家之一）。这也将是我们的国际首演，为我们的13位艺术家和团队打开艺术和文化交流的大门。

As the ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival will be covering only the accommodation and one meal per day for twelve production participants for four days during the Festival, we will need additional funds (up to $48,888) to cover the additional expenses for bringing the crew and cast of thirteen from Toronto to Shanghai, and for the crew and cast salaries, and for covering the meals and per diem expenses that are not covered by the Festival:

Return economy class airfares between Toronto and Shanghai for thirteen cast and crew members $15,600
Crew & cast salaries for one week rehearsal in Canada & one week in Shanghai $18,500
Rehearsal space rental $433
Per diem honoraria ($125/day/person abroad) $11,375
Taxi van of crew/cast/costumes/props in Toronto to airport and return $420
Extra baggage fees for transporting props and costumes $1,000
Travel insurance for thirteen crew and cast members ($60/person) $780
China visa fees ($50/person) $650
Rental of instruments in Shanghai (vibraphone/Chinese drum/African djembe)$130
Total expenses for Red Snow's participation at the ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival: $48,888

由于戏剧节只负责12个制作成员的当地4天的住宿和每日一餐的费用，我们仍需额外筹集4万8千8百8十8美元的资金，来支持排练场地费，全体13名演员和团队多伦多和上海之间的差旅费，还有演员和团队的薪水以及主办方不能负责的餐费和每日津贴。
 
13位演员和团队的多伦多和上海来回经济舱机票：$15,600
演员和团队成员的加拿大一周排练和上海一周排练的薪水：$18,500
排练场地租金：$433
象征性每日津贴（$125每日/每人海外）：$11,375
多伦多机场来回面包车租金：$420
机运道具和服装额外行李费: $1,000
13位演员和团队旅行保险（$60/每人）:$780
中国签证费（$50/每人）:$650
上海当地乐器租用费（电颤琴/中国鼓/非洲鼓）:$130

红雪参加ACT上海国际当代戏剧节费用总计： $48,888

The crew and cast of Red Snow will be most grateful for your support in our efforts to present Red Snow to the Chinese audiences, who with their shared history of this massacre and violence will no doubt be affected by the production's message of peace, healing and forgiveness.  Please join us in supporting the presentation and the international dissemination of Red Snow.  It takes a community to raise and to tell a story.

Red Snow (红雪)全体演员和团队对于您的不吝支持令我们能够将此剧献给中国观众不胜感激。毫无疑问，同样熟悉这段暴虐大屠杀历史的观众，定会被剧中的和平，疗伤和谅解的主题所打动。

筹款和讲述这个故事需要全社区的共同努力。多谢!

Who is Red Snow Collective:

Red Snow is produced by the Red Snow Collective (www.redsnowcollective.ca) - a team of talented artists of diversity both in art forms and cultures, to work together to bring new and transformative creations that enrich the Canadian and international stages.

1. To create theatre that is poetic and lyrical, using a mosaic of theatrical forms from eastern and western cultures’ storytelling that provokes, engages, crosses borders and challenges the norm.

2. To create compelling and socially relevant theatre that transforms a personal story, history and mythology into one that reflects universal stories.

3. To create theatre that incorporates movement and live musicians, following traditional theatre forms of drama and storytelling.

4. To create theatre that brings cultural and historical awareness.

5. To build bridges and dialogue between communities through art and theatre, both locally and internationally.

6. To outreach to students and teachers through artists in education workshops on empowering their voices and stories through theatre and after show talks about the art for change with the artists.

For photos and biographies of Red Snow actors & artists: www.redsnowcollective.ca

What reviews say about Red Snow?  …. FROM THE CANADIAN MEDIA...

"An astonishing, almost unbelievable work ... Red Snow is groundbreaking and brave. It is a stunning success. Go see it." ~ Mooney On Theatre

"A graceful, moving production ... both the poetic script and the impressive production are full of heart" ~ NOW Magazine

"Pleasingly lyrical...Director Beatriz Pizano's staging is lovely and delicate...The production, as much as the play, is a rebuke to brutality." ~ The GRID

"Red Snow provokes, fascinates ... Red Snow is the type of theatre we need more of in Toronto." ~ Charlebois Post

Perks conditions:

Gold Phoenix:                  

Bronze Phoenix gift plus ONE (1) RETURN ECONOMY CLASS PLANE TICKET between Shanghai and North America, Europe, Asia, Australia or New Zealand (choice of airline to be determined by the Producer; taxes, travel insurance, fuel surcharges, excess baggage charges, advance seat selection fees, airport transfers, and visa fees are not included) to attend the performance of Red Snow at the ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival; plus a PRODUCER-ACCOMPANIED REMEMBRANCE DAY-TRIP FROM SHANGHAI TO NANJING MEMORIAL AND SWALLOWS CLIFF IN NANJING, CHINA (meals not included; return car/rail transportation between Shanghai and Nanjing included; choice of land transportation between Shanghai and Nanjing to be determined by the Producer).

Jade Phoenix:     

Silver Phoenix gift plus TWO (2) RETURN ECONOMY CLASS PLANE TICKETS between Shanghai and North America, Europe, Asia, Australia or New Zealand (choice of airline to be determined by the Producer; taxes, travel insurance, fuel surcharges, excess baggage charges, advance seat selection fees, airport transfers, and visa fees are not included) to attend the presentation of Red Snow at the ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival; plus a PRODUCER-ACCOMPANIED REMEMBRANCE DAY-TRIP FROM SHANGHAI TO NANJING MEMORIAL AND SWALLOWS CLIFF IN NANJING, CHINA (meals not included; return car/rail transportation between Shanghai and Nanjing included, choice of land transportation between Shanghai and Nanjing to be determined by the Producer); plus ONE (1) EXECUTIVE PRODUCER CREDIT on the production of Red Snow to be presented at the ACT Shanghai International Contemporary Theatre Festival.

story:
I am a musical theatre major at Wright State University.  WSU is one of the top theatre schools in the country, and has a theatre dedicated solely to student-run shows.  I've written my first ever original musical, which will be performed in this theatre in April.  This is incredibly exciting for me, and we have an amazing cast and crew lined up and getting ready to open!
Although we have the use of this space, we don't have any access to funding.  We need funds for things like the band, the sets, the costumes, and the props.  The more help we get, the easier it will be for us to make this show look as amazing as it can possibly be!
This show is also very important because all of our proceeds from the actual performances, like the suggested entry fee (since there are no tickets), will be donated to Save the Chimps, an organization dedicated to rescuing chimpanzees.  The better our production is and the more people who come to see it, the more money we will be able to raise to benefit these amazing animals.
So even if you can't donate now, please spread the word so that people can help us put on the best show we can!  Everyone who donates at least $5 will be listed in the special thanks in our program.

story:
Hello!

Thank you for taking the time to visit our crowdfunding page.

You're probably here because your payment failed on our main Ideastap crowdfunding page! But have no fear, as we've set up this alternative page where it should be much easier for you to pledge. (Original page can be found at: http://www.ideastap.com/crowdfunding/project/christmas-storms-and-sunshine)

If you still have issues pledging on this page, please contact Jane at jane.crawshaw@hotmail.co.uk, and we'll be able to find you an alternative way to help!


For everyone else, let me tell you a bit about who we are!

We are Jane Crawshaw, Kim Scopes, Jon McLeod and Mary Beth Morossa, and we make up the team behind "Christmas Storms and Sunshine", a Gothic Christmas tale for adults based on a short story by Elizabeth Gaskell. 

We are scheduled to perform at the White Bear Theatre from 22nd December 2014 - 2nd January 2015, but we need YOUR help to make it happen! 

We are extremely grateful for any amount you can spare to help us out, even a couple of pounds can make a huge difference! It's not all one-sided though, we've put together some great rewards to say thank you for your generosity.

We're really excited about this project, and we hope you will be too! So grab a cuppa, make yourself at home and follow us on a journey into Victorian London...

THE PLOT 

“In the town of (no matter where) there circulated two local newspapers (no matter when).“

Jenkins works for the Flying Post (aka bigoted and Tory), and Hodgson works for the Examiner (aka new-fangled and Liberal). They lodge in the same house. So Christmas should be fun… Quarrels, snobbery and hilarity ensue, but can they forgive and forget in time to save Christmas, and who’s eaten all the [mince] pies?

TRAUM gives a new twist to Elizabeth Gaskell’s classic Gothic tale of Christmas rivalries. Told with beautiful puppetry, live original music and bold physical storytelling, Christmas Storms and Sunshine is a seasonal extravaganza like no other.

WHY "CHRISTMAS STORMS AND SUNSHINE"?

We love Christmas shows. The magic, the joy, the oodles of fake snow. But how many Christmas shows are just for adults? As much as we admire really high-quality children's theatre, there are just not enough Christmas shows for grown-ups. The same goes for puppetry, which is all too often consigned to kids' shows in the UK.

This project also provides opportunities for female artists, and showcases some excellent classical female writing. We are committed to bridging the gender divide in theatre. As Lyn Gardner recently stated, "British theatre offers far fewer opportunities for women than men." 

We also really want the show to feel at home in Lambeth's White Bear Theatre, so we're meeting with local residents of all ages to hear their memories of the area, which we will feed into the fabric of the script and the show’s design to create a truly bespoke Christmas experience for Lambeth.

WHAT'S THE PLAN NOW?

November

Over the next month we'll be visiting local community centres, libraries and literary groups to hear residents memories of Lambeth.

This month we will also begin our marketing campaign, by designing our show artwork, and printing flyers and posters. 

R&D

Following on from workshops with local residents, we will be workshopping the play in a Research and Development Week, so that we have a fully formed script and lots of great ideas ready for the start of rehearsals.

Rehearsals 

We're rehearsing the play for three weeks, starting at the beginning of December. We've got a great rehearsal space booked at Theatre Delicatessen, and we'll be rehearsing 8 hours a day, 5 days a week, to whip the play into shape!

Performances

After over 200 hours of blood, sweat and (hopefully not too many) tears, we'll be performing the show for seven nights at the White Bear Theatre from the 22nd December 2014 to the 2nd January 2015 (excl. 24th-27th and 31st December). We'll also be inviting lots of industry professionals and other London theatres along, with the hope of securing a longer run for the show in December 2015.

WHERE IS MY MONEY GOING?

We've already raised £3,000 from private donors towards the cost of this production, which is fantastic news!

£2,000 of this will go on:

Props

Set

Puppets

Rehearsal space hire

Marketing materials (printing posters and flyers, hiring photographers and buying advertisement space online)

Transporting equipment to the rehearsal space and theatre

The remaining £1,000 will go towards paying our cast and creative team.

We fervently believe that all artists deserve to be paid.

The artists that we have attached to this project are of an extremely high calibre, and are award-winning in their fields. Our dream goal for this project is to be able to pay all our artists the London Living Wage (£8.80 per hour).

This is no mean feat. To pay six artists the London Living Wage for 3 weeks rehearsals and 7 performances will cost £9,294.

We are aiming to cover this with an Arts Council Grant and the money raised from Accelerator.

If we don't receive the Arts Council Grant, then Accelerator becomes even more important.

Combined with the £1,000 we've already raised, plus the £3,000 from the Accelerator campaign, we will have a total of £4,000 to pay our creative team. We will also divide the profits from the performances between our artists to increase that fee.

This is not our ideal situation, but it is a step up from only paying expenses or profit share, which is all most Fringe productions are able to afford. Being able to pay our artists a guaranteed fee for this production will also help with funding applications in the future, and allow us to pay our artists a larger fee for the next show.

WHO WE ARE

Jane Crawshaw is Artistic Director of TRAUM. She also works as an actor, physical theatre performer, devisor, dancer, puppeteer and actor-musician.

Previous credits include work for Tangled Feet, Yellow Earth Theatre and Out of Chaos, Old Saw at Little Angel Theatre, Angel Exit Theatre, Zest Theatre, Culture Works East, Latitude Festival, the National Theatre's "Watch This Space" Festival and Emergency Exit Arts.

For TRAUM, Jane created the performance installation "Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes" for Culture Works East and Ideastap at Latitude Festival this year.

@JaneCrawshaw

Jon McLeod is a theatre sound designer and composer, specialising in devised, site-specific and headphone work.

His credits include “Spine” (Soho Theatre), “Borderline Vultures” (The Lowry), “66 Minutes in Damascus” (LIFT Festvial) and “The Invisible Show” (RedShift Theatre).

Jon worked for the National Theatre as associate sound designer on “Damned By Despair”, and his play “Organs of Little Apparent Importance” was produced for HighTide Festival.

@_jonmac_

Mary Beth Morossa is an award winning performer and cabaret artiste who specialises in gothic performance.

Mary won the Best Actress Award at the Dark Chat Awards and was shortlisted for the Les Enfants Terrible Award in 2012.

She is also creative producer at Third Mind Productions and has performed for Tate Britain, Louis Vuitton and Latitude Festival.

@MaryBethMorossa

Kim Scopes is an Actress and Puppeteer living in London.

Previously Kim has performed Shakespeare at the New Wolsey, Ipswich, appeared in a Special K commercial and toured extensively for Blunderbus Theatre, whom she has also directed for.

Most recently Kim has assistant puppeteered on Series 2 of CBBC'S Strange Hill High. She also puppeteers frequently for Flabbergast Theatre "who present for your viewing pleasure 'Boris & Sergey' in their myriad adventures" and Twice Shy Theatre.

This year Kim has also performed at Glastonbury and taught puppetry in Peru. 

She is thrilled to be part of this project. 

@Kim_Scopes 

Thank you so much again for visiting our page! Please remember, if we don't hit our £3,000 target then we won't receive anything. We are truly grateful for every penny pledged.

You can follow our progress via our twitter account @TraumTheatre, and please spread the word to family, friends and on social media!

Best wishes,

Jane, Kim, Jon and Mary x

story:
Moonshiner: A Musical Fabulism

The beginning.

A few years ago I reconnected with an old friend, Jason, during the production of a musical (I was music directing, he was playing in the pit). We took a break one afternoon to get a mani/pedi, bro-style.  As we whiled away our time in the spa I started bemoaning the fact that current pop culture was dominated by really serious vampires and werewolves. I told Jason that I liked "Teen Wolf" and that kind of tongue-in-cheek treatment of the the supernatural and undead. Jason casually suggested I write a show, so I did!

The end result is this piece, "Moonshiner." A supernatural spoof of classic film noir, with jazz, rock-a-billy, doo-wop, and a couple of musical surprises; a delightfully silly one-act musical; and a mythical fable about the origin of rock'n'roll!

Why we're here.

Some time after that spa afternoon, I became the artistic director of the Zeiders American Dream Theater. I created a series called "The Hatchery" that focusses on developing new theatrical works as part of our broader mission, and I plugged what I'd started calling "Moonshiner" into the calendar. We produced a reading of the show in 2015, and then did a full workshop in 2017. I submitted the show to a few places, and the Chicago Musical Theatre Festival selected it!

Here's the challenge: we- The Z- need to raise some money to produce this show at the festival. Or, as Pete Rock of "Moonshiner" might say- "We need some dough, daddy-o!"

What we're doing.

We're going to produce "Moonshiner" in full at CMTF. This doesn't mean just the actors and musicians- it also means costumes, props, projections, and all the other theater stuff. And marketing- tons of marketing. We're doing this because we believe that this show is a hit- it's family-friendly, engaging, twisty & turny. It's got story the way hurricanes have wind- from all directions. And it's all packaged in one act, about as long as a typical film noir from the 50's.

How you can help.

Quite simply, donate to the project! The Z is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization, so your contribution is tax-deductible!* Every little bit helps, from $20 to $2,000. It all ads up to helping us get this show on the road!

*Unfortunately, the value of the perks you may get isn't tax-deductible, so unless you forego those perks your total tax advantage may be a bit less than what you give. The perks are worth it, though!

Not-so-little things you can do.

If you can't contribute right now, here are some other things you can do:

  • Buy tickets to Moonshiner at CMTF! Click here for tickets.
  • Share this campaign- Indiegogo has easy built in sharing tools!
  • Follow Moonshiner on Facebook and share our posts!

story:
For over 30 years--through workshops, retreats, classes and productions--we at Artistic New Directions have developed new theatre pieces. We have a special interest in the intersection of improvisational and scripted theatre. Without-a-Net is one intersection.

For a Without-a-Net production, we give an original five-character play to five directors who, in turn, each cast five different actors. The play is rehearsed separately by each director and cast. Then, over two weeks, we present 25 performances of this one play with a different cast for every performance. At each performance, one actor is called from each of the five companies. The five actors encounter each other for the first time when they meet on stage. While they all have prepared their own characters (they have memorized their lines and understand the relationships to the other characters as written), they encounter the other characters as played anew every time the lights come up. They fly without a net in a performance requiring complete trust. The lines may be set but in all other respects the show is improvised, with discoveries surprising those on either side of the lights.

This production concept was introduced to us by Gary Garrison and Roland Tec when they offered their play The Rubber Room to be produced in this manner. A thought-provoking piece about New York City’s practice of moth-balling public school teachers with disciplinary issues for years at full pay, the show appealed to the theatrical community because of its daring and the educational community because of its provocative subject matter. Two years later, we offered Kristine Niven’s Human Resources, a bittersweet look at white collar workers in a shrinking employment market.

Café Pen is our third outing in this series. Set in a small town with an economy based on the local federal penitentiary, the script explores a community of characters who live outside the prison walls but whose lives are linked to those serving on the inside. The script has been developed through another of Artistic New Directions’ programs, the annual Summer Salt Playprov Retreat, where the playwright researched the characters and their encounters through a series of guided improvisations. The script continued to be developed through AND-sponsored readings and workshops. Its presentation as a Without-a-Net project is a fulfillment of the company’s mission to generate, revise, and polish a piece till it’s ready for a public audience.

Without-a-Net is a huge project for our little company. With 25 actors, five directors, five stage managers, plus the talents of set, lighting and costuming designers, our budget needs help. The complete budget is below. We are hoping to raise $10,000 towards it. Box office receipts are projected to bring in $5000-6000 (tickets are priced between $10 and $18, and as an Equity production, we are required to comp Equity actors and industry people, e.g. casting directors, agents, producers, directors). The balance will come from a recent benefit and our general funds. The company is determined to present this project. Your support will help move intention to realization.

Budget - Without-a-Net: Café Pen

Facility Rental

Rehearsal $4800

Theatre $4400

Auditions $ 250

Production Mtngs $ 100

Design Fees

Sets $ 100

Lighting $ 100

Costume $ 100

Sound $ 100

Graphics $ 100

Production Fees

Prod Stage Mgr $ 100

Asst PSM $ 100

3 Stage Managers $ 100

25 Actors $2500

5 Directors $ 500

Playwright $ 100

Box Office Mgr $ 100

Production Expenses

Sets $1500

Lighting $ 400

Costumes $ 200

Props $ 400

Insurance $ 185

Credit Card Fees $ 100

Postcards/Posters $ 350

Programs $ 500

Marketing/PR $3000

Copying $ 200

Closing Night $ 700

Trucking $ 300

4 Load In/Out Crew $ 400

TOTAL BUDGET $22,085

story:
Un paso adelante por DESTINO! - A step forward for DESTINO!

1. ¿Quiénes somos y qué es DESTINO? Somos Junaid Jemal Sendi y Addisu Demissie, de Etiopía. Hemos creado DESTINO Dance Company, la única compañía de danza contemporánea de nuestro país, para apoyar a la comunidad a través de la danza y, entre otras actividades, poder dar a 12 niños de la calle la misma oportunidad que tuvimos nosotros hace 18 años. Queremos ofrecerles un programa de formación completa en educación artística durante tres años. Sabemos que la danza, además de ser un lenguaje internacional, puede cambiar tu vida. A nosotros nos permitió creer en nosotros mismos y poder crear nuestro destino. Who are we and what is DESTINO? We are Junaid Jemal Sendi and Addisu Demissie, from Ethiopia. We have created DESTINO Dance Company, the only Contemporary Dance Company in our country to support the community through dance and, among the main activities, to provide 12 street children with the same opportunity we were given 18 years ago. We want to equip them with a complete arts education training for three years. We know that dance, besides being an international language, can change your life. Dance allowed us to believe in ourselves and create our own destiny.

2. ¿Por qué queremos ir a Europa? Vamos de tour a Europa para encontrar colaboradores y financiadores que permitan a la siguiente generación tener la misma oportunidad que tuvimos nosotros. Queremos contar nuestra historia en persona. Este tour nos permitirá explicar las actividades que llevamos acabo con la comunidad, con personas con discapacidad física, con jóvenes en centros de detención, y enfermos de SIDA en Addis Abeba. Este viaje también nos apoyará en nuestro trabajo porque conectaremos con otras personas que  quieren conseguir lo mismo y ser parte de este sueño. Compartir nuestra motivación y visión con el resto del mundo nos ayudará a enfrentar los retos. Why do we want to go to Europe? We are going on a tour to Europe to find supporters and funders to enable the next generation to have the opportunity we had. We want to tell our story in person and raise funds for our dance school project. This tour will enable us to explain all the activities we carry out with the community, disabled people, young offenders, and people affected by HIV in Addis Ababa. This trip will also help us do our work because we will connect with other people who want to do the same and be part of this dream. To share our motivation and vision with the rest of the world will help us to face the challenges.

3. ¿Qué haremos en España, Gales e Inglaterra? Daremos clases y actuaremos en distintos escenarios. En España estaremos acompañados de tres bailarines con discapacidad física: Morka, Mondo y Yitsegaw y representaremos la pieza Tilla, que competirá en el Festival 10 Sentidos en Valencia, y actuaremos en otros teatros en Madrid y Cardiff. Puedes consultar todas las fechas en www.facebook.com/destinodance What will we do in Spain, Wales and England? We will be teaching and performing in different venues. In Spain, we will be accompanied by three disabled dancers: Morka, Mondo and Yitsegaw, to perform “Tilla” in 10 Sentidos’ Dance Competition in Valencia, as well as in other theatres in Madrid and Cardiff. All dates are posted on www.facebook.com/destinodance

4. ¿Por qué ayudarnos? Apoyándonos en este viaje a Europa no sólo estarás ayudando a nuestra compañía y al patrimonio cultural de la danza etíope a darse a conocer internacionalmente, sino también a decenas de jóvenes etíopes de entornos marginales que se benefician de nuestros programas gratuitos en Addis Abeba. Este proyecto también consiste en crear esperanza y mostrar cómo la danza puede provocar cambios positivos en nuestra sociedad. Why support us? By supporting us, you will not only help our company and Ethiopia’s strong traditional dance heritage to become better abroad, but you will also be helping dozens of young underprivileged Ethiopians to benefit from our free dance programmes in Addis Ababa. Our project is about hope and shows how change can be brought about positively through dance. 

5. ¿Qué haremos con la recaudación? Tu donación para esta campaña nos ayudará a cubrir los gastos del tour como alojamiento, transporte y comida de estos tres meses en España y Reino Unido, así como parte del programa de formación de 3 años y las actividades de DESTINO en Addis Abeba que ya están en marcha. What will we do with your donation? Your donation to this campaign will help cover the costs of the tour such as accommodation, transport and food during the month in Spain, Wales and England, as well as part of the 3 year programme and all running DESTINO activities in Addis Ababa.

6. ¿Qué puedes hacer tú?

Puedes ayudarnos de muchas formas: haciendo una donación, viniendo a una clase o asistiendo a un espectáculo, facilitándonos un contacto interesante, haciendo fotos en un espectáculo, organizando un evento para captar fondos, vendiendo entradas, pasando esta campaña a contactos y amigos… Si quiere más información sobre nosotros, puedes escribirnos a destinodance@gmail.com, seguro que encontramos formas de colaboración! What can you do? You can support us in many different ways: by making a donation, coming to a dance class or attending one of the shows, providing us with a relevant contact, taking pictures in a show, organizing a fundraising event, selling tickets, sharing this campaign with friends and contacts... For more information about us, you can also email us at destinodance@gmail.com - we will find ways to collaborate!

Somos el futuro de Etiopía. Y estamos comprometidos a cambiar las cosas y lo conseguiremos. Ven a vernos, únete a las clases, se parte de este emocionante viaje, no te arrepentirás! Muchas gracias! We are the future of Ethiopia. And we are committed to change things and we will. Come to watch us, join us at the classes, be part of this exciting journey, you will not regret it! Thank you very much!

DESTINO!

creado DESTINO Dance Company, la única compañía de danza contemporánea de
nuestro país, para apoyar a la comunidad a través de la danza y, entre otras
actividades, poder dar a 12 niños de la calle la misma oportunidad que tuvimos
nosotros hace 18 años. Queremos ofrecerles un programa de formación completa en
educación artística durante tres años. Sabemos que la danza, además de ser un
lenguaje internacional, puede cambiar tu vida. A nosotros nos permitió creer en
nosotros mismos y poder crear nuestro destino. Who are we and what is DESTINO? We are Junaid Jemal Sendi
and Addisu Demissie, from Ethiopia. We have created DESTINO Dance Company, the only
Contemporary Dance Company in our country to support the community through dance and, among
the main activities, to provide 12 street children with the same opportunity we were given
18 years ago. We want to equip them with a complete arts education training for
three years. We know that dance, besides being an international language, can
change your life. Dance allowed us to believe in ourselves and create our own
destiny.

queremos ir a Europa? Vamos de tour a Europa
para encontrar colaboradores y financiadores que permitan a la siguiente

conectaremos con otras personas que 
quieren conseguir lo mismo y ser parte de este sueño. Compartir nuestra motivación y visión con el
resto del mundo nos ayudará a enfrentar los retos. Why do we want to go to Europe? We are going on a tour to Europe to
find supporters and funders to enable the next generation to have the
opportunity we had. We want to tell our story in
person and raise funds for our dance school project. This tour will enable us to explain all the activities we carry out with the community, disabled people, young offenders, and people affected
by HIV in Addis Ababa. This
trip will also help us do our work because we will connect with other people

story:
Summary

“Wilton’s Music Hall has atmosphere in spades... one of those spots habitually called a “hidden gem”. And it is.” The Times

Wilton’s Music Hall is supporting new and emerging artists, choreographers and dancers with Wilton’s Strike!, a three-day event taking place on 25th - 27th September 2014. Presenting a selection of styles and original concepts, this will be the perfect chance to witness the stars of tomorrow in an intimate setting.

A new platform for emerging dance talent, Wilton’s Strike! needs your support. Your support will give us much needed funds and equipment, including a new dance floor, to be able to fully assist in developing six new, original works. You will also be helping to ensure free admission to the performances for audiences and making it possible for us to stream the event live, making this new work even more accessible.




Who We Are

Wilton's is the world's oldest surviving Grand Music hall, a popular theatre, bar and historic attraction. Built over 150 years ago, it has been revived over the last decade to become a vibrant multi-disciplinary venue with a proven track record of supporting the arts. Recent programme highlights include a twice sold out immersive production of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby and the 2013 Southbank Sky Arts Award Winning Dracula dance-theatre piece, co-commissioned with Marc Bruce Company (pictured).

Wilton’s Music Hall offers a blend of culture, heritage and education and by supporting this project you are also supporting us. Our purpose is to bring together artists and audiences from diverse disciplines and cultures in our unique, historic venue. Our mission is to produce high profile, multi-disciplinary, distinct work that is accessible to a wide range of people. We are very grateful to the Arts Council England for seed funding this festival and we are now fundraising for the match funds.


The Performers

This is a grass roots project designed not only to platform new work but also to link Wilton’s with young and emerging dance artists for future collaborations. Six applicants from different dance backgrounds will be chosen and given three months to make a new piece of dance on the theme of metamorphosis.  Shortlisted candidates will receive a £1,500 fee to help develop their work to performance level, as well as rehearsal time here at Wilton’s.

The successful applicants will be selected by well-respected dancer Jonathan Goddard, as well as Wilton’s Artistic Team. Applications are now open and will close on 23rd June.  All donors will be kept up to date with progress and will be first to hear the announcement of the winners. 


What We Need & What You'll Get

We are looking for £2,500 to purchase a new dance floor and to be able to fully assist in developing six new, original works. This work will then be performed in September, giving the artists exposure to a new audience.

As a special thank you, we have some great perks to offer. From your name in a programme to a personalised postcard, and a signed poster to exclusive behind the scenes access, there are plenty of chances for you to see where your money has gone and to become more involved with Wilton’s.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are in the UK and visiting London then come along to Wilton’s for a History Tour and see the building. Please share this information and help us reach our target!

/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
Find out more at wiltons.org.uk.
Follow us on twitter, like us on facebook
or take a look at our gorgeous building on instagram.
/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

story:
English follows

Buongiorno a tutti,

il mio nome è Manolo Perazzi, sono un artista abruzzese e lavoro nell’ambito della danza contemporanea.

 

Ho presentato il mio lavoro, Crossover, all’interno del festival Oriente Occidente di Rovereto durante il mese di Settembre 2017. Ecco a voi una piccola presentazione:

 

“L’autore affida alla parola inglese crossover lo stato emotivo e fisico della sua danza. Questo lavoro cattura l’uomo sospeso tra il reale e l’immaginario, tra istinto e razionalità, impulsi e freni, guidato da un’energia che non si interrompe anche quando sembrerebbe accennare ad un’involuzione, ad un arresto. Si cerca un controllo al proprio flusso di azioni e pensieri.

 

L’idea del progetto nasce da alcune domande: come l’essere umano con il suo corpo può cambiare in relazione ai mutamenti dell’ambiente che lo circonda? Di che natura sono gli impulsi che esso riceve da un ambiente che sta mutando? Qual’è la reazione del corpo ad un mutamento, cosa percepisce e che tipo di trasformazione avviene all’interno? Nel lavoro, gli interpreti vengono collocati sempre in un nuovo ambiente, i loro corpi vengono plasmati in relazione ad esso e alla situazione che si viene a creare. L’uomo si perde, smarrito in un caos mentale che rispecchia la confusione dell’ambiente esterno: viene continuamente costretto al cambiamento.

 

Il lavoro, è stato pensato per tre persone: due danzatori e la musicista e regista del suono Flavia Massimo la quale, attraverso un violoncello, un synt e una loop station costruisce la partitura sonora; è lei a dettare le regole dello spettacolo e del movimento, lei a governare sui performer, è un elemento esterno al di sopra delle parti. Durante la prima residenza è nata quindi un’interazione che ha portato Flavia oltre che a comporre la musica originale dello spettacolo anche ad essere di fatto un interprete che si muove, abita e condivide la scena. È lei a scandire lo spettacolo delineando la costruzione di un percorso sonoro che interagisce con gli interpreti accompagnandoli e guidando la loro danza”.

 

Sono stato selezionato per una residenza artistica presso il Did Studio di Ariella Vidach e il progetto avra’ luogo nel mese di Gennaio 2018. Mi sono stati offerti 20 giorni di residenza.

 

Sto lanciando la mia campagna di crowdfunding per avere modo di reperire i fondi necessari per pagare gli artisti.

-              20 giornate lavorative per 3 artisti;

-              Viaggi di andata e ritorno;

-              Alloggio per 3;

-              un giorno di lavoro di un videomaker per la realizzazione di un video e di un promo professionale da poter inviare a festivals e teatri;

-              due giorni di lavoro per un light designer

 

Vi terro’ sempre aggiornati sulle varie fasi del lavoro, condividero’ foto e video e vi dedichero’ ogni singola performance! Spero davvero possiate darmi una mano affinche’ io possa realizzare il mio progetto fino in fondo!

 

Grazie mille,

 

Manolo

 

 

 

 

 

Hello everyone,

 

my name is Manolo Perazzi and I am contemporary dance artist from Abruzzo (Italy).

 

I presented my last work as a dancemaker, Crossover, at  Oriente Occidente Festival in Rovereto in September 2017. Here a short description of the dance project:

 

“The author recognises in the English word “crossover” the emotional and physical status of his own dancing. This work captures the man between real and imaginary, instinct and rationality, impulses and brakes, being led by an energy that does not interrupt itself no matter what the external circumstances are.

 

The idea of the project generates from some questions: how can the human being with his own body react in relation to the changes within the surrounding environment? What kind of impulses does a change generate? Performers are always placed in a new environment, their bodies are shaped accordingly to to new situation. Man is lost in a mental chaos that reflects the confusion of the external environment: he is forced to change, perpetually.

 

In the work, the two dancers interact with the musician and director of the sound Flavia Massimo, who, through a cello, a synt and a loop station, builds up a live sound score; she dictates the rules of the show and the movement, she takes control of the performers; she is an outside element beyond the parts. She gives shape to a soundtrack which leads the performers throughout their path”.

 

I have been selected for a 20-day residency period at Did Studio in Milan (Ariella Vidach/AIEP). The residency will take place during January 2018.

 

I am launching my own crowdfunding campaign in order to collect a budegt to cover:

 

- the salary for 3 people for 20 days;

-the travel expenses;

-the accommodation for 3 people for 20 days;

-two days with a light designer and a professional videomaker, in order to get all of the professional material (video, trailer, pictures and light design) ready to be sent to venues and festivals.

 

I will keep you updated and I will share pictures, videos, moments from the residency with all of you. Every single performance will be dedicated to you!

 

Thanks so much for your incredible help!

 

Love,

 

Manolo

story:
The Indo-American Arts Council is a registered 501(c)3 not-for-profit, secular service and resource arts organization charged with the mission of promoting and building the awareness, creation, production, exhibition, publication and performance of Indian and cross-cultural art forms in North America. We wholeheartedly support all artistic disciplines in classical, fusion, folk and innovative forms influenced by the arts of India. The IAAC is a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization. All donations are tax-deductible to the fullest extent allowable by law.

We work in close cooperation with colleagues around the United States to broaden our collective audiences and create a network for shared information, resources, funding and cultural exchange. Our focus is to help artists and art organizations in North America while facilitating artists from India to exhibit, perform and produce their work here. 


Erasing Borders is the Indo-American Arts Council's annual dance festival, bringing innovative artists and performers from across the Indian subcontinent to the USA. The aim of the IAAC in organizing Erasing Borders is to connect these two diverse countries through a cultural exchange of art and performance.

Please fund the IAAC's unique endeavor generously!

We currently need about 50K to cover the costs of bringing this event to New York City which entails bringing the performers over from India and other countries within the subcontinent. Any amount is helpful and will further our constant efforts in bringing a rich, cultural exchange of performance to New York City!

Spread the word and give generously to IAAC's annual dance festival, Erasing Borders 2014!

story:
8/3/16 @ 10:46am - We've had a wonderful angel donor give $1,000 directly through our website. It doesn't show up here - but that puts our fundraising at $6,275. That's 74% of the way to our goal. Please help us get the rest of the way and support this incredible production.

A Story of Acceptance, Growth, and the Power of the Stars

From August 18-September 4, 2016, two-time NY Innovative Theater Award-winning Libra Theater Company (and eight-time nominated!) will produce Touch, a thrilling play by Toni Press-Coffman directed by Nathaniel Shaw at NYC’s 59E59 Theaters.

"…a gripping, heart-wrenching, tender drama whose scenes shift seamlessly, character to character, past to present."   - The New York Times

Touch follows Kyle Kalke, an astronomer since childhood and a high school "science nerd” who falls in love with flamboyant, outspoken, openhearted Zoe. Astonishingly enough to Kyle, Zoe loves him back. But when she is kidnapped and murdered, Kyle barricades himself by devoting himself more feverishly to the cosmos and losing himself in loveless sex – groping toward once again finding the touch that will rekindle the joy that he once had.

Touch is about people in despair. People questioning whether there’s any point to rediscovering passion and risking connection. We see ourselves in Kyle and his friends and family around him. And we ask ourselves: How can we cope with the losses in our lives – particularly the most devastating? How can we pick up the pieces? And how can we grow to find ourselves again and let back in the people around us?

A Talented, Amazing Group of Artists

Touch is an incredible play, but even an incredible play is nothing without an equally incredible team led by director Nathaniel Shaw, Associate Choreographer of Broadway's Once and newly appointed Artistic Director of the Virginia Repertory Theatre.

We've assembled a fantastic cast of Broadway and off-Broadway actors including:

  • Emily Batsford (The Brightness of Heaven at Cherry Lane)
  • Amadeo Fusca (Upright Citizens Brigade)
  • Katrina Lenk (Broadway's Once and Spiderman: Turn Off the Dark, Indecent at The Vineyard)
  • Pete McElligott (Don Juan at The Pearl, The Thirteenth Commandment at Libra Theater Company)

Not only that, we've assemble an amazing design team that includes lighting designer Carl Weimann (Libra’s Kind Souls and The Thirteenth Commandment – NY IT Award nomination), scenic designer Craig Napoliello (The Bardy Bunch:The War Of... at St. Clement's Theatre), sound designer Julian Evans (John & Jen 20th Anniversary production at Theater Row), and costume designer Kristin Isola (The Understudy at McCarter Theatre).

We Need You!

Libra has been producing exciting, award-winning theater for five years now. But we’re sure you know that making theater in New York is expensive - especially for a small but might company like ours. And while we budget conservatively and think realistically when planning our productions, we still need your help. After all, Touch marks our most expensive production to date!

By giving today and helping us reach our $8,500 goal, you'll help close the gap in funding for Touch and ensure the success of this incredible show.

Does $5 Help?

YES! Of course, gifts of $50, $100, and higher go a long way. But so does $25, $10, or even $5. Here's a breakdown:

  • $5 pays for an actor's script
  • $25 funds one of our show props
  • $50 can help underwrite one set of costumes
  • $100 covers the cost of hundreds of show postcards
  • $300 pays for nearly a week's rehearsal
  • $1,000 funds almost an entire week of theater rental

And if you donate - even if it's $5 - we want to shout it from the rooftops! When you look at the perks to the right, you'll see that we've outlined all the ways we'll try to express our gratitude (from listings on our website to the sponsorship of costumes for one of our Touch characters).

How Else Can I Help?

In so many ways!

  • Sign up for the email list on our website. We'll keep you posted about all the great things we've got in the works.
  • Encourage others you think might be interested in supporting Libra. We're always looking to grow our family!
  • Come see Touch! It's going to be a phenomenal production that's now on sale!
  • Like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.

Thank you in advance for all your help! And we hope to see you at Touch!


Libra Theater Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Libra Theater Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted.

story:
Why support BOOM CRACK! + BOOM BOX! Road to Hip Hop International

BOOM CRACK! and BOOM BOX! Dance Companies are Chicago’s top professional and pre-professional hip-hop and urban contemporary company. Unlike average hip-hop companies, we create inspiring and memorable concept-based sets with a style that is unique to the company. Our concepts and style of dance push the boundaries of today’s hip-hop dance and open the door for creating the hip-hop dance of tomorrow. 

This August our passionate team of 35 dancers will be representing Chicago and the BOOM CRACK! Family in Las Vegas, Nevada at Hip Hop International Championships. This is the FIRST YEAR we will be representing Chicago and the USA in 3 categories, Varsity, Adult and MegaCrew. Through an intense 10 day competition of 40+ countries, Hip Hop International's mission is to unite the world of hip hop through dance. HHI continues to be the world's ambassador in promoting hip hop dance culture.

How You Can Help

There are a number of costs involved through out our journey to HHI. Thousands of dollars will be spent to cover: rehearsal studio rental fees, competition fees, costumes fees, transportation, hotel accommodations, and much more. Through your contribution, our hope is to raise $3000 to cover these expenses. 

You've Donated! Now What?

  1. Outstanding! Your support is greatly appreciated. You will receive an email at the conclusion of the campaign with information on how to claim your perk. 
  2. Share this message with your friends using the hashtag #BCDCRoadtoHHI or by using the IndieGoGo share tools at the top of this page!

story:
About BLANK CANVAS

Adam's paintings come to life and throw viewers into vivid scenes with their lost loves. The irony: Adam has never been in love. But when he does fall, what happens to the power of his paintings?

Two years ago, BLANK CANVAS had a staged reading in tea in a big mug's Sweet Summer Reading Series at ART/New York. Now, we have the opportunity to fully stage the play's premiere in the Downtown UrbanTheater Festival (DUTF) this April.

What This Campaign Can Do 

While the DUTF generously provides a small stipend ($300), production space/basic technical needs, marketing assistance, and discounts on rehearsal space, we are committed to paying our artists. After all, this is a show about an artist! Below is a breakdown of what we need.

Actors (7) $350
Stage Manager $100
Costume Designer $100
Lighting Designer $100


Director $100
Producer $100
Set Materials $100
Costume Materials $100
Rehearsal Space $100

The Impact

Your support will not only bring this premiere to reality, but will allow us to compensate the creatives involved in the process. 

OUR CAST

Zoey - Elizabeth Gray

Adam - Zane Johnston

Thea - Barbra Wengerd*

Woman - Kari Morris*

Woman 2 - Kristina Mueller*

Boy - Clarke Bliss

Girl - Emily Asaro

*Appearing Courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, and beyond. If you're in the city, be our audience! We want you to join us for the show on April 3rd. #BLANKCANVASplay

The Art Party!

JOIN US for the BLANK CANVAS rehearsal launch party! Meet the cast and creative team, enjoy happy hour drink prices, and bid on original artwork from a range of artists, including Esteban Delgado, LeeAnne Maxey, Sarah Cote, and Tasha Garcia. 

When: Friday 3/14 from 7pm to 11pm 

Where: West 3rd Common (1 W 3rd Street, New York, NY 10013; 4/6/B/D/F/N/Q/R)

Who: You!

story:
- Short Summary -

Greetings :-) My name is Ben Bagby and I've danced in movies, performed on Broadway, in Casinos, on Cruiseships and in Regional Theatres in the U.S. I've also choreographed television commercials for Levi's, Mazda and Harrah's Casino. The one constant in my life has been Music, and I've been asked to create a one-hour show. I already have a Talent Agent to book the show (Famous Faces Inc.), our first booking (December 13th) and a talented cast of performers to do the show with me. I have a home recording studio where I've created whatever music I couldn't find for the show. Now all I need is funding to create the best presentation possible. 

                               - What We Need - 

My goal is to raise enough money :
1. To Invest in props and costumes, for my cast of performers. We want to look professional and amazing. We need hats, wigs, props, and theatrical clothing to do this. 
2. To rent rehearsal spaces for myself and the other performers. We have to practice on a regular basis, to learn the songs and dances for the show. We need a large space with mirrors for this. We need to meet at least once a week. 
3. To pay my fellow cast mates for their valuable time.  For time spent rehearsing with me, driving to and from these rehearsals, and for performing our first show on December 13th. 
4. We need at least 4 high-quality, headset wireless microphones. Nothing can ruin a great show like bad sound. Cheap microphones sound cheap, no matter how great the singers are. The microphones I'm looking to invest in are approx. $550. each. This is the most critical of the list. Even if we have plain clothing, and have to rehearse outdoors, for no pay, we will still need to "sound great" :-)   
5. Advertising (other than social media) If we don't meet the $5,000.  goal, the microphones will be the first investment. If we exceed the goal, the extra funds can be spent on advertising. Social media advertising is free, but many patrons of the arts are not "savvy" when it comes to social media and get all of their entertainment info. from local papers and television. 

                                  - The Impact - 

Your contribution can make all the difference in the world, between a show that "has potential" and a show that is a truly professional presentation. 

                           - Other Ways You Can Help - 

    I realize that some people are not able to make a contribution, but we still could use your help. If you know of anyone, friends, family, co-workers in your employment, or anyone in your social media network, who may be able to contribute or spread the word about this project, please refer them to this page. I thank you in advance, just for taking the time to read this far. Take care and hope to see you in the audience one day :-) Very Sincerely, Ben Bagby.

story:
Adopt a Sequin Today! 

It takes a lot of money to produce a show like Little Miss Glitz, a show that requires this much sparkle and glitter. We need your help to make it happen. Every dollar you donate will go towards adopting a sequin to put on our pageant dresses to make us sizzle and shine like we’ve always dreamed.

Premiering March 11-26 at the PAL Studio Theatre in Vancouver, this is your chance to support the pageant event of a lifetime. 

The Show

Little Miss Glitz is a full-scale, over-the-top parody of child beauty pageants set to some of the biggest pop hits of the past 30 years. 

The show sets the questionable beauty standards and parenting practices of hit reality TV’s Toddlers and Tiaras to music in a high-energy musical with a twist: there is no scripted winner. Each night, a panel of judges pulled from the audience will determine who wins, leaving the cast to improvise the end of the show. Who will win the pageant? You’ll have to see it to find out.  

Adding to this element of surprise is a heartwarming story of Isabella Connor, a frumpy and impressionable 7-year-old played by Paige Fraser, as she navigates through the world of child beauty pageants. While at first pageants seem like a fun way to dress up, have fun and get a foot in the door of stardom, Isabella soon discovers that the cutthroat world of pageants takes no prisoners. You have to fight to survive.

Shocking, sassy, and uncompromisingly funny, Little Miss Glitz questions modern society’s obsession with a person’s looks to uncover the beauty within. Coupled with Dawn Ewen’s fearless direction and show-stopping choreography, and Stewart Yu’s pop-savvy music direction, Little Miss Glitz promises to take you on a musical adventure like you’ve never seen before.

Go Glitz or go home!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $2,500 to help us get this show off the ground. As you can imagine, producing a big-budget musical production is a daunting task, especially for a brand-new non-profit theatre production society like ours. We need your help to make our dream become a reality. 

Your donation helps us to:

  • Buy costumes, and glitter them to the gods;
  • Build sets;
  • Rent rehearsal space;
  • Pay for our venue rental;
  • Print lots of posters, postcards, etc. to help us market the show, and;
  • Buy more sequins, glitter and rhinestones than we can possibly handle.

We have come up with some amazing perks for you, our wonderful donors, friends and supporters, including tickets to the show and autographed merchandise.

The Impact

In the high-stakes world of musical parodies, every little bit helps and there is no donation too small. Everything that is donated to this campaign will be lovingly used to realize our dream of having this show come to life. It is our goal, no, our duty to make this musical a reality, and need your help to make it happen. As the ancient proverb goes: It takes a whole online community to produce a new musical!

About Us

Too Fly Productions is made up of are a group of creative people who support each others’ visions and help our dreams become a reality. No creative pursuit is out of bounds or too ridiculous to realize. Except perhaps an all unicorn water polo team – they pop too many balls.

Creativity and performance is our passion. We seek out others who are equally passionate about what they do to join us in creating fresh collaborative works. Our projects are a chance for emerging artists to showcase their talents in a supportive environment while nurturing joy for the craft. In other words, we put the “fun” in “theafuntre”.

The Glitz Team

Creative

Director and Choreographer: Dawn Ewen
Music Direction: Stewart Yu
Writer: Alan Pronger

Cast

Paige Fraser as Isabella Connor
Ben Bilideau as Cliff Connor
Rose McNeil as Hillary Butterfry
Grace Newson as Heather Butterfry
Vanessa Coley-Donohue as Carol Wood
Kayla Heyblom as Sparkle America
Rebecca Piplica as Rose Ziploc
Meaghan Hommy as Mackenzie Ziploc
Jennifer Suratos as Franny Darlene
Stewart Yu as Stefan St. Claire
Tiana Jung as Jaylene Darlene
Matthew Fedorowicz as Peter Phyle

Production

Production Manager, FOH, Set Designer: Tim Kraumanis
Stage Manager: Genevieve Magtoto
Assistant Stage Manager: Julia Lank
Costume Design: Jacqueline Breakwell
Lighting Designer: Ian Connor

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that times are tight, and so if you can't help us financially, there are still ways you can help us reach our goal! 

-  Please feel free to share this link/project on Facebook, Twitter, email, poster, anything! Every little bit helps. 

-  Come see our show! Tickets available at: www.universe.ca/glitz

Come see our show! Tickets available at: www.universe.ca/glitz

story:
Help support the best show in Brooklyn, and help SlamBamDance! Grow!

SlamBamDance! is an immersive dance and rock music performance that joins choreographers with Brooklyn bands in a first-of-its-kind stage show, only at the Knitting Factory, Sunday, September 13th, 2015. 

       My goal with SlamBamDance! is to create an industry proving ground that provides new talent with a platform to engage a wide variety of audiences. Our first event in May was a smashing success (see video promo for performance clips), but we need your help to take SlamBamDance! to the next level. Your contributions will help SlamBamDance! take its production value sky rocket, with a goal providing funds to keep SlamBamDance! going and of documenting the choreography process for a television docu-series. I truly want to show the world my passion for bringing professional dance and live rock music together. It's incredible important me to be able to provide the artists and bands with funding because of the hard work they put into their passions! We know all too well that artists don't get the financial support they truly deserve.

This event features choreography by SlamBamDance! Creator and Executive Producer, David Guggino, along with Katrina Philip and Holly Maddock, live music from Sun Voyager, Eiko Hara, Ice Balloons.

I earned my dance chops at the Joffrey Ballet School and performing with the Joffrey Ensemble along with prestigious companies like Momix, Rebecca Kelly Ballet, the Chase Brock Experience with appearances on Regis and Kelly and Equity Musicals. I've self-produce my own off-broadway show "What Guys Do!" the last "SlamBamDance!" and many individual works.

I see SlamBamDance! as a pure creative space for the New York dance and music – world class choreography, hung on the backdrop of the independent Brooklyn music scene. 

“SlamBamDance! is what happens when dance and music are allowed to organically collide, resulting in the truest form of art,”.

Click Here to read a review of our first SlamBamDance performance in May.

Photo by Drew Kolar, AllMediaNY.com

--

Here’s what your contributions will go toward:

*First and foremost, to support the show on Sept. 13th!!

*Artist Stipends for choreographers, dancers and bands

*Costumes for dancers

*A lighting designer for the night of the performance

*Rehearsal space for this and future SlamBamDance! events.

*Production and editing of SlamBamDance! sizzle reel.

*Most importantly, the help SlamBamDance! Continue on into the future.

*PR and advertising, as well as helping to get important reviewers to the event.

Lastly I want everyone to know that your support means the world to me, this dream of mine is only beginning and your help ensures amazing creative work can be brought to the masses. Please share this with everyone you can! Don't forget use the indiegogo share tools!

Sincerely,

David Guggino

Creator

story:
What is the Play About?

Al Marshall just wants to do what's right, but when he has to look after his troubled teenage son and his aging father at the same time, Al begins to lose his grip on reality.  How do you move forward while you're being pulled into the past?

We are thrilled to have been selected out of over 800 applicants to be a part of the New York International Fringe Festival. 

Our mission is to bring a family story into the 21st century. In the age of smart phones and social media, we aim to remind our audiences that while it may be challenging, human connection is what's most fulfilling. 

Who's Involved?

Playwright: Zack Friedman

Director and Sound Designer: Stephen Cedars

Producers: Zack Friedman, Rosie Kolbo, and Kara Ayn Napolitano

Starring: Doug Willen*, Robert Sean Miller* and Andrew Chamberlain (*Pending Equity Approval)

Set and Lighting Designer: Tyler M. Perry

ACR: Lydia Lavin

Produced by: Drift In, Act Out

Why Donate?

While being a part of FringeNYC means being a part of an awesome Indie theater community, it also means funding your own production. Here's where we turn to you. You can make this show happen! Your support will make it possible for us to...

  • Book rehearsal space (cause our apartments are too small)
  • Buy props and costumes (so our actors have things to wear)
  • Build a set that is collapsible and portable 
  • Create a sound and lighting design that will transport our audience into the world of the play 
  • Produce promotional materials to help get the word out about the play 
  • Purchase insurance 
  • Pay our dues to FringeNYC 
  • Make sure our actors and production team get are reimbursed for their hard work!

And lastly... it's always good to support new, live theater in this medium of expression we love so much!

How Else Can You Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still be a part of our show!

  • Come to a performance!
  • Share this campaign with your friends! If they donate and mention you, you'll receive a special thanks in our program. Because we are thankful for you!

Stay in Touch

Web: FathersAndSonsThePlay.com
Facebook: facebook.com/FathersAndSonsThePlay
Twitter: @FatherAndSons2

Challenges 

FringeNYC is a festival of over 200 shows. As a result, we will have very little time to rehearse in our performance space. That's why we have put together a team of problem solving, experienced theater professionals to apply the necessary forethought and detailed pre-planning to assure that our load-in, tech and performances will be efficient and productive.

We are so excited to be a part of the 2015 New York International Fringe Festival community, but standing out in a crowd of over 200 plays is a definite challenge. This is an area where you can help! We would greatly appreciate you spreading the word about our play.

Thanks and we'll see you at FringeNYC!

Sincerely,

Zack, Rosie, Kara and Our Whole Team
