story:
HELP THE WHISKEY MAIDEN PRODUCTION TEAM RAISE $2,000!

We have set the bar at $2,000…but the sky is the true limit and any amount will help!

**Be sure to check out our amazing donation incentives**

A NEW INCENTIVE HAS BEEN ADDED AT $75!

The Basics…

Christopher Kelley, award winning playwright and director, has written yet another wonderful play and placed this bundle into the hands of the esteemed theatrical company Theatre of NOTE. Elegant in its simplicity, Whiskey Maiden is an allegorical piece surrounding Billy, a worldly, intuitive homeless man with a bewildering mythology and Phil, an extremely wealthy former agent now forced out and fearing for his life.

We are excited to bring Christopher Kelley’s latest creation to life on our stage, BUT WE CAN’T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!

We at Theatre of NOTE are very passionate about our productions and quite creative ourselves. These funds would go towards …

  • Costumes for 7 separate characters
  • Designer Stipends – We believe that these talented and dedicated theatrical artists should be compensated for their hard work and the countless hours that they invest. The Costume Designer, Set Designer, Audio Designer, Lighting Designer, Prop Master, Graphics Designer, Stage Manager, Master Carpenter,…
  • Building materials, lighting & sound design elements, painting supplies, etc.
  • Programs, postcards, & a banner for the front of the theatre.

We need to raise at least an additional $2,000 in order to mount the production that we believe the script deserves and we are hoping to raise as much of that as possible with this campaign.

All donations are tax deductible as Theatre of NOTE is a 501(c)(3).


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT AND ENJOY OUR DONATION INCENTIVES!

Hopefully some of our featured incentives will inspire you. Even more important, we hope that your desire to support new art, amazing theatre, and this exceptional script will inspire you. We will be grateful for any donation, no matter how small. If you’re unable to provide financial support, you can still show your support of live theatre by:

·  Sharing this campaign with your friends and family!

·  Follow Theatre of NOTE & Whiskey Maiden on Facebook and Twitter and share our posts to help spread the word!

·  Come to Theatre of NOTE and experience Whiskey Maiden, opening September 18th (with your help)!


WHO IS THE TEAM BEHIND WHISKEY MAIDEN?

Former member of Theatre of NOTE, Christopher Kelley has been associated with the acclaimed theatrical company for over twenty years and has acted, written, and directed numerous productions that have come to life on the NOTE stage. Having acted in productions such as Dennis Miles' The Guileless Side  and Susan Champagne's Winter Soldiers  and pulled double duty as playwright and director in Salt Ink, Near Death, and The Wreck of the Unfathomable, which attained numerous Ovation Award nominations alone, Christopher Kelley is no stranger to using the stage to showcase impactful and talented work. 

Whiskey Maiden is currently scheduled to open at our home, Theatre of NOTE, 1517 N. Cahuenga Blvd. in Hollywood on September 18th, 2015 co-produced by Chantelle Albers, Jason Denuszek, Claudia de Vasco, & Aaron Saldaña.


WHAT ARE SOME OF THE PERKS?

All reward incentives above $20 automatically come with acknowledgement of your support all of our social media accounts and a special thanks within the program.

_


$50 - The Literary Soul

Do you have a love for language? Perhaps you have a favorite quote? Are you looking to frame those perfect words for someone? This package gives you the opportunity to attain a custom designed calligraphic message that you can cherish or give away as a gift.

_


 

$75 - The Artist

Are you looking to develop that voice of yours in preparation for your next big role? This package nets you a one hour session in dialect coaching with Cluadia De Vasco. She's professionally coached countless artists including Antonio Banderas, Liam Hemsworth, John Malkovich, Juliette Binoche, and more. And, if you support Whiskey Maiden, you'll get 25% off of her normal rate. What a deal! Sessions to be scheduled upon the completion of the Whiskey Maiden Indiegogo Campaign and are subject to coach's availability. Sessions are transferable and available via Skype. 

_

 


$300 - The Criminal Mind -  !SOLD OUT!

The top incentive in the Whiskey Maiden Indiegogo Campaign! Theatre of NOTE member Kirsten Vangsness of the television show Criminal Minds has generously donated this autographed Quantico sweatshirt to be part of our fundraising campaign. Whether you're a collector, a fan of the show, or a fan of 'Garcia', this incentive is sure to make at least one supporter very happy.

story:
What is AIITF 2016?

Milwaukee Irish Arts is proud to host the 2016 Acting Irish International Theatre Festival (AIITF) from May 24-29 at Next Act Theatre in Milwaukee. Founded more than 30 years ago, the AIITF has been held annually by its member Irish theatre companies in cities around the U.S., Canada and Ireland. Continuing this long tradition of showcasing Irish works, this year Milwaukee welcomes theatre groups from Chicago, Cincinnati, Rochester NY, Del Ray Beach FL, Calgary and Winnipeg in Canada, and Dublin, Ireland to present a wide variety of offerings in an exciting week of Irish theatre.

Momentum for the festival is building locally with planning for fundraising, hotel accommodations, adjudicator selection, programs, transportation and reception venues spearheaded by a dedicated local festival committee.

Why we need your help

Fundraising for the festival is a huge challenge and your support is crucial to making the festival a success. Among the many expenses we need to cover: 

·  Housing for participating groups at the InterContinental Milwaukee

·  Rental of Next Act Theatre

·  Hiring of adjudicators

·  Set construction for the 9 participating groups

·  Rental of some required set pieces for the 9 groups

·  Transportation 

·  Awards brunch for all participants on Sunday, May 29

Hotel accommodations and theatre rental account for almost half of our $50,000 budget. As the host group, Milwaukee Irish Arts must provide 15 room nights of lodging to each of the participating groups. We have been fortunate to be able to rent the professional theatre space at Next Act Theatre as the festival headquarters, which will provide the flexibility needed to present nine different plays in six days with production crews building and striking sets at break-neck speed for two performances a day with only a few hours of change-over between the plays.

Without housing for the participants and an ideal theatre space for the nine productions, the festival cannot go on. We are asking for any help you can extend to us to make the magic happen!

Fundraising Challenges

Our skilled and dedicated festival committee has been hard at work seeking funds from grant sources and local businesses, and we’re already thrilled to welcome Northwestern Mutual, We Energies and Milwaukee Irish Fest as partners. But the additional donations of individuals, Irish theatre fans and organizations are absolutely essential for us to achieve our funding goals and allow us to host the best festival in the history of AIITF this May.

The Impact

The mission of Milwaukee Irish Arts for over 30 years has been to bring the Irish story to American audiences. Hosting the 2016 Acting Irish International Theatre Festival not only continues the tradition of the festival, but brings nine Irish plays to Milwaukee for local audiences to enjoy. According to Irish theatre festival tradition, all performances are assessed by an experienced adjudicator, who shares his/her evaluation with the cast and audience following each show, making the performances a learning experience for all.

Milwaukee Irish Arts hopes to impress with this year’s production of Sean O’Casey’s epic “The Plough and the Stars,” to be presented on the opening night of the festival in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the Easter Rising in Dublin.

The festival affords an excellent opportunity to participating groups to improve their craft by sharing their work and ideas, in addition to receiving invaluable critique by trained adjudicators.

Awards are given out at a final brunch on Sunday, May 29. Milwaukee Irish Arts has won numerous awards at the AIITF over the years, including awards for Best Production, Best Actor/Actress/Supporting Actor and Director. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donations are urgently needed and gratefully accepted, but you can also help us out by:

  • Passing on the word about this campaign to your personal network.
  • Volunteering on one of various committees. The festival will require a large contingent of volunteers. If you wish to volunteer, send your name, phone number to aiitf2016@gmail.com and someone will contact you.

If you are having trouble donating through this site

If you prefer, you can mail a check to:
Milwaukee Irish Arts
2604 E Capitol Dr

Milwaukee, WI 53211

Other Ways to Connect with us

Website: https://milirisharts.wordpress.com (here is where you will find a lineup of the plays as well as ticket and hotel information)
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/milirisharts
Twitter: https://twitter.com/milirisharts

Thank you for your generosity and support! And be sure to join us for the festival shows – meet the actors and adjudicators and experience all the excitement and conviviality that a great Irish theatre festival has to offer! If you are coming from out of town, check out our website for great hotel rates.

Slainté

Milwaukee Irish Arts

story:
Performances Dec. 2nd, 3rd & 9th, 10th
At The Local 3036

RESERVE SEATS HERE

Who are we?

We are a small ensemble of Chicago artists brought together for the purpose of developing a full-length original piece of theatre.  As members of the Alluvium Group, we are dedicated to creating exciting theatre in alternative spaces.  Our rich history of collaboration has given us a strong shared vocabulary, allowing us to create work efficiently and in-the-moment.


Why dreams?

For us, dreams are a subject of endless fascination.  The average human being spends about six years of their life dreaming: this has been true since the dawn of man, and despite how far we've come we still lack any concrete understanding of the meaning or purpose of our dreams.  Having crossed the bridge of psychoanalysis and gotten a glimpse of the endless horizon beyond, we tend to turn away, cruising through life without a moments thought of the contents of our nightly meanderings.  Is there perhaps another way to navigate through these expanses?   Through the application of our devising process (and borrowing techniques from the Ancient Egyptians, the European Surrealists, and many other dream-explorers) we look to find our own inspiration from the dreaming mind.


How you can help!

We are building a play from the ground up.  Our work is not wasteful, and our needs are basic but important.


- Space is a necessity of making any sort of theater. The majority of the money donated will be used to pay for space for rehearsals and performances. We have cut a deal with a dance studio in the Lakeview neighborhood of Chicago to use their space for rehearsal purposes for $576. In addition to performance space expenses and extra rehearsal time, the grand total of space expenses should be about $1000. 


- As an original piece, the specific demands of the show will be revealed as it is developed. We strive to create great theater with minimal props, costumes, and crew, by using what we have to the fullest potential and transforming the everyday into the extraordinary. $150 dollars will be used to pay for what little material we may need.


- The last hundred dollars will be used to develop and produce promotional materials to ensure butts in the seats come show time. 


 We do this work because we love it, but any independent director/producer's dream is to be able pay an ensemble for their long and difficult work.  Your contributions could make the difference between starving artists and entrepreneurs.  Ticket sales are becoming a less and less reliable percentage of income for theatres across the country, and the involvement of individuals like yourself allows alternative and risky work to continue.

 

Thank you so much for your interest in this production. And if you really like what we do, please spread the word!

The Dream Machine is:

    - Taylor Brewerton

    - Justin Deming

    - Katie Dingle

    - Kevin Duvall (Directing)

    - Cooper Forsman

    - Kirsten Riiber

    - Mike Sater


Here are some photos of our initial work.
story_txt:
Performances Dec. 2nd, 3rd & 9th, 10thAt The Local 3036RESERVE SEATS HEREWho are we?
We are a small ensemble of Chicago artists brought together for the
purpose of developing a full-length original piece of theatre.   As members of
the Alluvium Group, we are dedicated to creating exciting theatre in
alternative spaces.  Our rich history of collaboration has given us a strong shared vocabulary, allowing us to create work efficiently
and in-the-moment.

Why dreams?For us, dreams are a subject of endless fascination.  The average human being spends about six years of their life dreaming: this has been true since the dawn of man, and despite how far we've come
 we still lack any concrete understanding of the meaning or purpose of 
our dreams.  Having crossed the bridge of psychoanalysis and gotten a 
glimpse of the endless horizon beyond, we tend to turn away, cruising 
through life without a moments thought of the contents of our nightly 
meanderings.  Is there perhaps another way to navigate through these 
expanses?   Through the application of our devising process (and borrowing techniques from the Ancient Egyptians, the European Surrealists, and many other dream-explorers) we look to find our own inspiration from the dreaming mind.
How you can help!
We are building a play from the ground up.  Our work is not wasteful, and our needs
are basic but important.

- Space is a necessity of making any
sort of theater. The majority of the money donated will be used to
pay for space for rehearsals and performances. We have cut a
deal with a dance studio in the
Lakeview neighborhood of Chicago to use their space for
rehearsal purposes for $576. In addition to performance space expenses and extra rehearsal time, the grand total of space expenses should be about
$1000. 

- As an original piece, the specific demands of the show will be revealed as it is developed. We strive to create great theater with minimal props,
costumes, and crew, by using what we have to the fullest potential
and transforming the everyday into the extraordinary. $150 dollars
will be used to pay for what little material we may need.

- The last hundred dollars will be used
to develop and produce promotional materials to ensure butts in the
seats come show time. 

 We do this work because we love it, but any independent director/producer's dream is to be able pay an ensemble for their long and
difficult work.  Your contributions could make the difference
between starving artists and entrepreneurs. 
Ticket sales are becoming a less and less reliable percentage of
income for theatres across the country, and the involvement of
individuals like yourself allows alternative and risky work to
continue.
 
Thank you so much for your interest in this production. And if you
really like what we do, please spread the word!
The Dream Machine is:
    - Taylor Brewerton
    - Justin Deming
    - Katie Dingle
    - Kevin Duvall (Directing)
    - Cooper Forsman
    - Kirsten Riiber
    - Mike Sater

Here are some photos of our initial work.

story:
About the Show:

FREAK PLAYGROUND is an original play by me, Keiko Green.  It follows 6 women on a playground, slowly retreating back into their childhood roles and games. 

The show explores themes of sibling rivalry, bullying, competition, gender roles, drugs, and sex. All of the characters are based on playground children, and we will be recreating many playground structures (the slide, the swings, etc.) through representational movement.   

With aspects of dance, chance, and masks, this 60-minute performance is planned to perform in Seattle on July 6th & 7th. The final script will be presented in mid-May, with rehearsals beginning right as the fundraising campaign comes to an end on May 21st.

About Me:

My name is Keiko Green. I'm a 26 year-old half-Japanese theatre artist. I got my BFA in Theatre from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, studying mostly under the Experimental Theatre Wing. I like to mix little kid things with grown up things. I think it's important to say something with a show, but I take the word "entertainment" very seriously. I am here to entertain you!

Only 2 Nights?

Freak Playground has already been submitted to a few festivals, and will continue to grow. But we need your help. I also have plans to do at least one site-specific version of the show at a local playground.

Why $3,000?

The goal amount is the bare minimum of what it will cost to put up this production.
This includes rehearsal/performance space, the (unfortunately very little) pay for talent and crew, costumes, props, posters, etc. Anything you can give will be GREATLY appreciated!

THE CAST:

Sarah Bixler as Claire

Sarah J Eagen as Nik
 

Elaine Huber as Katie 

Pearl Klein as Teri

Jordi Montes as Jo

 

Thank you so much for your support! We'll keep you updated, and I'll see you at the show!

story:
About Lamondance And Their Trip To Brazil

This July, Lamondance has been invited to perform as a guest in the Prestigious Summer Gala at the International Seminar of Dance in Brasilia, Brazil. This invitation marks the end of the company's fourth season and the directors are excited to bring their talented group of dancers and their new full-evening show Human on the road!  The company will participate in a three-week long workshop with international teachers and choreographers and then tour with Human to the neighbouring cities of Taguatinga, Ceilandia and Sobradinho.

Lamondance was established in 2009 as a contemporary training and performance company for aspiring professional dancers. Directed by Lara Barclay, Monica Proença and Davi Rodrigues, the program offers dancers the opportunity to immerse themselves in original choreography and learn the motivation behind a professional dance company. The directors bring their unique international experience and passion together to guide students toward a career in dance. As well as nurturing young Canadian talent, Lamondance also invites select Brazilian students to join the program to share their experience and knowledge in dance. This allows for a wonderful cultural exchange between Canadian and Brazilian dancers.

Lamondance has showcased their work in various local and international performances, festivals and fundraisers including Vancouver Global Dance Project, Art Umbrella’s Sunday Performance Series, Move: the company, TanzArt Festival in Germany, Dancestreams, Art for Impact, Vancity Projects, One Night for 1 Day and the Cultch’s Ignite Youth Festival. 

Lamondance operates as a Not-For-Profit Society, working under the umbrella of RNB Dance and Theatre Arts, based in North Vancouver.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The company’s fundraising goal is to raise $5,000.00, an amount that will be put toward accommodations as well as transportation while in Brasilia.  Costs associated with performing abroad are expensive but it is important that our dancers are given this opportunity to perform and exchange with international artists.

Our dancers have already booked and paid for their own flights but we are still seeking support for their accommodation and transportation while in Brazil.   

 

The Impact Your Contributions Will Have

Any aid we receive here on Indiegogo will go toward off setting costs for the dancers and their paid chaperones while in Brazil as well as enable them to see the country and explore its rich history. This trip will change the lives of everyone on the journey, and your help will ensure that we are able to provide these deserving dancers with the best possible experience. 

 

Lamondance is a creation center without limits, where movement and expression are explored through the physical language.  Your help is valuable to us because with it, we can plant more cultural seeds not only in Vancouver, but in Brazil where we can share our ideas with a broader community of artists.  

By making a donation, you will not only be helping Lamondance with their exciting trip to Brazil, you'll also be contributing to the development of world culture through dance.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

So many of you have already helped with your financial contributions, time and emotional support. If you are unable to assist us with a contribution at this time, you can still help us by spreading the word! Feel free to share links to this page on your personal Facebook and Twitter accounts. You can “Like” the official Lamondance page on Facebook at the link below. In the coming days we’ll be launching a YouTube channel collecting video highlights from our performances over the past few years – be sure to visit it and send the link to your friends. The more awareness we can raise the better our chances for meeting our goal.

Thank you again for your time. We appreciate your help and hope to be able to share the stories of our visit with you soon!!

story:
What's this all about?

We all know psycho ex-girlfriends. Some of us have even been psycho ex-girlfriends. They’re on reality TV, stalking you on facebook, having lunch with your mothers and secretly showing up at your weddings “just to say ‘congratulations’”. They know your location, doctor’s name and social security number and their memories are impeccable. They love you so hard it just may hurt. You. But where, why and how were they created? Are they truly psychotic or simply victims of romantic crimes who were once innocent girls who looked for love in all the wrong places? Want to find out?

The Shelterbelt Theatre, Omaha's home for Certified Original theatre, is presenting Beaufield Berry's new original play, Psycho Ex-Girlfriend, running from April 18th through May 12th. This is happening, but that's not to say we don't need your help!

What We Need

The Shelterbelt has brought original plays to the Omaha theatre scene for 20 years now. We've developed new talent both on and off stage. We're dedicatied to continuing that tradition for at least another 20 years. But shows cost money to stage, and no matter how good the play, the cast, the production, it's just harder to get people to come see a show they've never heard of, written by someone they've never heard of, and performed by actors they've... you get the idea. The result is that a lot of our shows... really good shows that get great reviews... don't break even.

So we're trying something a little different this time. Our goal is to raise the money to cover the cost of the show before we open. Based on past productions, we're estimating this at $2000. This breaks down roughly as:

  • $600 for the crew costs (designers, stage manager, house manager...)
  • $500 for production costs (sets, props, costumes...)
  • $900 for posters, mailers and other publicity. Even at bulk rates, mailing is expensive!

What You Get

You mean other than a high quality orignal show? Well, there are perks to being a donor. Everyone who donates will be included in a special thank you section in our program and on our website. But we do have several other incentives for the Psycho Ex-Girlfriend in us all:

$5

Cyberstalker

Your name will appear in a special thanks section of our program and website.

$10

Late-night Caller

Your name will appear in a special thanks section of our program PLUS you will receive a reverse restraining order and your choice of either an “I survived my Psycho Ex-Girlfiend” pin or “Former Psycho Ex-Girlfriend” pin!

$20

Peeping Tom

Everything from above PLUS a Psycho Ex-Girlfriend poster and a ticket to see the show on the night of your choice (reservations permitting).

$40

Dumpster Diver

Everything from above PLUS "Your Little Black Book": an exclusive Psycho ExGirlfriend photo album!

$60

I made it just for you!

All of the above, and you get the Psycho Ex-Girlfriend mix-tape (as featured in the show!). Well, okay, it's a mix-CD, but that's even better, right?

$75

Dear Diary...

All of the above and you get the official Psycho Instruction manual co-written by Beaufield Berry and Katie Hurst! And your poster will be signed by the cast!

$100

I'm watching you...

All of the above and a DVD of the show signed by the cast!

$200

You've got it backwards!

The cast of the show will stalk you! That is, they'll take you out for drinks after the show. Plus all the other stuff from above.

As we get the designs finalized on the swag, we'll post pictures so you can see what it's going to look like.

In addition, we'll be providing exclusive updates that take you behind-the-scenes as we head towards opening night!

I'd like to help, but I'm a poor student!

It may be that you can't afford to donate. We're theatre people! We're familiar with being broke! But even if you can't contribute, there are still ways you can help!

Get the word out! You may be poor, but I bet you know someone who isn't! Let them know what we're trying to do here! For that matter, let everyone know! Indiegogo was nice enough to provide all those handy social-media links up there. It'd be a shame not to use them.

Look for more updates here as we get this rolling.

story:
The Project

Straeon is all about the extraordinary telling of great stories.  As a co-production between Straeon Filmworks Inc and Grove Hall, we are bringing you the beautiful and haunting play "Agnes of God" by John Pielmeier.

Our cast, crew, and production team are all local talent and supporters of English Theatre in Quebec, brought together by this passion project and the desire to share a wonderful story with you all.

Le Projet

Straeon se consacre au récit extraordinaire de grandes histoires. Nous vous présentons une pièce magnifique et envoûtante co-produite par Straeon Filmworks Inc et Grove Hall, “Agnes of God”, de John Pielmeier.

Notre casting, les personnes qui travaillent avec nous et notre équipe de production sont des talents locaux qui soutiennent le théâtre anglophone au Québec, rassemblés autour de ce projet passionant et par la volonté de partager une histoire magnifique avec chacun d'entre vous.


Performances/Réprésentations

November 12-14, 19-21, and 26-28 @ 8PM
November 15, 22, and 29 @ 3PM

Le 12-14, 19-21, et 26-28 novembre à 20h00
Le 15, 22, et 29 novembre à 15h00

Tickets: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2403621

What We Need & What You Get

Putting on a great show costs money.  We aren't looking for a lot (because we also believe that you don't need fancy digs and extreme - not to mention costly - measures in order to tell a great story), but there are still costs that must be covered.

Help us pay for:

  • Our talented, hard-working, and dedicated ACTORS!
  • Our talented, hard-working and dedicated CREW!
  • Advertising Material (flyers, posters, programs)
  • Costumes (we can't have naked nuns, after all)
  • Tech (so you can see and hear us)

How your good deeds will come back to you ten-fold:

  • You'll be supporting a fantastic show and local artists
  • Count this as your good deed for the day
  • Pick from some fun and interesting perks

And if we don't make our goal?  Well, as they say, the show must go on.


Ce dont nous avons besoin &
Ce que vous obtenez en retour

Mettre sur pieds un grand spectacle coûte de l'argent. Nous n'avons pas besoin de beaucoup (car nous pensons aussi qu'il n'est pas nécessaire d'avoir des loges luxueuses ni de prendre des mesures extrêmes – pour ne pas dire coûteuses - pour raconter une belle histoire), mais il y a toujours des frais à payer.

Aidez-nous à couvrir les frais pour:

  • Nos ACTRICES, talentueuse et dévouées, qui travaillent dur.
  • Notre EQUIPE, talentueuse et dévouée, qui travaille dur.
  • Le matériel publicitaire (flyers, posters, programmes)
  • Les costumes (nous ne pouvons pas avoir une religieuse dévêtue sur scène, après tout!)
  • Les supports technologiques (pour que vous puissiez nous voir et nous entendre)

Voici comment vos bonnes actions vous seront rendues décuplées:

  • Vous apporterez votre soutien à un spectacle fantastique et des artistes locaux
  • Considérez cela comme votre bonne action de la journée
  • Choisissez parmi les autres avantages intéressants et amusants qui s'offrent à vous

Et si nous n'atteignons pas notre objectif? Comme on dit, le spectacle doit continuer.

The Impact

Your contribution will demonstrate the community's support of the arts and of its local storytellers.  Not to mention encouraging a higher standard for creative theatre experiences.

L'Impact

Votre contribution témoignera du soutien apporté par la communauté aux arts et à ses conteurs d'histoires locaux. Sans compter le fait d'encourager un niveau supérieur de créativité théâtrale.

Risks & Challenges

We're dealing with mature and graphic themes, challenging people's expectations and comfort zones.  We're taking the risk to make innovative and daring theatre.  With a passionate and dedicated team, we've already trouble-shooted our production process and come up with solutions as the journey takes us further into heaven (or down into hell).  Now all that's left is a little help from our friends ($$$).

Risques & Défis

Nous abordons des thèmes sérieux et graphiques tout en remettant en question les attentes du public et sa zone de confort. Nous prenons le risque de produire un théâtre innovant et audacieux. Avec notre équipe passionnée et dévouée, nous avons déjà analysé en profondeur notre processus de production et avons élaboré des solutions à mesure que ce voyage nous emmène plus loin vers le Ciel (ou en Enfer). Maintenant, tout ce dont nous avons besoin, c'est d'un peu d'aide de la part de nos amis ($$$).


Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have two pennies to rub together?  We still want your support!

You can:

  • SPREAD THE WORD
  • SHARE and TWEET our indiegogo campaign on social media
  • And if you're in the area and want to lend a helping hand, we could always use a couple VOLUNTEERS!  Just email Katherine (one of our co-producers) at agnesofgodmtl@gmail.com!

D'autres façons de nous aider

Vous n'avez pas un sous? Nous voulons quand même votre soutien! 

Vous pouvez:

  • PASSER LE MOT
  • PARTAGER et TWEETER notre campagne indiegogo sur les médias sociaux
  • Et si vous êtes dans le coin et souhaitez donner un coup de main, nous pourrions avoir besoin de BENEVOLES! Il vous suffit d'envoyer un email à Katherine (l'un de nos co-producteurs) à l'adresse agnesofgodmtl@gmail.com!

Our talented, hard-working, and dedicated ACTORS!
Our talented, hard-working and dedicated CREW!
Advertising Material (flyers, posters, programs)
Costumes (we can't have naked nuns, after all)
Tech (so you can see and hear us)

How your good deeds will come back to you ten-fold:

You'll be supporting a fantastic show and local artists
Count this as your good deed for the day
Pick from some fun and interesting perks


And if we don't make our goal?  Well, as they say, the show must go on.


Ce dont nous avons besoin & Ce que vous obtenez en retour

Mettre sur pieds un grand spectacle coûte de l'argent. Nous n'avons pas besoin de beaucoup (car nous pensons aussi qu'il n'est pas nécessaire d'avoir des loges luxueuses ni de prendre des mesures extrêmes – pour ne pas dire coûteuses - pour raconter une belle histoire), mais il y a toujours des frais à payer.Aidez-nous à couvrir les frais pour:

Nos ACTRICES, talentueuse et dévouées, qui travaillent dur.
Notre EQUIPE, talentueuse et dévouée, qui travaille dur.
Le matériel publicitaire (flyers, posters, programmes)
Les costumes (nous ne pouvons pas avoir une religieuse dévêtue sur scène, après tout!)

Les supports technologiques (pour que vous puissiez nous voir et nous entendre)


Voici comment vos bonnes actions vous seront rendues décuplées:

Vous apporterez votre soutien à un spectacle fantastique et des artistes locaux
Considérez cela comme votre bonne action de la journée
Choisissez parmi les autres avantages intéressants et amusants qui s'offrent à vous

Et si nous n'atteignons pas notre objectif? Comme on dit, le spectacle doit continuer.
  The ImpactYour contribution will demonstrate the community's support of the arts and of its local storytellers.  Not to mention encouraging a higher standard for creative theatre experiences.L'Impact
Votre contribution témoignera du soutien apporté par la communauté aux arts et à ses conteurs d'histoires locaux. Sans compter le fait d'encourager un niveau supérieur de créativité théâtrale.
  Risks & Challenges  We're dealing with mature and graphic themes, challenging people's expectations and comfort zones.  We're taking the risk to make innovative and daring theatre.  With a passionate and dedicated team, we've already trouble-shooted our production process and come up with solutions as the journey takes us further into heaven (or down into hell).  Now all that's left is a little help from our friends ($$$).

Risques & Défis
Nous abordons des thèmes sérieux et graphiques tout en remettant en question les attentes du public et sa zone de confort. Nous prenons le risque de produire un théâtre innovant et audacieux. Avec notre équipe passionnée et dévouée, nous avons déjà analysé en profondeur notre processus de production et avons élaboré des solutions à mesure que ce voyage nous emmène plus loin vers le Ciel (ou en Enfer). Maintenant, tout ce dont nous avons besoin, c'est d'un peu d'aide de la part de nos amis ($$$).

  Other Ways You Can Help Don't have two pennies to rub together?  We still want your support!
You can:

SPREAD THE WORD
SHARE and TWEET our indiegogo campaign on social media
And if you're in the area and want to lend a helping hand, we could always use a couple VOLUNTEERS!  Just email Katherine (one of our co-producers) at agnesofgodmtl@gmail.com!


D'autres façons de nous aider

Vous n'avez pas un sous? Nous voulons quand même votre soutien! 
Vous pouvez:

PASSER LE MOT
PARTAGER et TWEETER notre campagne indiegogo sur les médias sociaux

Et
 si vous êtes dans le coin et souhaitez donner un coup de main, nous 
pourrions avoir besoin de BENEVOLES! Il vous suffit d'envoyer un email à
 Katherine (l'un de nos co-producteurs) à l'adresse 
agnesofgodmtl@gmail.com!

story:
Short Summary

Better Angels: A Parable will be my third professional production since 'Eating Pomegranates Naked' debuted at SummerWorks in 2013.

  • Better Angels: A Parable is about a young woman from Ghana who moves to Canada to work for a young couple as a domestic only to find herself trapped in an untenable situation. Unbeknownst to them she, too, isn't what she presents herself to be.
  • Modern Day Slavery affects almost 21 million people in the world and Canada is not exempt.http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/toronto-a-hub-for-human-trafficking-report-says-1.2675941 
  • SummerWorks is one of the most prestigious juried festivals in the country and being accepted for the second time on their 25th anniversary is humbling.
  • By supporting this project you will be helping to compensate the artists behind the words, remind people of a pressing, insidious problem around the world and investing in the future of theatre.

WHAT ARE MY INTENTIONS:

  • $10, 000 is a lot of money.  $10, 000 for Better Angels: A Parable is to cover the cost of 3 actors, the director, stage manager, lighting designer, sound designer, costume/set designer and producer. I will need these amazing people for 5 weeks but I can't pay them what they deserve so each will get a honorarium plus a cut of the box office at the completion of the show. 
  • The remaining costs are in paying for rehearsal space, costumes, set, advertising and insurance coverage. As the producer I have to remove my writer hat and put on the bookeepers' chapeau to make this all work.
  • I can't give you a tote bag or a cd of my favourite songs if you help me. All I can give you is myself and the chance to share an experience with me. I'll take you to TIFF, HotDocs, make you a lunch so you don't have to eat at the food court one day...I'll even bake you cookies. I won't give you stuff, I'll give you experiences.
  • I am not entirely relying on you for capital since I am aware that a diversification of funds is the smart route. I will have a fundraiser, bug my family for support and sell ads in my programs; one should know not put all their eggs in one basket.

The Impact

Even though this play functions within the realm of Fairy Tale I hope it will make people look a little closer into the eyes of the people around them: suffering is closer than we know.

  • With 'Eating Pomegranates Naked' I had strangers opening up to me about their fertility issues, marriage problems and fears they didn't know others experienced. I have already had people share their horror stories about loved ones trapped in situations much like Akosua's in Better Angels: A Parable, proving that these crimes are happening around us.
  • This will be my 3rd Indiegogo campaign. The first two were instrumental in helping me pay my actors and present my stories.

Risks & Challenges

 If I cannot raise the $10,000 for a full production the actors and crew still get paid. I will not take a paycheque since I am doing this for love and we'll design a play that could be done with a bare stage and a naked light-bulb.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help me with my play by talking about it. Let the better angels of your nature guide you and I will be forever grateful.

     

.

story:
In Rooms Such As These is a dark comedy about fucking and fucking-up. When Maggie suddenly finds herself without an apartment in New York City, she crashes from room to room, testing the realities of friendship, relationships, and having a room of one's own. Presented in association with Columbia University School of the Arts, Written by Dianne Nora, Directed by Mikhaela Mahony and Produced by Aisling Murray.


Tickets to the performances are free and that's why we need to raise as much funding as possible in order to cover the costs of set, costume and stipends.

Featuring dramaturgy by Cameron Jefts, stage management by Mary Linehan, and original designs by Colm McNally, Mark Van Hare, Sarah Abigail Hoke-Brady, and Audrey Nauman.

In Rooms Such as These will be performed at The Ford Studio at Signature Theatre for three performances only:

Wednesday, May 6th at 2:30pm

Friday, May 8th at 8:00pm

Saturday, May 9th at 2:30pm

Tickets are FREE and can be reserved online at www.bit.ly/DianneNora

Playwright mentor: Tracy Letts

Featuring performances by:

Brittany Allen

Emily Gardner Hall*

Dylan Lamb

Kyle Leibovitch

Erin E. McGuff

Brielle Silvestri*

*appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association

story:
What is [redacted]?

[redacted] Theater Company is a theater collective based in Philadelphia. The group is composed not just of performers, but painters, musicians, writers, choreographers, and composers. We create ambitious performances through collaboration, and through the juxtaposition of many art forms and many brains. We are a motley group, and we’re staunchly proud of that.

Previous performances in and around Philadelphia include Juniper Street: A Sleepover Play in the 2014 fringe/fringe Festival, Earnestness #2 in the 2014 SoLow Festival, created and performed by Co-Artistic Director Joshua McLucas, XY Scheherazade in the 2013 Fringe Festival, created and performed by Co-Artistic Director Swift Shuker and Founding Member Meryl Sands, as well as Lex & Goldaline at Swarthmore College, directed by Swift Shuker and starring Founding Member Naia Poyer.

More information can be found at redactedtheater.org, on twitter @redactedtheater, and on Facebook at facebook.com/redactedtheater.


What is This Damned Body is Carved Out of Meat?

This Damned Body is a two-year, exhaustive archive of transgender performer Swift Shuker's transition from a male body to an androgynous body. It is made of two components, the Living Archive of Transformation, an online portal where every second of the process is documented, and a series of live performances exploring the problems of embodiment through allegory. This Damned Body is Carved Out of Meat is the first of these performances. We began workshopping it in December 2014.

Carved Out Of Meat is the story of two lonely bodies falling in love with each others' ugliness. MichiganAngel77 is a young trans woman in an unfriendly corner of the world. Amber is older, an ascetic, living in a tiny world, confined by the walls of an apartment, but that world is teeming with magical life. They find each other and Amber invites MichiganAngel77 to live with her. This is their first night together, lovers who have never breathed the same air, both hoping to find, in each other, the answer to one final question. How can body and soul be one?

In addition to the live production, we will be converting the show to an album available for download featuring the text (by Swift Shuker and Naia Poyer) and music (by Alec MacLaughlin) so This Damned Body is Carved Out of Meat can live forever and transcend geography.

Check out thisdamnedbody.com to explore the Living Archive of Transformation. And keep a close watch, because it too is changing.

This Damned Body is Carved Out of Meat. We will not be saved.


Why we need your money

[redacted] believes in accessibility and in full theatrical experiences. We've already booked an incredible space at the MAAS Building in Philadelphia, but we need more assistance to fill it with performers and production elements.  If you choose to donate to us, here’s how we’re going to use your money.

$250 - Transportation. Some of our performers will be living in NYC this summer, and we rehearse in the Philadelphia area on the weekends. Moving the performers from city to city is critical.

$600 - Technical requirements. In order to make the space as intimate as we desire, we need some money for set pieces, lights, and sound equipment. 

$150 -  Publicity. Theater doesn’t exist without an audience, so some of the money will go to getting the word out about the production.

Total - $1000

We’ve been very lucky to have support from the Swarthmore Project in Theater, which has given us free rehearsal space for the summer, and the Philadelphia Cultural Fund, which has paid for our rehearsal space. They got the ball rolling and we’re looking to you to help us keep it moving. If you don't feel like you can give money, please share this campaign on any and all social media platforms and spread the word about the performance.


What is fringe/fringe?

fringe/fringe is a festival created by [redacted] in partnership with other Philadelphia-area artists to provide a low-cost, low-stress platform for creating work around the time of the Philadelphia FringeArts Festival. We charge no registration fee, and shows are promoted equally within the festival. fringe/fringe debuted last year, and hopefully remains a precursor to the FringeArts Festival for many years to come.

story:
Our Story

We are a collection of Los Angeles actors (As well as actors from across the nation) performing William Shakespeare's plays with no more than 7 days of rehearsals. Performances are FREE to the public and are performed in locations all throughout Los Angeles. Our current project, The Tempest which will be performed on November 18th, 2012.

 

The Impact

Our goal is to create quality, ensemble productions of Shakespeare's work that are unique and inventive for the Los Angeles public. Audiences are encouraged to bring picnic fixings and relax while watching a free performance.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $500 for rehearsal space, props, and coffee/lemonade for audiences the day of performance. Help us create a fun, new, and free theatrical opportunity!

 

Can't donate? No worries!

Please help us get the word out by tweeting our Indiegogo page or posting it onto to Facebook. Also, "like" our page at http://www.facebook.com/SevenDayShakespeareLosAngeles

story:
Short Summary

DoingSome Theatre is an emerging London theatre company comprised of graduates from the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama, which aims to push the boundaries of theatre.

Our debut show 'Exposure' explores the idea of superstition; its genesis, its effects, and the question of 'what if?' This performance will be constructed and framed by photography; in both the rehearsal process and the live event. We will examine people's representations, and what they choose to capture; to discover what is lost or gained in translation.

We are campaigning to raise funds for our production which will be performed as part of the Camden Fringe Festival. Our project is important to us as we are taking our first steps into the challenging and exciting field of experimental theatre and you can be a part of that process!

Without your contributions we would not be able to realise our debut production and any support we receive is greatly appreciated!

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise £600 to fund our venue costs as well as our equipment and costume costs.

So far we have held three bake sales at our university to fund our fees to enter the festival, and now we are reaching further afield to fund our production costs.

We are also holding a fundraising event with live music, a photobooth, homemade baked goods, and a raffle to both raise funds, and awareness for the project.

By donating on our indiegogo page you will receive exclusive benefits as detailed in our 'perks' section!

 

 

The Impact

This project gives contributors the opportunity to be a part of a new, exciting and experimental form of theatre that we are passionate about, and the production will play a valuable part in the Camden Fringe Festival. 

This project ensures that we will be able to carry our successful theatre making from a university setting to the world of professional theatre, something which is daunting, but also bold and exciting! 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you can't help us out financially! You can still help out by promoting and sharing our facebook and twitter pages and sharing our indiegogo page!

 

Twitter: @DoingSomeT

Facebook: www.facebook.com/DoingSomeTheatre

story:
Dear Friends,


I knew when I heard my good friend Melanie Jane Parker read her compilation of short stories for the first time that I needed to use them to create a performance piece.  Her work is delicate, beautiful, violent, and full of movement. This production will be performed in a non-traditional space in Brooklyn combining art-installation, dance, theatre and literature in a unique and meaningful way that enhances the stories and continues to give them breath.

I am working with an amazing team of collaborators including Grace Courvoisier, Taylor Donofrio, Jonathan Cottle, Ryan Maeker, Chantel Pascente and Melanie Jane Parker

 

This piece has been on my mind for several years now and it is only now that I feel prepared to bring it to life.  Any assistance you can provide would be so appreciated as I embark on this very meaningful artistic journey.

 

Love,

 

Teff & The night-song and Te Ilum Family

 

We Can’t Do it Alone!

 

To bring this production to life we are working to raise $2,000. The money will be used to rent space, pay performer and designer stipends, and to create a visual landscape that tells the story of night-song in conversation with the movement of the performers.

                    

$20 pays for an evening of rehearsal

$100 pays for a costume

$500 pays for all the paint and lumber to build the set

$750 pays for the incredible sound package for our sound design

$1,000 pays for half of our performance space

 

Any donation of $100 or more automatically makes you eligible to join Te Ilum's Partner program should you choose to receive rewards!

 

Go to Te Ilum's website to read more about our partner program.

Every dollar we receive will be poured directly into the development of this piece, please help support emerging artists to create new and exciting theatre.

 

 

Other Ways to Get Involved 

We are always in need of volunteers willing to dedicate their time and services. If you have a skill or interest that you think would be of use we would love to hear about it. We always need people to help with events and front of house positions at productions. Please email us at info@teilum.org.

story:
Who Are We? (The Active Theater, that's who!)

     We're an Off-Off-Broadway company made up of a volunteer staff of 12 who are working our asses off to make this world a better place.  We do that by making theater.  Add in our collaborations with our charity partners, the tickets we give away to senior and school groups in our community, and our free workshop series - and you get a pretty good idea of how we like to roll.  


The Violet Hour

     The Violet Hour asks if you would have the courage, when surrounded by fear and uncertainty, to grab the reigns and lead your life in the direction of your dreams.  This is a play that examines the impact we all have on the world around us.  It's beautifully written, funny and heart-wrenching, and leaves you caring deeply about what will happen to every one of the characters.  
 
Culpability, desire, fate - these massive ideas converge in one small publishing office.


Why Us?

     The Violet Hour will kick off The Active Theater's 4th season of producing high quality contemporary American plays in New York City.  We do everything in our power to make sure our audiences have a phenomenal theatrical experience from top to tail.  We want you leave the theatre talking about what you saw - something that touched you, something that surprised you, something that outraged you, something that moved you.  We're telling human stories, encouraging human dialogue, and promoting a more humane world.  

 

Here are a couple examples of the buzz from our past productions:

 
  • "they are...producing work that gets an audience talking."  BroadwayWorld.com
  • "Wait until you see it, and you will witness comic hilarity at its ï¬nest."  CultureCatch.com
  • "For a company that ï¬lls the role of the ‘new kid' on the Indie Theatre scene, The Active Theater may move to the head of the class very quickly. It's always good to see a group out there that promotes the fact that theatre can ignite cultural discourse, and it's high time for a fresh new 'Active' group with a serious voice. All that's left is for us to listen.”  BroadwayWorld.com

 

 
 

What we're trying to do...

     For this production, we're constructing a beautiful office, clothing 5 characters from 1919, and building a paper-spewing machine.  Technically, this production is more expensive than any show we have done, and beyond that we still have to pay for the space, scripts, marketing, actor and production team stipends, etc.  Plus, because of the demands of our absolutely fantastic set design - we're having to hire out construction to a shop for the first time ever.  We have raised most of our budget, but are trying to gather the last $7,500 to ensure that, as we raise the bar in certain areas of production, we won't have to cut corners in others.  
 
     To that end, we are asking for your help! 
 
     Whether you can give $3, $225, or $1312, any contribution will make a difference for us as we strive to make this production the best one yet.  We have put our creative hats on to come up with what we hope will be quirky and enticing perks that will put a smile on your face.  They represent our attempt to say, from the very bottom of our collective Active hearts, thank you for helping us continue to do what we do.  
 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Come see the show.  (It takes a little more effort on your end than online donation, but it's definitely worth it!)

  • Donating is extraordinary - but getting the word out is sensational, too!  Let your friends know about the show and how they can contribute to help make The Violet Hour a resounding success.  
               You can direct them to this page:  www.indiegogo.com/TheVioletHour
               Or have them check out our website directly:  www.theactivetheater.com
               How about our Facebook page: www.facebook.com/TheActiveTheater
 
 
  • And if you'd like to get involved and donate your time, we'd love to have you!  We're always in need of help for load-in and strike, as well as with the front of house during the run.  If you're interested, please contact us at virginia@theactivetheater.com.
 
 
 
Performance Schedule

          The Violet Hour
           by Richard Greenberg
           Directed by Nathaniel Shaw
 
          March 9-25
           The Workshop Theater
           312 W. 36th St., 4th Floor

story:
Language of Fish Collective Arts began as a four woman revolution.   We came together to co-create multi-medium performance work inspired by the dance in discovering the world in between our internal and external environments.

        

About Sticks & Stones, Cans and String

We can be like flowers

or roots of flowers

or seeds or weeds

or the animals who eat them.

We could be like the ground they grow in

or the bodies that lie underneath them

the water that feeds them and all the matter in between.

What are you in many numbers?

 

       Sticks & Stones, Cans and String will be performed August 21-24 at 12pm.  Meet at the Children's Fishing Pond at Canyon and 6th streets.  You will be led down the inner walking trail towards Eben G Fine Park. Bodies of water, bodies in water, string cocoons, voices and violin accompany the way. There are no physical tickets, just show up or RSVP to languageoffish@gmail.com.

       

        For this project we have invited 10 women to be a part of creating dance, music and architectural poetry in relation to the water, trees, and stones of the Boulder Creek.

         We came to the creek with our own images and ideas of how we saw ourselves there. Our minds were soon silenced by the rush of the water and the wind.  We let the environment tell us what was needed. We responded in the language of dance, music, poetry and visual structures.

         After the performances are over, a dance for camera adaptation will be filmed to keep the experience alive. 

         If this work resonates with you, please make a contribution.  If you are unable to be at the live performance, dvd copies of our film will be available.

 

What We Need

 We need to raise $700 to cover our costs and thank our contributing members. The $700 covers the bare minimum.  Please help us exceed our goal to help fund future projects! Consider this your annual donation to LOFCA! $10 is great contribution.

                                                   Budget


                           Costumes                          --  $100

                           Props                                 --  $200

                           Tea Party for Audience     --  $70

                           Promotional Materials      --   $170

                           Thank you to cast & crew --  $ 160

                                       TOTAL-- $ 700

\

                                      

 

What You Get

A donation is your ticket to this experiential performance.  You are again thanked with a myriad of gifts to choose from. See sidebar!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Share our video!  Come see the performance!  Donate red string for our installations!  Donate fruit or nuts for our audience tea party! Donate the use of a massage table to help carry out one of our perks!

story:
WELCOME!

Hi! We are so pleased that you are here, and hope that you will get involved with What I'm Failing To Learn.  Your donations will help us mount this initial workshop production of What I'm Failing To Learn, AND will pave the way for taking the show beyond this small workshop to the next level!


While we call this workshop "small" because it is a workshop, don't be fooled... We are staging a rich and intense experience, a journey... full of exciting live original music, multimedia, wonderful characters and world class percussive dance. Coming from the unique perspective of a young teen, yet universal in its message, we believe that the music, the characters and the story will strike a chord with many people.  This is the alternative to the manufactured image of American youth, it's gritty, funny, joyful, sad, hopeful, poignant, thoughtful, compassionate, complicated and REAL. Schuyler brings people together, she makes you feel good, and she makes you think...

 

“My first experience of hearing Schuyler (Skye) Iona Press sing was one of those moments [being in the presence of greatness] and inspired me to share my appreciation for her remarkable talent.” – Rebekah Blu, Avalon Magazine Spring 2012

 

THE SHOW

14-year-old singer songwriter Schuyler Iona Press, whose eclectic compositions include influences from modern folk, rock, and punk peppered with Latin grooves, is an outsider longing to be on the “inside”, yet simultaneously outraged by the implications of that — she's a kid entering adolescence and questioning her world. Accompanied by a live band, percussive modern Irish dancers and video, Schuyler brings us on a poetic imaginative quest into the depths of her emotions.

A mashup of theatrical drama/live concert/multimedia video, What I’m Failing To Learn takes us on a walking tour through the unpredictable streets of NYC and through the even more unpredictable mind of a young teenager.

What I’m Failing to Learn is a personal journey of a child colored by both positives and negatives of growing up unsheltered from certain truths of our human world.  As Schuyler learns, truth holds both comedy and tragedy, but most importantly, truth holds hope. 

WHERE YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS GO

Your donations will help us cover some of the costs of staging this workshop production of "What I'm Failing To Learn." (anything generously donated above our goal will be valuable to us and go to good use for show expenses and recording the cast album)

Your contributions will go to:

1. Audio and visual equipment used in the show: Sound system, projector, screen

2. Compensating our musicians, dancers, arranger and theater staff (producers, writers and directors are donating their services to this project)

3. Rehearsal space

4. Printed materials for the show

5. Purchase of Marley dance floor

THE I AM TODAY PROJECT

This workshop production will also help us raise awareness and support for the I AM TODAY PROJECT.

THE I AM TODAY PROJECT is inspired by the song I AM TODAY, written by Schuyler at age nine and recorded by her at age ten. Schuyler wrote the song as a gift and it was her desire to use the song to raise money for pediatric cancer research.  'I am Today' has been on Itunes doing just this, but now Schuyler (and we) want to take it to another level.  The I AM TODAY PROJECT pairs children and teens in various at-risk situations (coping with life threatening and chronic illnesses, economic and social disadvantages, young victims of disasters and wars) with a mentor in the the arts.  Together with the guidance, friendship and support of his or her mentor, each child imagines and creates a personal and meaningful piece of art (poem, song, play, film, painting, etc.) The experience enriches the lives of the child, their loved ones, their mentor and many others who are able to witness the final creation.  The I AM TODAY PROJECT empowers young people with a creative ‘voice’ that tells their story, which in turn enriches the world.  Through creativity, young people learn to view their world with a sensitive eye and see themselves as important participants in making a positive impact.  Adults have much to learn from listening to the voices of these young people whose life experiences have given them unique perspective and understanding.  The children also gain practical skills by conceiving a vision, working with a partner and seeing a project through to finish.  The I AM TODAY PROJECT aims to expose young people, and the adults who care for and about them, to the healing and life affirming power of creativity and to help them understand and exert their own important "voice."  The final works of art will also serve as a means of promoting understanding, peace, hope, positive communication and purpose for our young mentees and those many people who are and will be affected by them.  Positve Creativity can heal our world! 

THE TEAM

SCHUYLER IONA PRESS (Music, Lyrics, Performer) is a 14-year old singer/songwriter guitarist and actress from NYC.  She is the youngest artist ever to play the singer/songwriter sessions at the Bitter End in NYC and has played numerous music festivals in the northeast throughout the summer of 2012 including Boston GreenFest, Block Island Music Festival, Black Pottoe Music Festival and more.

A prolific songwriter from an early age, at 12 years old Schuyler opened for award winning recording artist Ellis Paul. Schuyler composed the score to the independent feature film “Theresa is a Mother,” including recording “Summer Child” the main theme song. "Theresa is a Mother" is currently playing in film festivals around the country and has won numerous Best Film awards. Schuyler recently recorded a guitar/vocal for the music video to her 9/11 tribute song “Playground Museum.” This video premiered at the 2012 International Film Festival Manhattan and won in the music video category at the 2012 My HERO Film Festival in LA.  Schuyler was also nominated for a prestigious Ron Kovic Peace Prize.

PLAYGROUND MUSEUM VIDEO:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lMm6wL9uZ-Q

As an actress, Schuyler was nominated for a Best Supporting Actress Award from the 2012 Reel Independent Film Festival in Washington DC for her role in the film "Theresa is a Mother".

A budding philanthropist, Schuyler is combining her talents and passions to create the I AM TODAY PROJECT, an arts driven organization that works with children fighting serious illness and facing soical and economic difficulties, helping them create personal and expressive projects in various artistic disciplines.

C. FRASER PRESS (writer, co-director) An Emmy nominated actress and writer, C. Fraser Press began her professional career with the famed LaMama Theatre company in New York City where she performed in Andre Serban’s Fragments Of A Greek Trilogy both in NYC and on tour in the Middle East. She continued to act in theater in both Los Angeles and New York City. On stage nationally and on network and cable television, she has performed improvisation and stand-up comedy as well as three critically acclaimed one-woman shows. As a writer/director, her first film, the short, A Driving Lesson, was an official selection to over 30 film festivals worldwide and was nominated for and won numerous awards including the  Lou Costello Comedy award at the Garden State Film Festival.  A Driving Lesson was also part of GlamourFilmFest.tv Glamour Magazine’s online film festival. Glamourfilmfest selects the best shorts by female directors chosen by Hollywood insiders. C. Fraser wrote, co-directed and starred in the award winning feature film Theresa is a Mother. Press received ‘Best Actress’, ‘Best Screenplay’ and Best Director’ awards for her work on Theresa is a Mother. She is currently working on two new feature film scripts and a television pilot.

DARREN PRESS (co-director, producer) Darren began writing, directing and producing in New York City’s off-off Broadway theater scene. Quickly moving to larger projects Off Broadway, Darren became the Managing Director of the Melting Pot Theatre Company, producing the highly acclaimed Outer Critics Circle Award nominee Woody Guthrie’s American Song and the Drama Desk Award winning Lee Blessing play Cobb, co-produced with Kevin Spacey. He produced the short film, A Driving Lesson, which was an official selection to over 30 film festivals and winner of numerous best short and comedy short categories including the Lou Costello Award at the Garden State Film Festival. With his wife, C. Fraser Press, Darren co-directed and produced the feature film Theresa is a Mother which is currently on the festival circuit and has already garnered many accolades, including Best Film awards from the Orlando Film Festival (including Best Director), International Film Festival Manhattan, and Reel Independent Film Extravaganza. Darren’s theatre directing credits include the critically acclaimed play Why We Don’t Bomb the Amish (St. Marks Studio Theatre, Gershwin Hotel); Checkpoint (Kraine Theatre, NYC); and Succulent (Pulse Ensemble Theatre, NYC). Darren has also won awards for video and commercial direction for the United Way and the prestigious Dalton Pen Award for writing.

JOEL HANNA (Choreographer, dancer) is known for his athletic and boundary-breaking fusion of tap dance, musical percussion, Irish dance, and martial arts Joel Hanna has been called “one of the most exciting dancers to ever step on the World stage”.

Joel began his training at age 9 in Vancouver, B.C., achieving competitive success all over the world. Joel’s professional career took off after joining Riverdance: The Show in 1997, performing throughout Britain and North America. During this time he was selected to be the subject of a documentary, produced by CBC/Riverdance, called "The Badboy and the Hometown Girl", which is still broadcast today.

He has taught and choreographed award-winning pieces for schools and professional dance companies all over North and South America. His innovative style of teaching and performing has been sought-after all over the world, from Mexico City to as far North as Juneau, Alaska, and from Singapore to Warsaw, London and back! Joel also spent the summer of 2008 touring as Lead Tap Soloist in a UK tour of Magic of the Dance.

In 2007 Joel created Revolution: Sweat, Dance, Rock & Roll, which debuted in New York City at the world-famous Joyce Theater during its 25th anniversary season in Oct. 07'. Following the phenomenal success of its run, the production (partnered with Columbia Artists Management Inc. or "CAMI") performed a national tour sponsored by Gibson Guitars.

Recently, Joel performed for the delegates at the United Nations, opening the World Youth Assembly. He has performed as a soloist at the Jacob's Pillow Concert Series two years in a row, and has appeared with Grammy Award Nominee Dave Eggar at Lincoln Center in New York City. He will be seen choreographing in an upcoming Cirque du Soleil.


JEB PATTON (Music Arrangement) graduated magna cum laude with a Bachelor of Arts and Sciences degree with a major in music from Duke University, where he studied piano with Tibor Szasz, Douglas Buys, and Jane Hawkins. As a member of the Duke Jazz Ensemble under Paul Jeffrey, he performed with and/or arranged for more than 60 professional jazz artists, including 48 musicians from New York and more than 12 international jazz musicians from Italy, Monaco, and Portugal.

Studying under Sir Roland Hanna and Jimmy Heath, Jeb earned his Master of Arts degree, summa cum laude, in 1997 from the Aaron Copland School of Music, Queens College, City University of New York, where he also received the Louis Armstrong Award for composition from the ASCAP Foundation.

Major national and international festival appearances with the Heath Brothers include Savannah Music Festival, New Orleans Jazz and Heritage, Newport (Rhode Island). Career highlights include Opening Nights of Jazz at Lincoln Center, performing with Antonio Hart at the Kennedy Center.

A MAY SKY PICTURE ENTERTAINMENT

A MAY SKY PICTURE ENTERTAINMENT (AMSPE) is an entertainment production company founded by writers, producers and directors C. Fraser Press and Darren Press.  AMSPE’s first project was the short film A Driving Lesson – featured in over 30 film festivals worldwide and nominated for and winner of numerous film festival awards. A Driving Lesson was also a Glamour Magazine web film series official selection, which screened short films from up and coming female directors.

AMSPE’s latest project is the upcoming feature film Theresa is a Mother starring Edie McClurg, Matthew Gumley, and C. Fraser Press. Currently on the festival circuit, Theresa Is A Mother has already garnered many awards including Best Feature Film and Best Director, Orlando Film Festival; Best Feature Film and Best Actress, The Reel Independent Film Festival Washington DC; Best Feature Film; International Film Festival Manhattan; Best Screenplay and Best Actor, NYC Independent Film Festival.

AMSPE’s first music video, Playground Museum by Schuyler Iona Press, was screened at various film festivals and was a winner at the MY HERO film festival.

AMSPE is focused on developing artist-driven material for the Film, TV, Web, Live Entertainment and Music industries. A May Sky Picture Entertainment aims to bring arts and entertainment projects to the public that inspire, provoke thought and foster cross-racial, cross-cultural and cross-generational dialogue and shared experience.

A May Sky Picture Entertainment Youth Education Initiatives

MAY SKY MENTORS

In an effort to honor the natural and necessary relationship between positive artistic contribution and positive social contribution, A May Sky Picture Entertainment utilizes the process of development and production of their live and filmed performing arts as living classrooms in which youth from diverse backgrounds are paired with artist mentors.

THE MAD INITIATIVE

A May Sky Picture Entertainment developed the MAD (Make A Difference) Initiative in order to foster a new generation of social entrepreneurs.  The Mad Initiative is a full curriculum geared towards Middle School and High School students.  Through a series of creative exercises and hands on projects students are challenged to think as social entrepreneurs, critically examining their world, their place in it, and their personal ability to make a positive difference with their lives and their career choices.  While fostering social consciousness and responsibility as well as skills of positive teamwork, problem solving and creativity, students ultimately develop their own “businesses” or non-profits and become social entrepreneurs.

The MAD Initiative workshops have been run privately in the Hudson Valley and through the organization Girls, Inc. in New York City.

 

STERN DESIGN WORKS (Check out the perks):

Stern Design Works was founded by husband and wife team Cameron and Rebecca Stern in 2007.

"Playing with our own obsessions we create a constantly evolving assortment of scientifically, historically, and intelligently designed collections using a mix of traditional metalsmithing techniques and modern technology."

If you choose a perk with a piece of jewerly from Stern Design Works you can expect a high end, one of a kind amazing piece of wearable art.  Every piece of aesthetically stunning jewelry created by these exceptional artists is a conversation piece.

See some examples of their amazing work:

http://sterndesignworks.com/

https://www.facebook.com/SternDesignWorks
