Schuyler wrote the song as a gift and it was her desire to use the song to raise money for pediatric cancer research.  'I am Today' has been on Itunes doing just this, but now Schuyler (and we) want to take it to another level.  The I AM TODAY PROJECT pairs children and teens in various at-risk situations (coping with life threatening and chronic illnesses, economic and social disadvantages, young victims of disasters and wars) with a mentor in the the arts.  Together with the guidance, friendship and support of his or her mentor, each child imagines and creates a personal and meaningful piece of art (poem, song, play, film, painting, etc.) The experience enriches the lives of the child, their loved ones, their mentor and many others who are able to witness the final creation.  The I AM TODAY PROJECT empowers young people with a creative ‘voice’ that tells their story, which in turn enriches the world.  Through creativity, young people learn to view their world with a sensitive eye and see themselves as important participants in making a positive impact.  Adults have much to learn from listening to the voices of these young people whose life experiences have given them unique perspective and understanding.  The children also gain practical skills by conceiving a vision, working with a partner and seeing a project through to finish.  The I AM TODAY PROJECT aims to expose young people, and the adults who care for and about them, to the healing and life affirming power of creativity and to help them understand and exert their own important "voice."  The final works of art will also serve as a means of promoting understanding, peace, hope, positive communication and purpose for our young mentees and those many people who are and will be affected by them.  Positve Creativity can heal our world! 
THE TEAM
SCHUYLER IONA PRESS (Music, Lyrics, Performer) is a 14-year old singer/songwriter guitarist and actress from NYC.  She is the youngest artist ever to play the singer/songwriter sessions at the Bitter End in NYC and has played numerous music festivals in the northeast throughout the summer of 2012 including Boston GreenFest, Block Island Music Festival, Black Pottoe Music Festival and more.
A prolific songwriter from an early age, at 12 years old Schuyler opened for award winning recording artist Ellis Paul. Schuyler composed the score to the independent feature film “Theresa is a Mother,” including recording “Summer Child” the main theme song. "Theresa is a Mother" is currently playing in film festivals around the country and has won numerous Best Film awards. Schuyler recently recorded a guitar/vocal for the music video to her 9/11 tribute song “Playground Museum.” This video premiered at the 2012 International Film Festival Manhattan and won in the music video category at the 2012 My HERO Film Festival in LA.  Schuyler was also nominated for a prestigious Ron Kovic Peace Prize.
PLAYGROUND MUSEUM VIDEO:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lMm6wL9uZ-Q
As an actress, Schuyler was nominated for a Best Supporting Actress Award from the 2012 Reel Independent Film Festival in Washington DC for her role in the film "Theresa is a Mother".
A budding philanthropist, Schuyler is combining her talents and passions to create the I AM TODAY PROJECT, an arts driven organization that works with children fighting serious illness and facing soical and economic difficulties, helping them create personal and expressive projects in various artistic disciplines.
C. FRASER PRESS (writer, co-director) An Emmy nominated actress and writer, C. Fraser Press began her professional career with the famed LaMama Theatre company in New York City where she performed in Andre Serban’s Fragments Of A Greek Trilogy both in NYC and on tour in the Middle East. She continued to act in theater in both Los Angeles and New York City. On stage nationally and on network and cable television, she has performed improvisation and stand-up comedy as well as three critically acclaimed one-woman shows. As a writer/director, her first film, the short, A Driving Lesson, was an official selection to over 30 film festivals worldwide and was nominated for and won numerous awards including the  Lou Costello Comedy award at the Garden State Film Festival.  A Driving Lesson was also part of GlamourFilmFest.tv Glamour Magazine’s online film festival. Glamourfilmfest selects the best shorts by female directors chosen by Hollywood insiders. C. Fraser wrote, co-directed and starred in the award winning feature film Theresa is a Mother. Press received ‘Best Actress’, ‘Best Screenplay’ and Best Director’ awards for her work on Theresa is a Mother. She is currently working on two new feature film scripts and a television pilot.
DARREN PRESS (co-director, producer) Darren began writing, directing and producing in New York City’s off-off Broadway theater scene. Quickly moving to larger projects Off Broadway, Darren became the Managing Director of the Melting Pot Theatre Company, producing the highly acclaimed Outer Critics Circle Award nominee Woody Guthrie’s American Song and the Drama Desk Award winning Lee Blessing play Cobb, co-produced with Kevin Spacey. He produced the short film, A Driving Lesson, which was an official selection to over 30 film festivals and winner of numerous best short and comedy short categories including the Lou Costello Award at the Garden State Film Festival. With his wife, C. Fraser Press, Darren co-directed and produced the feature film Theresa is a Mother which is currently on the festival circuit and has already garnered many accolades, including Best Film awards from the Orlando Film Festival (including Best Director), International Film Festival Manhattan, and Reel Independent Film Extravaganza. Darren’s theatre directing credits include the critically acclaimed play Why We Don’t Bomb the Amish (St. Marks Studio Theatre, Gershwin Hotel); Checkpoint (Kraine Theatre, NYC); and Succulent (Pulse Ensemble Theatre, NYC). Darren has also won awards for video and commercial direction for the United Way and the prestigious Dalton Pen Award for writing.
JOEL HANNA (Choreographer, dancer) is known for his athletic and boundary-breaking fusion of tap dance, musical percussion, Irish dance, and martial arts Joel Hanna has been called “one of the most exciting dancers to ever step on the World stage”.
Joel began his training at age 9 in Vancouver, B.C., achieving competitive success all over the world. Joel’s professional career took off after joining Riverdance: The Show in 1997, performing throughout Britain and North America. During this time he was selected to be the subject of a documentary, produced by CBC/Riverdance, called "The Badboy and the Hometown Girl", which is still broadcast today.
He has taught and choreographed award-winning pieces for schools and professional dance companies all over North and South America. His innovative style of teaching and performing has been sought-after all over the world, from Mexico City to as far North as Juneau, Alaska, and from Singapore to Warsaw, London and back! Joel also spent the summer of 2008 touring as Lead Tap Soloist in a UK tour of Magic of the Dance.
In 2007 Joel created Revolution: Sweat, Dance, Rock & Roll, which debuted in New York City at the world-famous Joyce Theater during its 25th anniversary season in Oct. 07'. Following the phenomenal success of its run, the production (partnered with Columbia Artists Management Inc. or "CAMI") performed a national tour sponsored by Gibson Guitars.
Recently, Joel performed for the delegates at the United Nations, opening the World Youth Assembly. He has performed as a soloist at the Jacob's Pillow Concert Series two years in a row, and has appeared with Grammy Award Nominee Dave Eggar at Lincoln Center in New York City. He will be seen choreographing in an upcoming Cirque du Soleil.
JEB PATTON (Music Arrangement) graduated magna cum laude with a Bachelor of Arts and Sciences degree with a major in music from Duke University, where he studied piano with Tibor Szasz, Douglas Buys, and Jane Hawkins. As a member of the Duke Jazz Ensemble under Paul Jeffrey, he performed with and/or arranged for more than 60 professional jazz artists, including 48 musicians from New York and more than 12 international jazz musicians from Italy, Monaco, and Portugal.
Studying under Sir Roland Hanna and Jimmy Heath, Jeb earned his Master of Arts degree, summa cum laude, in 1997 from the Aaron Copland School of Music, Queens College, City University of New York, where he also received the Louis Armstrong Award for composition from the ASCAP Foundation.
Major national and international festival appearances with the Heath Brothers include Savannah Music Festival, New Orleans Jazz and Heritage, Newport (Rhode Island). Career highlights include Opening Nights of Jazz at Lincoln Center, performing with Antonio Hart at the Kennedy Center.
A MAY SKY PICTURE ENTERTAINMENT
A MAY SKY PICTURE ENTERTAINMENT (AMSPE) is an entertainment production company founded by writers, producers and directors C. Fraser Press and Darren Press.  AMSPE’s first project was the short film A Driving Lesson – featured in over 30 film festivals worldwide and nominated for and winner of numerous film festival awards. A Driving Lesson was also a Glamour Magazine web film series official selection, which screened short films from up and coming female directors.
AMSPE’s latest project is the upcoming feature film Theresa is a Mother starring Edie McClurg, Matthew Gumley, and C. Fraser Press. Currently on the festival circuit, Theresa Is A Mother has already garnered many awards including Best Feature Film and Best Director, Orlando Film Festival; Best Feature Film and Best Actress, The Reel Independent Film Festival Washington DC; Best Feature Film; International Film Festival Manhattan; Best Screenplay and Best Actor, NYC Independent Film Festival.
AMSPE’s first music video, Playground Museum by Schuyler Iona Press, was screened at various film festivals and was a winner at the MY HERO film festival.
AMSPE is focused on developing artist-driven material for the Film, TV, Web, Live Entertainment and Music industries. A May Sky Picture Entertainment aims to bring arts and entertainment projects to the public that inspire, provoke thought and foster cross-racial, cross-cultural and cross-generational dialogue and shared experience.
A May Sky Picture Entertainment Youth Education Initiatives
MAY SKY MENTORS
In an effort to honor the natural and necessary relationship between positive artistic contribution and positive social contribution, A May Sky Picture Entertainment utilizes the process of development and production of their live and filmed performing arts as living classrooms in which youth from diverse backgrounds are paired with artist mentors.
THE MAD INITIATIVE
A May Sky Picture Entertainment developed the MAD (Make A Difference) Initiative in order to foster a new generation of social entrepreneurs.  The Mad Initiative is a full curriculum geared towards Middle School and High School students.  Through a series of creative exercises and hands on projects students are challenged to think as social entrepreneurs, critically examining their world, their place in it, and their personal ability to make a positive difference with their lives and their career choices.  While fostering social consciousness and responsibility as well as skills of positive teamwork, problem solving and creativity, students ultimately develop their own “businesses” or non-profits and become social entrepreneurs.
The MAD Initiative workshops have been run privately in the Hudson Valley and through the organization Girls, Inc. in New York City.
 
STERN DESIGN WORKS (Check out the perks):
Stern Design Works was founded by husband and wife team Cameron and Rebecca Stern in 2007.
"Playing with our own obsessions we create a constantly evolving assortment of scientifically, historically, and intelligently designed collections using a mix of traditional metalsmithing techniques and modern technology."
If you choose a perk with a piece of jewerly from Stern Design Works you can expect a high end, one of a kind amazing piece of wearable art.  Every piece of aesthetically stunning jewelry created by these exceptional artists is a conversation piece.
See some examples of their amazing work:
http://sterndesignworks.com/
https://www.facebook.com/SternDesignWorks

story:
The Play – Presented by Moyo Theatre in Association with GromKat Productions

 

Tainted  tells the story of the Steele family and their fight to stay intact when the unimaginable happens. Set against the backdrop of the devastating tainted blood crisis, Tainted is a story about love, grief, justice, and the enduring power of forgiveness.

 

Tainted will run from September 26th to October 12th at the new premier arts venue in Toronto, The Aki Studio Theatre, Daniels Spectrum. We have brought together a stellar cast and design team under the direction of multi-Dora-winning director Vikki Anderson.

 

Moyo Theatre’s Mandate

 

Moyo Theatre’s mandate is to present theatre with a fearless heart. We have come together to create Tainted as there is an immediate need for this story to be told.

We believe it is our obligation and our privilege to stand behind this story to ensure that the voices of the people who were so deeply affected by the tainted blood crisis continue to clamor. We believe that the truth must never be forgotten. We believe that one of the only ways to ensure catastrophes like the tainted blood crisis do not happen again is by creating a living testament to the real cost of this tragedy.

The funds we raise will go directly to the launch and costs of our Toronto production and will further our efforts in getting Tainted performed across the country as well as in the US and UK!

 

The True Story

The tainted blood crisis has spanned 30 years and infected over 30,000 Canadians of all ages and ethnicities with hepatitis C and HIV – many of those infections could have been prevented. It has wiped out almost an entire generation of hemophiliacs dependent on blood-clotting product to save them from life threatening bleeds. In the early '80s when HIV was a new blood-borne disease, the Red Cross, Health Canada and our government did not take the precautions necessary to protect the blood supply. Thousands of people were infected via blood transfusions. The effects were catastrophic.

Our government is paying out billions of dollars in compensation to those affected. But compensation and acknowledgment of government failings was hard won and it came at an incredible cost to Canadian families. Those infected lobbied for years in order to attain a public inquiry into how the system failed them. They struggled financially, emotionally, and physically trying to stay alive during the height of AIDS, when life-saving treatment was not available.  What many people don’t realize is that hemophilia is a disease inherited genetically. For many Canadian families the loss was compounded by losing more than one son (hemophilia usually occurs in males). Moreover, people who were exposed to tainted blood were often not informed for years. Many unknowingly passed on the diseases to their spouses and unborn children.

The Impact – The Urgency

In the federal inquiry into how our blood supply was contaminated, the legendary judge, Justice Krever recommended not to allow paid compensation for blood donation so as to ensure the future safety of the Canadian blood supply.

After millions of dollars has been spent creating a new and safe blood system it is now more crucial than ever for this story to be told. In the past, one of the reasons so much tainted blood was received was that it was purchased from the United States, who was sourcing it from paid-donor programs in prisons, skid rows, and neighbourhoods that attracted equally high-risk donors. A similar scenario is currently being proposed in Canada. In Toronto and Hamilton private collection clinics have already been set up - ready to open their doors to pay people for their plasma. One is beside a homeless shelter, another beside a methadone clinic. This has major implications for the safety of our blood supply and our voluntary system.

Our play shines light on the vital role we share in preventing tragedies like the tainted blood crisis from recurring. We must not make the same mistakes again.

Make sure this story is told! Make sure their voices are never forgotten.

Our deepest gratitude.

The Moyo Creative Team and GromKat Productions


Other ways you can help! Write your Federal MP and say no to paid-blood-donor clinics. You can also sign our online petition http://www.change.org/en-CA/petitions/health-canada-do-not-open-paid-blood-donor-clinics

 

We'd like to also give a special thank you to our friends at Sons & Daughters and Associated Producers for ensuring we had our video for our campaign!

 

Our Venue:

http://regentparkarts.ca/visit/

 

 

OUR CAST

story:
interCulture casting & management is the brain-child of respected actor, director & producer Michael Turkic and talented writer, media consultant and analyst William Uy Vu Le

Since 1981, Michael Turkic has been appeared in or directed some of the largest commercial stage productions in Australia. An original Australian cast member of the international hit, Les Miserables, Michael has since 1985 worked at the top of his profession. His credits as either actor and/or director include: Company (Sydney Theatre Company) Les Miserables (Cameron Mackintosh) Chess (Theatre Royal Sydney) The Secret Garden (State Theatre Sydney) Grease The Arena Spectacular, Tim Rice's Concert Spectacular, Happy Days The Mega Musical, as well as projects for ABC TV. He was a regular featured actor in the children;s TV series Ship To Shore as well as Andrew Denton's The Money Or The Gun. A respected educator, he has lectured at the National Institute of Dramatic Art, West Australian Academy Of Performing Arts, and the Central Queensland Conservatorium of Music.

 

William Uy Vu Le is a writer with extensive experience in film, television, literature and media, particularly in the Asia Pacific rim. He worked for Persuasive Networks in HK and specialised in content aggregation, planning, forecasting and social media. He assisted with market research, branding, scheduling, acquisitions and co-production of two luxury lifestyle and educational channels in Asia-Pacific Pay TV market.

He also was strategy advisor to the direction of a full-service digital media agency. He assisted with 360-degree video content management solutions (CMS), convergence technologies and distribution needs in multi-platform or IPTV products.

William is well connected to the Vietnamese community and to key demographics of Australia and as such brings a wealth of talent identification and credibility to the business.

What We Need & What You Get

interCulture casting & management is in the start-up phase. Australia has approximately 47% of its population from a non Anglo Saxon background. This is currently not represented in the main-stream media, on stage, or in the web space insofar as it emanates from this country. Our business will represent and market actors, singers, dancers, choreographers, presenters, spokespeople, models and skilled artists from the diasporas of Asia, The Middle East, Middle Europe, the sub-continent, Pacific Islands and beyond.

Our model is to not only divide the business into both casting for feature film, TV, stage, event, corporate training, single projects, festivals and the like, but also to represent and manage the careers of up and coming artists, and artists with promise whose current management is not adding value.

We need $15,000 to open the business and have the following infrastructure in place:

 

  • Website
  • Social Media
  • Team
  • Equipment
  • Office Space (Surry Hills, artistic hub of Sydney)
  • Business relationships
  • Customer Database
  • Venture Partners

 

The Impact

Like all start-ups we are rich in intellectual property, contacts, experience, and potential. We are the ONLY NON TRADITIONAL ENTERTAINMENT AGENCY currently in Australia and as such this gives us a unique selling proposotion and market advantage/position.

  • Help us create the first NON ANGLO SAXON ARTISTS AGENCY IN AUSTRALIA
  • Be part of one of the most progressive multi-cultural high visibility businesses yet conceived.
  • By assisting us in start up mode, you will have the pleasure and satisfaction of seeing the incremental change to the way Media progesses to a fully representational model of Australia's multicultural society.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us by talking about us, liking us on facebook, and sharing your enthusiasm!

Alternatively, make a contribution and receive attribution on our Facebook Page, and on our Website!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
The Show

Alice in Wonderland, based on the novels by Lewis Carroll, was originally adapted by André Gregory and the Manhattan Project in 1970. Lending itself to a six person cast, Wonderland is created through the use of comedy and the search for humanity behind Carroll's characters. Alice explores Wonderland as a young girl begging the question, "Who am I?" and matures as she encounters its inhabitants and grows to learn that Wonderland has its own shadows. 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding a project of this scale is no simple task! Financial support is a necessity in making the director's vision come to fruition and in publicizing this incredible show. Your donation OF ANY SIZE will go toward

  • Buying lumber, plywood, and paint to build our set
  • Purchasing clothing from thrift shops, rental stores, and consigment shops to dress our actors
  • Acquiring props from rental markets, thrift stores, and the like
  • Renting sound and lighting equipment
  • Advertising all around campus and the Chicagoland area

The Impact

Women are a large majority of the individual involved in theatre. However, their voices are not the majority voices - they are not an equal voice. The number of male roles are significantly higher than female roles. While Lipstick does not shy away from casting men in their shows, they make an honest effort to choose plays that showcase a larger number of the talented women at their disposal.


Thank you for giving me your time. Shows like ours and organizations like Lipstick Theatre would not be able to exist were it not for your kindness and encouragement to keep working. Spreading news of our show and goals by word of mouth and coming to see us Dec 5th-7th would be delightful! Please feel free to contact me with any questions you may have.

Wonderfully yours,
Aparna Ramachandran, Producer
story_txt:
The Show
Alice in Wonderland, based on the novels by Lewis Carroll, was originally adapted by André Gregory and the Manhattan Project in 1970. Lending itself to a six person cast, Wonderland is created through the use of comedy and the search for humanity behind Carroll's characters. Alice explores Wonderland as a young girl begging the question, "Who am I?" and matures as she encounters its inhabitants and grows to learn that Wonderland has its own shadows. 


What We Need & What You Get
Funding a project of this scale is no simple task! Financial support is a necessity in making the director's vision come to fruition and in publicizing this incredible show. Your donation OF ANY SIZE will go toward

Buying lumber, plywood, and paint to build our set
Purchasing clothing from thrift shops, rental stores, and consigment shops to dress our actors
Acquiring props from rental markets, thrift stores, and the like
Renting sound and lighting equipment
Advertising all around campus and the Chicagoland area



The Impact
Women are a large majority of the individual involved in theatre. However, their voices are not the majority voices - they are not an equal voice. The number of male roles are significantly higher than female roles. While Lipstick does not shy away from casting men in their shows, they make an honest effort to choose plays that showcase a larger number of the talented women at their disposal.



Thank you for giving me your time. Shows like ours and organizations like Lipstick Theatre would not be able to exist were it not for your kindness and encouragement to keep working. Spreading news of our show and goals by word of mouth and coming to see us Dec 5th-7th would be delightful! Please feel free to contact me with any questions you may have.

Wonderfully yours,
Aparna Ramachandran, Producer

story:
Our project- "Small Hours Serenade"

Laura Heikkinen is an emerging playwright in Detroit, MI and Puzzle Piece Theatre is producing her first full length play, "Small Hours Serenade" in the Spring of 2014.

Laura's first play, "Chiseled" was selected for inclusion in Wayne State University's Louise-Heck Rabi One Act Festival in March of 2013.

Puzzle Piece Theatre's mission is to serve the community through storytelling that re-imagines what is possible in live performance. Debuting in February 2013 the company is quickly earning acclaim in the Detroit Arts Community.

Opportunities for early career playwrights are vital for the future of the American Theatre and Puzzle Piece Theatre is pleased to bring Laura's voice into the mix.

How we will use your donation

We have a budget of just under $5,000 for most of our productions. The goal of this campaign is to raise one-tenth of our budget, $500, to be used as operating capital to get this project off the ground.

While producing on a shoestring budget, we pay all of our actors and creative team a stipend for their work. Your donation will be applied towards those stipends. The other major expense we have with each production is the technical elements: set, lights, etc. A portion of the funds raised will be used to purchase materials to be used with our existing technical pieces.

In addition to the satisfaction of launching a world premiere play, we have many exciting ways to share our thanks. Take a look at our perks where you can receive: an autographed copy of the play, tickets to a performance, recognition as the primary underwriter, and more. We are thankful for any support you can provide.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are excited about Laura's play and Puzzle Piece's work but unable to contribute financially please pass along our campaign. Through your word of mouth with social media we can expand our network of friends and continue to re-imagine what is possible in live performance.

www.puzzlestage.org

story:
Angry Women REvisited

Greetings! My name is J Dellecave and I am a Brooklyn-based performer, choreographer, scholar, and theater provocateur. My formal background is in dance, though I have been making experimental theater since choreographing jungle gym routines to Olivia Newton John songs (a long, long, long, long, long time ago). Since last May, I have had the utmost pleasure to work with the sublimely fantastic multi-ethnic, multi-generational, multi-disciplinary fifteen-person ensemble which has come together for this epic wild project. We have been examining the interviews of badass (and sometimes problematic) activists/artists of the 1990s, through the lens of 2014 ideas about feminism, and grounding our inquiry in the pages of the classic feminist text, REsearch Journal's Angry Women.

The performers/collaborators in the project are: Avi-Rose, Angela Beallor, Joshua Bastian Cole, Kate Conroy, Gaby Cryan, lizxnn disaster, Roo Khan, daniel rosza lang/levitsky, Sloan Lesbowitz, zavé martohardjono, niknaz, Azure D. Osborne-Lee, Jenny Romaine, Zachary Wager Scholl and Alma Sheppard-Matsuo, with textile construction by L.J. Roberts.

We are a queer cast of dancers, filmmakers, theatre makers, theatre scholars, visual artists, puppeteers, animators, musicians, writers, and rabble rousers, across a wide spectrum of genders. The opportunity to work through important ideas with such a diverse cast is a once in a lifetime opportunity. We were fortunate to be selected for a performance at HERE, 145 6th Avenue, in Manhattan, April 3-6, 2014. The cast of Angry Women REvisited wants to be able to share all of our work with you and our audience, in its fullest professional capacity, and for that we need the funds to support this project.

(This production is a part of SubletSeries@HERE, HERE’s curated rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support.) 

$$$$$$$$$

  • It is $2700 for us to rent the theater for our show. We have already spent $1500 on rehearsal space. The first $4200 raised as part of this campaign will go directly to cover these expenses. 
  • Need a tarot reading? An outfit consultation? Some leather working? A massage? Some fine-tuning on your website? Kombucha brewing? One of the most exciting perks offered for this fundraiser is the $100 FEMINIST SKILL SHARE. The skill shares offered exemplify the vast array of talents this very special cast has to offer. Our ensemble offered up an impressive and wide array of skills to benefit this production! I recommend scrolling down and checking it out, there are perks from the practical to the luxurious. You can check things off your to-do list and support an artistic endeavor all-in-one! We offer various modalities of somatic and bodily practices, knitting and sewing lessons, dramaturgy (drool, drool), editing, illustration, baked goods, fundraising consultation, and lots more!!! 
  • Beyond the initial $4200, we are seeking professional services to support the exciting multi-disciplinary work that we have created. We want all of our hard work to be fully realized and documented professionally. Donate at the $200 level and sponsor a support service for our performance directly. Professional videography and photography will benefit each and every cast member when we further our professional and artistic project portfolios after the show. 
  • Every dollars counts--$1, $5, $10, $20, bring it on!!

Our Footprints

In the early 1990s, when I was an angry, queer, feminist youngster, my encounters with the book Angry Women profoundly shaped my sense of possibilities for making dynamic and world-changing performance. I loved this publication as a twenty-something and returning to it with more life experience under my belt has been invigorating, inspiring, at times challenging, and overall just as juicy as the first time. As part of the process of creating and performing our multi-disciplinary revisitation it has been rewarding to share "the book" with younger cast members, as well as with audience members who hadn't previously encountered it. Revisiting the artists and ideas from this book and their relationship to the current political moment has enhanced all of our understandings of what a feminist/activist/artist looks like, and some of the issues that still need to be addressed. Our sold-out work-in-progress performance (at Dixon Place's HOT! Festival in July) sparked rich conversations and responses from our audience. We aspire for our full length performance of Angry Women REvisited to provoke even more. We consider this performance to be in reverence of the artists in the book, a celebration of not settling for the world we live in, a pushing of the boundaries of multi-disciplinary performance, and an example of what it might look like if we define things in our own, sometimes very contradictory, terms.Your contribution will directly impact our ability to present this material as a live performance and to have the performance documented professionally.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the cold hard cash, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Donate your services to us. We are seeking in-kind support staff for professional sound mixing, photography shoot, videography, stage manager, and lighting design.
  • Spread the word about this show and about our campaign. Please post as far and wide as your imagination allows! Use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Volunteer for our show. We need ushers, strikers and floor painters on Sunday night, and publicity volunteers. All volunteers will receive a complimentary ticket to the show in exchange for their help. Contact jdellecave@hotmail.com for more information, please put Angry Women Volunteer in the subject line. 
  • Keep checking back, as we will continue to post new photos/videos from our upcoming rehearsals. Maybe even a sneak peek of the show!

story:
Short Summary

In the past few years I have become very passionate about aerial dance. I have always been a mover and a shaker, and even did aerial as a teenager. During a long break from aerial dance, I pursued my BFA in modern dance and picked up fire dancing, stilt walking, and hula hooping, before coming back full circle to where I thrive the most: dancing in the air!  Since coming back to the world of aerial dance, it has re-ignited my passion to be creative, become stronger, perform, and teach others.

I have been awarded a work-study scholarship to teach yoga and Pilates at an 8 day aerial retreat intensive in the Dominican Republic! But, I need your help to get there.

I am attending a training called Aerial Acro Play hosted by Sweet Retreats. It will include 8 days of training on a variety of aerial apparatus including lyra, acro yoga, handstand training, flexibility, flying trapeze, and more.

This training will enable me to accomplish some of my immediate and long term goals in my performance career, as well as coming back with plenty of new material to teach others in my classes and workshops!

What I Need & What You Get

I need $1000 to cover the cost of my flight from Cincinnati to the Dominican Republic.

I am only $1000 short from making this actually happen! I appreciate any and all contributions you have, and I have many perks to offer.

The Impact

Aerial dance is an extremely difficult craft, not only physically, but just in maintaining a regular practice. As far as I know, I am one of the only aerial hoop artists in Central/Southern Ohio actively performing and teaching workshops throughout the region. No one offers regular training in my particular craft that is open to the public, and I have reached my limit on what I can do on my own to continue advancing my craft and performance skills. 

Attending this retreat will enable me to come back to Ohio with more skills to enhance my performance and ability to teach. My goal is to make aerial dance more accessible to people through performing in non-traditional settings outside the theater, such as music festivals, charity events, and site-specific concerts. I intend on utilizing this training to inspire me to produce a site-specific aerial dance concert by Fall 2014 in Cincinnati and to prepare a video demo reel to eventually send to cruise line entertainment companies and take my performing to the next level.

Other Ways You Can Help

It's OK if you can't contribute today! What you CAN do is help spread the word! Please share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or whatever social media site that you use! Word of mouth is always the best way to share!

story:
***** 'Makes you sit up, listen and think about what is being said on your terms, in relation to your own life - recommended to anyone'  The Public Reviews 


THE SHOW

CLOWN SLUT is a one woman show following one girl’s journey through the confusion and mayhem of growing up. Written and performed by Joanna Griffin and directed by Lauren Bracewell, this stand-up theatre piece takes a tongue-in-cheek look at how to be a woman. Starting from clueless adolescence through groping teenage boyfriends, from slut-dropping students at uni through to the tragic office party, CLOWN SLUT asks if shaking out to MC Hammer might make us happier than marriage, mortgages and mowing our muffs.

 'Rips away the stereotypes of feminism. Griffin story tells like an eloquent poet and eccentric comedian' A Younger Theatre


CLOWN SLUT PEOPLE

Joanna Griffin is a LAMDA trained actress and writer. This Fringe she will also appear in Richard Herring's new play I KILLED RASPUTIN at the Assembly Rooms. Other recent roles include those at the Donmar Warehouse, The Arcola, Tara Arts and Lee Nelson's WELL FUNNY PEOPLE (BBC3).

'A dazzlingly intelligent and courageous performer, her talent is unique and her insight incredibly special. Joanna is an artist to watch and I would urge anyone to support her Edinburgh venture.' Josie Rourke, Artistic Director Donmar Warehouse

Lauren Bracewell will direct. She is Artistic Director of Local Girl Productions and has recently worked at the Finborough, Park Theatre and Jermyn Street Theatre. 

Elly Hopkins will produce the show. She is currently Assistant to the Producer at Complicite and has previously worked for the Royal Court Theatre, for Sonia Friedman Productions and was Marketing Director at the Tricycle Theatre.

Monica Dolan is Executive Producer. Monica  won a BAFTA for her portrayal of Rose West in Appropriate Adult. Currently filming for The Casual Vacancy, she has recently been seen onscreen in W1A (BBC), Alpha Papa (The Alan Partridge Movie), and onstage in The Same Deep Water As Me at the Donmar Warehouse.


CLOWN SLUT - THE POTENTIAL 

‘Fun, dynamic and entertaining. Gives you something to think about and coats its message in hilarity - prepare for bellyaching laughter.' Everything Theatre

CLOWN SLUT had a modest first outing last year. Just four shows meant less than 100 people caught it. Our slot at Edinburgh means that over 1000 people could experience the show this August, including critics, industry professionals and venue programmers. We believe CLOWN SLUT should have a future life, and where better to grow it but at it than at the world's biggest theatre festival. 

'She gets the balance right between entertainment and revolution, a tricky task at the best of times' Views from the Gods 

We know how tough the Fringe can be. Literally thousands of other productions will be competing for bums on seats - so what is essential is great publicity design, a dedicated press rep and a watertight marketing plan. 


THE BUDGET

We need your help to afford: 

Travel - from London to Edinburgh for Joanna, director, producer and props.

Accommodation - Somewhere for Joanna to lay her weary head for the month in Edinburgh (plus some floor space for her director and producer!)

Props, costume and tech hires - we’ll beg borrow and steal, but there will still be some things to cough up for.

Flyer and poster design & printing - a winning design is paramount

Press rep - audiences watch shows off the back of reading reviews = fact. We have a professional press rep on board to nail our listings, previews, and to herd the critics in.  

Flyer distribution - Joanna will be operating alone for most of the festival, so we need to get her some flyering support - a one woman army won’t be sufficient. 

Marketing spend - We’ll need to be creative and responsive during the festival, with some room to buy advertising and/or extra print while we’re up there. If we're lucky enough to get great reviews, these will need further promotion to convert into audience members - and it all costs £$£$.


WHY YOU SHOULD HELP 

'An inspired way of helping [young men and women] make empowering choices' Public Reviews

CLOWN SLUT is a rare and exciting thing. A piece of live performance that is laugh out loud funny, an entertaining plot, widely appealing and yet also raises important, pressing questions. People see CLOWN SLUT and want to debate around the issues it raises, and to reflect on their own behaviour and choices. We're proud of that, and we think we should show it to as many people as we can. Come on board and help make it happen.

We're proud of that, and we think we should show it to as many people as we can. Come on board and help make it happen.

story:
***Special Note***

My previous attempt at raising funds through another site has challenged my ethical values, and left me with a moral decision to fund elsewhere. 

I am VERY close to my goal of $5000, and to offset the fees incurred through the previous site, I am now asking for $2000 to make my complete goal allowing me to fully enroll in the SITI program.

My original campaign details are below, thank you for your cooperation and support, I truly have never known a more important opportunity to my artistic growth.

-JACKIE 


I was accepted to SITI Company's 2nd Conservatory class!

SITI stands for Saratoga International Theatre Institute, and operates under the artistic leadership of Ann Bogart and a company of brilliant theater makers. 

I have been offered a spot in their second ever conservatory class based on the articulation of my creative ideas, and my needs for focus and grounding as an actor. I will join 16 students from over 11 different countries to hone our creative voices and contribute to the next generation of theater artists.

The program is 26 weeks, 5 days a week, 10am - 5pm plus outside rehearsal, and culminates in a showcase of a devised work created by the class, in May 2015 in NYC.

The tuition total comes to: $14,250

- $1,250 non-refundable deposit, already paid.
- $4,000 Financial Aid Internship award
- $4,000 saved from the 5 jobs and countless odd jobs I'm working this summer to contribute...
-$3,478.17 raised through GoFundMe and 85 donors in the past 2 months.


SO! together I believe we can raise the $2,000 needed by September 9th to officially enroll me in this program.

If ALL of my Facebook friends donate $2, we will raise more than $2,000 easy peasy!!!! Every little bit helps!!

Thank you all for your consideration in my cause. I've never known a more important opportunity for my artistic growth.

Please and Thank You. 

-Jackie
story_txt: ***Special Note***My previous attempt at raising funds through another site has challenged my ethical values, and left me with a moral decision to fund elsewhere. I am VERY close to my goal of $5000, and to offset the fees incurred through the previous site, I am now asking for $2000 to make my complete goal allowing me to fully enroll in the SITI program.My original campaign details are below, thank you for your cooperation and support, I truly have never known a more important opportunity to my artistic growth.-JACKIE I was accepted to SITI Company's 2nd Conservatory class!SITI stands for Saratoga International Theatre Institute, and operates under the artistic leadership of Ann Bogart and a company of brilliant theater makers. I have been offered a spot in their second ever conservatory class based on the articulation of my creative ideas, and my needs for focus and grounding as an actor. I will join 16 students from over 11 different countries to hone our creative voices and contribute to the next generation of theater artists.The program is 26 weeks, 5 days a week, 10am - 5pm plus outside rehearsal, and culminates in a showcase of a devised work created by the class, in May 2015 in NYC.The tuition total comes to: $14,250- $1,250 non-refundable deposit, already paid.- $4,000 Financial Aid Internship award- $4,000 saved from the 5 jobs and countless odd jobs I'm working this summer to contribute...-$3,478.17 raised through GoFundMe and 85 donors in the past 2 months.SO! together I believe we can raise the $2,000 needed by September 9th to officially enroll me in this program.If ALL of my Facebook friends donate $2, we will raise more than $2,000 easy peasy!!!! Every little bit helps!!Thank you all for your consideration in my cause. I've never known a more important opportunity for my artistic growth.Please and Thank You. -Jackie

story:
Spectrum Theatre Company 

Founded in 2005, Spectrum Theatre Company is a student-run theatre board that produces a full season every year and is dedicated to recognizing the spectrum of beliefs, opinions, colors, creeds, and lifestyles of all people by producing thought provoking and challenging theater. Our mission is to collaborate with and empower the greater Northwestern community by raising awareness, inspiring dialogue, and effecting change through theatrical experiences based on relevant social and political issues.
To learn more visit our website at Spectrum Theatre Company

BARE

A contemporary rock musical, BARE follows a group of teens wrestling with identity, sexuality, and religion at a co-ed Catholic boarding school. 

Provocative and raw, BARE is unyielding in its exploration of how our generation navigates the tightrope between adolescence and adulthood. Our production will explore what it means to wear a mask through life, how these facades alter our identities, and ultimately how far we are willing to go to compromise our sense of self in order to maintain the validity of our masks and fit into society’s prescriptive norms.

When our story gives these young adults the choice whether or not to reveal the turmoil underneath their masks, their decision to keep others out or lay themselves "bare" will not only alter the course of their lives, but leave everyone changed forever.

The Team

Cast: Sam Shankman, Eric Peters, Sara Kase, Tessa Dettman, Alex Christ, Lindsey Olson, Dan Stromfeld, Rosie Chandler, Frankie Leo Bennett, Adhana Reid, Daniel Liu, Jessie Jennison, Chris Paul, Jason Dillion 

Artistic Team: Alex Bird, Rob Cassie, Natascha Buschmann, Walker McKinney, Rosie Jo Neddy, Megan Wines, Bryan Matias, Emily Koller, Kali Skatchke, Amanda Odasz, Jack Birdsall, Marin Nass, Sam Nagler

Business Team: Daniel Stompor, Allie Hagen, Solveig Herzum, Abby Weissman, Tess Musky-Goldwyn, Katelyn Buchta, Collin Rice, Ben Weiss, Aditi Bhandari, Isabel Robertson

To learn more about BARE visit the show's page at Spectrum Presents: BARE

The Impact

Your generous donation will allow this project to become a reality in many ways. 

  • Set: The set design will transform our performance space into a church, complete with pews and stained-glass windows. Funds will go towards buying lumber, paint, and tools. 
  • Lights: To light the actors and to create special effects, funds will go towards renting and purchasing lights and lighting equipment.
  • Costume and Props: Funds will allow us to purchase and construct costumes for our 14-person cast as well as props.
  • Publicity: For the production to have the greatest impact possible, funds will be used to publicize our event across campus and the Evanston community with materials such as posters, programs, and promotional videos. 
  • Outreach: This production and Spectrum Theatre Company are committed to  making a positive impact on the community through meaningful theatre. Donations will allow us to organize community events such as workshops in local high schools and talkbacks and post-show events surrounding the theme of the show. 

Other Ways You Can Be Involved

  • If you'd like to make an in-kind donation of any sort, email spectrumsbtm2014@gmail.com
  • Spread the word! Help us raise our goal by sharing our indiegogo campaign and telling everyone you know about our production.
  • Support our production by coming to see the show! 

Performances will be held in Shanley Pavilion at Northwestern University. The dates and times of the performances are:

  • Thursday, October 23rd: 8 pm
  • Friday, October 24th: 8 and 11 pm
  • Saturday, October 25th: 2 and 8 pm

Tickets are $5 for students and $10 for the general public.

Thank you for your generosity!

story:
WHO WE ARE:

We are Bluebox Theatre Company.  We are a relatively new theatre and performing arts company founded in Long Island, NY. Our goal is to bring new visions and people to live theatre with original content and unique takes on classic and contemporary works.

Our styles and practices reflect the needs not only of artists, but for the community as a whole.  We want to create more creative work opportunities for the artists around us, and above all, we aim to present a unique opportunity to bring new audiences to the theater.

Our campaign is important because it means more fair job opportunities for artists, as well as more exposure to live performance to people who might not usually enjoy theatre.  We as a company pick nontraditional shows.  Our target is young adults ages 16 to 35, which is also the market thats most lacking in even multi million dollar Broadway shows.  We want to help fix that by exposing people to something different, and our next show "BUG" will accomplish just that. 

A portion of the shows profits will get directly donated to "Hope House" as well.  Hope House is an organization that houses specifically young people and families in crisis with abuse, neglect, as well as all other people in our society who are seen as abandoned.  Hope House is in the same town as our performance, and the members of the recovery programs there will get free tickets, as well as the staff.  So, that being said, support from our fundraiser campaign is critical in making all this happen well.

In 2013, we produced the New York premiere of Night of the Living Dead on stage for the Performing Arts Studio in Port Jefferson, NY.  We've also put on The Breakfast Club live, three episodes of The Twilight Zone, and other productions before we chose our names including different live music performances from hip-hop shows in Manhattan to heavy-metal-string-quartet hybrid bands in Port Jefferson.

Our names are David Morrissey, Joe Rubino, and Andrew Beck, and we need your help.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:
Fresh off of a successful adaptation of episodes of The Twilight Zone, the plan is to produce Bug by Tracy Letts. Already a popular movie, Bug started as a small thriller on stage in London. The play has a built in audience and Long Island theatre companies don't produce the show often. We need YOUR help to make this show the best it can possibly be. A trailer for our campaign will be posted soon but we need your help to get the ball rolling.

Theatre is a costly venture, and we need you to help fund our dream so the Long Island community can be aware of the top notch shows we put on. We are looking to raise $2500 to cover the costs of:

-Rehearsal/ performance space
-Performance rights and Licensing
-Actor stipends
-Professional sets/props
-Marketing solutions and advertising
-Playbills, scripts, and show posters.



SYNOPSIS AND IMPACT:
Most of the play takes place in a seedy motel room. Lonely cocktail waitress Agnes lives there, hiding from her violent ex-con ex-husband Jerry Goss. One night, her lesbian biker friend R.C. introduces her to Peter, a Gulf War veteran who might be AWOL. She gets involved with Peter, who grows increasingly paranoid about the war in Iraq, UFOs, the Oklahoma City bombing, cult suicides, and then secret government experiments on soldiers — eventually drawing Agnes into his delusions. The play deals with the issues of love, paranoia, conspiracy theories, and Agnes' slow descent into insanity under Peter's influence.

We are looking to team up with a local charity to spread the word about issues and themes in the play. For our last production, we teamed up with VEThack, a burgeoning charity to end veteran suicide.


WHAT YOU GET:
If you look below, we have various perks you will receive as incentive to help us out! We wish to extend our eternal gratitude to you, just for looking at our campaign.

story:
Short Summary

HI! I'm Tracy Broyles, and I am a dancer and choreographer. I have been making work for over 15 years from my home base here in Portland, OR.  HYDE will be my 8th evening length piece, and I am so excited to share it with you.

I explore consciousness through movement. Energy states, the psyche, human behavior, and relationship, are all great influences on my work. My process is collaborative and develops through play, trial and error, and intuition.
I have been supported through grants and residencies throughout the Northwest. HYDE is my first group evening length work after years of creating solo pieces,  and I am pushing myself as a choreographer and director, while involving a larger community of artists in the process.

What We Need & What You Get

 MY GOAL is to pay all of the artists involved in HYDE.

THE ARTISTS ARE:

Choreographer/director :

TRACY BROYLES

Movement collaborators:

DOUGLAS ALLEN, REBECCA HARRISON, STEPHANIE LANCKTON, MARK KLINE, NIKO THOMAS

Sound collaborators:

ADRIAN HUTAPEA, LISA DeGRACE

Video Collaborator:

STEPHEN A. MILLER

Lighting designer:

VANESSA JANSON

Costume Designer:

ELODIE MASSA

Videographer/indiegogo film:

KARL LIND

Photographer:

KAMALA KINGSLEY

The core artists/collaborators will give over 200 hours worth of their time. $1000 will compensate them slightly under $5.00 an hour. While this may seem low, it is more that most working artists are often guaranteed. With your help you can ensure that the artists will not indeed be "starving."

The total budget for the show is $20,000, of which $11,000 is artist fees. The remainder of the budget is projected to come through ticket sales and funding bodies.

I am asking for 40% of the total budget through this campaign, 100% of which will go to the artists. Your contribution will not go through any middle person, but directly to the individual, making the impact of each dollar strong.

I have managed numerous projects like this before, and have seen what a positive impact even a little support can make. And the impact is made by and large by individuals just like you. Talented and trained artists, rehearsal time, vision, marketing outreach, fundraising, visibility, venue, all these elements are entwined into a process that is intricate, costly and necessary for the success of a performance. And can be made possible by your financial contribution. PLUS we want you to be our audience, and even if you are not able to give at this time, please let us dance for you.


Risks & Challenges

$8100 is a lot of money for an independent dance artist to ask for, however that is what is needed to bring this  work and visibility to the next level, and to pay the artists who give so much of themselves.  Asking for help is vulnerable and exposing and asking artists to work for free is disheartening. Let's make a change!

Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD! Share, share, share, like, tell people about it, question it, talk to us, love it, hate it, start a conversation. This is so important! and COME TO THE SHOW!
AND WE THANK YOU FOR WATCHING, READING, SUPPORTING AND SHARING!!

story:
Stockholm

By Byrony Lavery 

Todd and Kali.  Young, beautiful, and in love beyond comprehension.  With a trip to Stockholm on the horizon, the couple prepares to celebrate his birthday with a romantic night in.  As the night goes on and regular tensions work their way out from the cracks, their perfect union begins to crumble with tragic familiarity.  Exploring jealousy, sex, and the cycle of abuse, Stockholm's balance of prose, poetry, and dance create a heightened tale of modern love.

How Your Donation Helps

In creating a work of theatre, we essentially need to create another world, and even the smallest donation can help us get our hands on a part of this world! The Struble Project Series generously provides us with a $500 grant to help us put this work together, but our visions for this project go past what we can do with $500, and we're hoping to double our budget. Your donations go towards...

  • Set: Our set designer is full of innovative ideas on how to move the characters fluidly through the different locations of the show, and your donation can help make his wildest dreams possible.
  • Costumes: We need to get a wardrobe for these two characters which will not only fit their personalities but will also work for the dance elements of the show.
  • Props: This show requires everything from large knives to smiling fish, and any amount you donate can help our props designer properly furnish this world, and if you donate enough you can take one of these props home after the show is over!
  • Publicity: We firmly believe that this work is important and that it's part of a dialogue that this campus needs to have, and so we'd like as many people as possible to come see it. In order to do that, we need posters and other physical forms of advertisement to put out into the world.
  • Outreach: Any fundraising that exceeds our goal will be donated to RAINN, the Rape, Abuse, and Incest National Network. We'd love if this show could make an impact not just on members of the audience but on people outside of the show who are affected by abuse. 

The Struble Project Series

The Struble Project Series began officially in the fall of 2010 due to a generous grant from an annonymous source.

The Series accepts applications from NU undergraduate students.  A total of six slots are available each year (two each in the fall, winter and spring quarters.) The Struble Selection Committee consists of Jim Davis, Lab Theater production manager, a Theatre Department advisor (currently John Haas), and two Wirtz Center Staff members (currently Diane Claussen, managing director and Dixie Uffelman, production manager.) This committee reviews petitions and selects a number of applications in each round for in-person interviews and makes final selections and offers to the applicants who they feel best fit the program.  Applications are accepted in the late spring for the following fall and winter quarters and in early winter for the spring quarter.

The Struble is a safe space. New work, staged readings and workshops are all ideal fits for the program.  Each project occupies the theatre for one calendar week, performs on the Friday and Saturday of that week and strikes on Sunday. Scenic elements are limited to simple furniture pieces. Production elements are otherwise limited to a repertory lighting plot. Because of the generosity of our annonymous donor, The Wirtz Center is able to provide a budget of $500 for production materials. Tickets are free for all performances.

story:
Devil Lay Me Down

"Devil Lay Me Down" is a new play by Ean Miles Kessler, and will premiere at Theater for the New City, with the Dream Up Festival in August.  We've got an incredible team working on this project--with Stephen D'Ambrose, Mara Gannon, and Joe Williamson starring, David Delaney directing. and Glenn Quentin producing--and we're thrilled to be working with such an incredible venue and festival.


But we need your help.  There are dozens of costs in making a play a reality--from rehearsal space, to props and costumes, to paying all of our talented collaborators--and in order to bring this piece to life, we are looking to raise $5,000.  We're offering a whole bunch of perks for helping us out, including signed memorabilia from the show, Haikus written by the Devil himself, invites to the cast party after the final show, shout-outs for your own personal projects, and much more.  Any help you can offer is tremendously appreciated.


The Play Itself...

"Devil Lay Me Down" centers on Julian Carthy, as he returns from prison to his father's trailer on the Texas-Mexico border.  There he finds his father Marcus, living with Ro—his much younger live-in girlfriend.  And when a spark of interest lights between Julian and Ro, old tensions seethe between father and son, drawing Julian's brutal past to the surface.  A modern Western, at its heart "Devil Lay Me Down" is a brutal love story, and love song to the American West.


Our Goals...

This is a workshop production, and our aim is to make it fairly bare-bones, so as to minimize costs, and any contribution you can give will help to make this show a reality.  No amount is too small, and everything is much appreciated.  This piece began as a through-line in another play that we produced in 2012, called "King's River."  If you helped with that fundraising campaign, we cannot thank you enough.  Now, we're trying to do the same thing for "Devil."  Fortunately, our monetary goal is much smaller this time--$5,000, a fraction of what "King's River" cost.  You'll be helping us build a new play, one that we've been working on for over 2 years now.  This piece has finally reached the next step in its gestation, and it needs to be put up on it's legs in front of an audience.  This campaign will help do that.


We want to get as much notice as we can for all of the artists we have collaborating with us on this project.  We're tremendously proud of all the work that they've done, and it's very important to us that they be recognized for all of their dedication.  Our hope is that this workshop production will lead to other extended productions in the near-future, and we want everyone affiliated with this play to grow and benefit from this experience.  But most of all, we want to put on a great show.  We hope you can help with this venture.


Costs...

Below is a budget for "Devil" so you can see up-front where your money will be going:


    Devil Lay Me Down Budget

    Festival Participation Fee:  $500

    Rehearsal space:  $2,000

    Actor Stipend:  $1,500, ($500/actor)

    Stage Managers Stipend:  $250

    Lighting Design Stipend:  $200

    Sound Design Stipend:  $150

    Props Budget:  $225

    Costumes:  $175

    TOTAL:  $5,000


      Other Ways You Can Help...

      Thank you all tremendously for all of your support; we can't say how much we appreciate it.  Please take a moment and like us on Facebook (search for event:  “Devil Lay Me Down”), follow us on Twitter @DevilLayMeDown, and check out our website (www.devillaymedown.com)  It's a small gesture, and only takes a second, but truly helps to boost awareness for the show.  Help spread the word, and invite your friends to like us and follow us.  And share our Indiegogo campaign with friends and family.


      For tickets to the play, go to:  

      http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?EID=&show...


      Hope to see you all at the show--


      Sincerely,

      -The Creative Team of Devil Lay Me Down
story_txt:
Devil Lay Me Down

"Devil Lay Me Down" is a new play by Ean Miles Kessler, and will premiere at Theater for the New City, with the Dream Up Festival in August.  We've got an incredible team working on this project--with Stephen D'Ambrose, Mara Gannon, and Joe Williamson starring, David Delaney directing. and Glenn Quentin producing--and we're thrilled to be working with such an incredible venue and festival.



But we need your help.  There are dozens of costs in making a play a reality--from rehearsal space, to props and costumes, to paying all of our talented collaborators--and in order to bring this piece to life, we are looking to raise $5,000.  We're offering a whole bunch of perks for helping us out, including signed
memorabilia from the show, Haikus written by the Devil himself, invites to the
cast party after the final show, shout-outs for your own personal projects, and
much more.  Any help you can offer is tremendously appreciated.




The Play Itself...

"Devil
Lay Me Down" centers on Julian Carthy, as he returns from prison to his
father's trailer on the Texas-Mexico border. 
There he finds his father Marcus, living with Ro—his much younger
live-in girlfriend.  And when a spark of
interest lights between Julian and Ro, old tensions seethe between father and
son, drawing Julian's brutal past to the surface.  A modern Western, at its heart "Devil Lay Me
Down" is a brutal love story, and love song to the American West.


Our Goals...

This is a workshop production, and our aim is to make it fairly bare-bones, so as to minimize costs, and any contribution you can give will help to make this show a reality.  No amount is too small, and everything is much appreciated.  This piece began as a through-line in another play that we produced in 2012, called "King's River."  If you helped with that fundraising campaign, we cannot thank you enough.  Now, we're trying to do the same thing for "Devil."  Fortunately, our monetary goal is much smaller this time--$5,000, a fraction of what "King's River" cost.  You'll be helping us build a new play, one that we've been working on for over 2 years now.  This piece has finally reached the next step in its gestation, and it needs to be put up on it's legs in front of an audience.  This campaign will help do that.

We want to get as much notice as we can for all of the artists we have collaborating with us on this project.  We're tremendously proud of all the work that they've done, and it's very important to us that they be recognized for all of their dedication.  Our hope is that this workshop production will lead to other extended productions in the near-future, and we want everyone affiliated with this play to grow and benefit from this experience.  But most of all, we want to put on a great show.  We hope you can help with this venture.


Costs...

Below is a budget for "Devil" so you can see up-front where your money will be going:




Devil Lay Me Down Budget
Festival
Participation Fee:  $500
Rehearsal
space:  $2,000
Actor
Stipend:  $1,500, ($500/actor)
Stage
Managers Stipend:  $250
Lighting
Design Stipend:  $200
Sound
Design Stipend:  $150
Props Budget: 
$225
Costumes: 
$175

TOTAL: 
$5,000


  Other Ways You Can Help... Thank you all tremendously for all of your support; we can't say how much we appreciate it.  Please
take a moment and like us on Facebook (search for event:  “Devil Lay Me Down”), follow us on
Twitter @DevilLayMeDown, and check out our website (www.devillaymedown.com)  It's a small gesture,
and only takes a second, but truly helps to boost awareness for the show.

http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?EID=&show...

Hope to see you all at the show--

Sincerely,
-The Creative Team of Devil Lay Me Down

story:
What is Fringe?

Fringe Festival San Miguel de Allende (October 11-19) is a celebration of the performing arts in multiple languages and venues in this historic, cosmopolitan city. In addition to a thrilling array of performances we will also offer workshops in acting, voice, movement, stage fighting, playwriting and more.

In Edinburgh, where Fringe began in 1947, the Festival Fringe is now the largest arts festival in the world, and includes over 2000 shows every year in 300 venues. The population of the city doubles during the festival. Fringe festivals have popped up in many cities around the world - New York, Avignon, Prague, Toronto, New Orleans - but this will be the first Fringe festival in Spanish-speaking Latin America.

To date, we have received 45 performance submissions from Mexico (DF, Guanajuato, Querétaro, Mérida, Hermosillo, Guadalajara), Spain, Great Britain, Costa Rica, the US (LA, NYC) and Canada (Montreal) in the categories of drama, thriller, comedy, cabaret, performance collage, stand-up, farce, children's theatre, dance, puppetry, improv and more. We have also invited several outstanding solo artists and groups, some of whom performed to great acclaim in our first small theatre festival held in San Miguel de Allende in August 2012 (Encuentro de Teatro San Miguel).

Why San Miguel de Allende?

San Miguel de Allende is a top destination for tourists from all over the world and this vibrant city has a colorful history as an artistic and culturally diverse community. English and Spanish, Latin and Anglo, ancient and modern all mingle here. In this beguiling atmosphere of cultural schizophrenia, the Fringe Festival SMA will make itself at home by bringing fresh entertainment and insights to the beautiful town’s theatres, cafés, restaurants, bars and streets. The Fringe Festival SMA will be accessible and inclusive to a broad audience and will attract visitors from other cities to stay in our city's hotels, eat in our restaurants, shop in our stores and markets.

Mexico is home to many innovative playwrights, actors, dancers and other performers and we hope that Fringe Festival SMA becomes an annual pilgrimage for them, a chance to try something new, test their boundaries, expand their horizons and interact with others in their field.

Why we need your help

We have been so inspired by the eager response to this festival on the part of the performing arts community here in Mexico and beyond. They are hungry for it. We have also been impressed by the quality of their work and the possibilities it represents for not only this inaugural festival, but for years to come.

Our only limitation is funding. We are working with artists to help them make the trip to SMA; as this is our first year, we are trying to be generous to encourage the best performers and instructors to participate. This means we will need to help cover some transportation costs, lodging and per diem.

Ticket prices will be kept low and the income will be shared with the artists (after paying the venue). Ticket sales will never cover our budget, which also includes administrative costs, print and digital advertising, and those thousand little costs you don't expect. One of our favorite quotes about the theatre business sums it up: "The natural condition is one of insurmountable obstacles on the road to imminent disaster." Need we say more? We need your help!

We have come up with some exciting perks to express our gratitude for your contribution (named after lucha libre wrestlers, our mascots). But your support - at any level - for launching this new cultural experience in San Miguel and Mexico is truly a priceless gift.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our campaign and the Fringe Festival SMA! If you would like to volunteer or make an in-kind donation, contact us at participar@fringesanmiguel.com.

And if you are interested in adopting a show (minimum donation of $2500 USD), you can contact us at the above address to discuss details. If you decide to become a proud adoptive parent to one of our shows, you will be given preferential space in all publicity related to the production (as well as Festival publicity) and receive invitations to exclusive events with the show's creative team and cast.

¿Qué es Fringe?

Fringe Festival San Miguel de Allende (11-19 de octubre) es una celebración de las artes escénicas en múltiples idiomas y diversas sedes en esta ciudad histórica y cosmopolita. Además de una selección emocionante de espectáculos, también ofreceremos talleres y clases en interpretación, voz, movimiento, esgrima, dramaturgia y más.

En Edimburgo, donde inició el Fringe en 1947, el Festival Fringe es hoy en día el festival las artes más grande del mundo e incluye más de 2000 espectáculos en 300 sedes cada año. La población de la ciudad se duplica durante el festival. Ahora han apreceido Fringe festivales en varias ciudades alrededor del mundo - Nueva York, Avignon, Praga, Toronto, Nuevo Orleans - pero esto será el primero festival Fringe celebrado en la América Latina hispanohablante.

Hasta la fecha, hemos recibido 45 solicitudes de artistas de México (DF, Guanajuato, Querétaro, Mérida, Hermosillo, Guadalajara), España, Gran Bretaña, Costa Rica, los Estados Unidos (Nueva York y Los Ángeles) y Canada (Montreal) en las categorías de drama, comedia, suspenso, cabaret, collage escénico, stand-up, farsa, teatro para niños, títeres, danza, improvisación y más. También hemos invitado a varios artistas y grupos destacados, algunos que hicieron presentaciones elogiadas en nuestro primer pequeño festival de teatro celebrado en San Miguel de Allende en agosto 2012 (Encuentro de Teatro San Miguel).

¿Por qué San Miguel de Allende?

San Miguel de Allende es uno de los mayores destinos turísticos en todo el mundo. Esta vibrante ciudad posee una historia llena de colorido así como una comunidad artística y culturalmente variada. Lo europeo y lo indígena, lo latino y lo anglosajón, lo antiguo y lo moderno convergen aquí.

En esta cautivante atmósfera de esquizofrenia cultural, el Fringe Festival San Miguel de Allende se encontrará el entorno ideal para atraer un tipo de entretenimiento fresco a los teatros, cafés, restaurantes, bares y calles. El Fringe Festival SMA será  incluyente y accessible a un público grande y atraerá a visitantes de otras ciudades para hospedarse en nuestros hoteles, comer en nuestros restaurantes, ir de compras en nuestras tiendas y mercados.

México es el hogar de muchos dramaturgos, actores, bailarines y otros artistas de gran innovación. Esperamos que el Fringe Festival San Miguel de Allende conduzca a un peregrinaje anual para ellos, se vuelva una oportunidad para intentar algo nuevo, traspasar límites, expandir horizontes e interactuar con otros artistas.

Por qué necesitamos tu apoyo

Nos entusiasma la ávida respuesta que ha recibido el festival por parte de la comunidad de las artes escénicas en México. Lo anhelan. También estamos impresionados de la calidad del trabajo y las posibilidades que representa no solamente para el festival en éste su año inaugural sino para los años venideros.

Nuestra única limitante son los fondos. Estamos trabajando con los artistas para ayudarlos hacer el viaje a SMA. Ya que es nuestro primer año, estamos tratando de ser generosos para motivar a los mejores actores, artistas e instructores para participar. Esto significa que vamos a necesitar apoyo para cubrir los costos de transporte, alojamiento y alimentos.

El precio de los boletos será bajo y este ingreso se dividirá entre el festival y los actores (después de pagar para el uso de la sede). La venta de boletos no cubrirá nuestro presupuesto, lo que también incluye costos administrativos, imprenta y publicidad digital, y millones de pequeños detalles inesperados. Una famosa cita sobre el negocio del teatro lo resume todo “la condición natural es uno de los insuperables obstáculos en el camino hacia el desastre inminente.” ¿Necesitamos decir más? ¡Necesitamos de tu ayuda!

Ofrecemos unos beneficios emocionantes ("perks", denominados por nombres de luchadores mexicanos que son nuestra mascota) para agradecer tu aportación. Sin embargo, tu apoyo - a cualquier nivel - en lanzar esta nueva experiencia cultural en San Miguel y en México es un regalo que no tiene precio.

Otros tipos de apoyo

¡Favor de correr la voz sobre el Fringe Festival SMA y esta campaña! Si te gustaría participar de voluntario o hacer una donación en especie, favor de contactarnos en participar@fringesanmiguel.com.

Y si te interesa adoptar a un espectáculo (aportación mínima de $2500 USD), nos puedes contactar a la misma dirección más arriba para informes. Si decides convertirte en un orgulloso padre adoptivo de uno de nuestras producciones, te daremos preferencia en toda publicidad relacionada a la producción (y publicidad del festival) y te invitamos a evento exclusivos con el elenco y equipo creativo de la obra.
