story:
Carole is an administrative assistant at Scrooge Industries in modern-day San Francisco. When three colorful and quirky ghosts visit her on Christmas Eve (including The Ghost of Christmas Breaks and The Ghost of Christmas Bonuses), Carole embarks on a wild yuletide adventure... but can she change things at the office, cheer up her humbug boss, and catch the holiday spirit in time for Christmas dinner?! Find out in this World Premiere play brought to you by the Thrillride Mechanics — the creative team that wowed Bay Area audiences with last summer’s all-ages hit WUNDERWORLD. Featuring broad physical comedy, innovative puppetry, unforgettable characters, and outrageous costumes, It’s Christmas, Carole! is a 50-minute holiday comedy for all families, all cultures, and all ages.


Who We Are:

The Thrillride Mechanics are San Francisco's very own Theater of Human Animation in residence at the beautiful Creativity Theater in Yerba Buena Gardens. Our mission is to tell stories onstage that are universally entertaining for children and adults and promote acceptance, empathy, and positive change. After the success of our flagship production WUNDERWORLD, our friends at the Children’s Creativity Museum asked us to come back in December with a new take on a beloved holiday classic. Like WUNDERWORLD, we wanted to do something a little different with this particular tale, something that updated the story for the modern family audience by including ALL holidays & cultures, plus plenty of our signature comic twists and turns. The result is It's Christmas, Carole! and we need YOUR help to make it happen!


By donating to our IndieGoGo campaign you become an integral part of bringing It’s Christmas, Carole! to the Children’s Creativity Museum this holiday season. As an independent producing company, we rely on the generous support of donors like you to bring new theater to life. We’ve got a tremendous community of performers, artists, designers, and technicians contributing their talents to this show. Your donations go directly to the independent artists who are building this new work. Any amount you can contribute will keep this community thriving and ensure that our show looks, sounds, and feels like the holiday hit we know it can be. We need your help, and we promise you won't be disappointed with the results!


What We Need:

The Thrillride Mechanics make miracles happen with a small amount of cash. We’ve done it before and we’ll do it again! Our $5,000 budget will help us pay for all of these things and more:


  • Costumes (materials, design, construction)

  • Sound Design (music, sound effects, microphones)

  • Lighting Design (animated effects & colors)

  • Website & Publicity Materials (domain & web hosting, photography, press packets)

  • Director, Stage Manager & Actor Rehearsal Stipends


We love paying good people good money for their time and talents, and for that we need a little help. Our fundraising goal of $5,000 is the minimum we’d like to raise and any additional funding means additional pay to all of these wonderful artists. Your contribution will help the entire It’s Christmas, Carole! community bring you a World Premiere that will surprise and delight!


What You Get:

Besides the thrill of bringing new theater to life, your donation may get you a fun keepsake or two. We've got:


  • Signed It’s Christmas, Carole! memorabilia!

  • Exclusive Carole Art! Collect it all!

  • Carole Soundtracks! Rock out to the weirdest Christmas songs ever recorded!

  • Tickets to the Show!


And if we meet our goal we’ll have even more ways to show our appreciation to you, our generous benefactors. We promise it will be worth the investment! Every cent counts so please consider contributing whatever you can!


The Impact:

In addition to being a fun, hilarious, highly-inventive show, It’s Christmas Carole! is a poignant tale about opening your heart to the people around you, not just on holidays but EVERY day of the year. Celebrating holidays is a universal practice and, while the holidays may differ from culture to culture, the act of coming together is an important part of how we survive and thrive as human beings. Carole's holiday adventure takes the lasting themes of Dickens' story and updates them for today's world, telling a tale that applies to all cultures, religions, and walks of life. It's a heart-warming and thoroughly entertaining story that needs to be told, needs to be seen, and needs YOU to help make it happen!


Other Ways You Can Help:

After you've donated you can still help us in easy, high-impact ways. For instance, you can:

  • Tell everyone you know about the show!

  • Forward this campaign to all your friends, especially those who love theater and have money!

  • Like us on FaceBook: search for Thrillride Mechanics!


If You're Not Convinced:

Or even if you are, check out these great reviews and quotes from our last hit show,  WUNDERWORLD:


"Irresistible... Family-Friendly Comedy!"
SF Bay Guardian Review

"Hilarious... Truly Original... Exquisitely Presented!"
SF Examiner Review


"WUNDERWORLD is a miracle of originality. We came in as grownups but left as enchanted 7-year-olds. Don't miss it!" - David Weissman, award-winning documentary filmmaker (The Cockettes, We Were Here)


Thank you so much for your time! Any and all contributions are greatly appreciated.

We hope you and yours have a wonderfully fulfilling holiday season and we'll see you at the Creativity Theater!


Cheers,

Sara Moore, Michael Phillis, & Debra Mosk

THRILLRIDE MECHANICS

Sound Design (music, sound effects, microphones)
Lighting Design (animated effects & colors)
Website & Publicity Materials (domain & web hosting, photography, press packets)
Director, Stage Manager & Actor Rehearsal Stipends

We
 love paying good people good money for their time and talents, and for 
that we need a little help. Our fundraising goal of $5,000 is the 
minimum we’d like to raise and any additional funding means 
additional pay to all of these wonderful artists. Your
contribution will help the entire It’s Christmas, Carole! community bring you a World Premiere that will surprise and delight!

What You Get:
Besides the thrill of bringing new theater to life, your donation may get you a fun keepsake or two. We've got:

Signed It’s Christmas, Carole! memorabilia!
Exclusive Carole Art! Collect it all!
Carole Soundtracks! Rock out to the weirdest Christmas songs ever recorded!
Tickets to the Show!

And
 if we meet our goal we’ll have even more ways to show our appreciation 
to you, our generous benefactors. We promise it will be worth the 
investment! Every cent counts so please consider contributing whatever 
you can!

The Impact:
In addition to being a fun, hilarious, highly-inventive show, It’s Christmas Carole!
 is a poignant tale about opening your heart to the people around you, not just on holidays but EVERY day of the year. Celebrating holidays is a universal practice and, while the holidays may differ from culture to culture, the act of coming together is an important part of how we survive and thrive as human beings. Carole's holiday adventure takes the lasting themes of Dickens' story and updates them for today's world, telling a tale that applies to all cultures, religions, and walks of life. It's a heart-warming and thoroughly entertaining story that needs to be told, needs to be seen, and needs YOU to help make it happen!

Other Ways You Can Help:
After you've donated you can still help us in easy, high-impact ways. For instance, you can:

Tell everyone you know about the show!
Forward this campaign to all your friends, especially those who love theater and have money!
Like us on FaceBook: search for Thrillride Mechanics!


If You're Not Convinced:
Or even if you are, check out these great reviews and quotes from our last hit show,  WUNDERWORLD:
"Irresistible... Family-Friendly Comedy!"SF Bay Guardian Review
"Hilarious... Truly Original... Exquisitely Presented!"SF Examiner Review 

"WUNDERWORLD
 is a miracle of originality. We came in as grownups but left as 
enchanted 7-year-olds. Don't miss it!" - David Weissman, award-winning 
documentary filmmaker (The Cockettes, We Were Here)

Thank
 you so much for your time! Any and all contributions are greatly 
appreciated. 
We hope you and yours have a wonderfully fulfilling holiday
 season and we'll see you at the Creativity Theater!

Cheers,
Sara Moore, Michael Phillis, & Debra Mosk
THRILLRIDE MECHANICS

story:
Hello,

I recently got accepted into a Musical Theater program at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. I am looking to raised money to fund my enrollment into the program and evenutally jump-start a career as a singer, dancer and actress. Please contribute as little as $20 to my campaign.

- the program offers career preparation

- courses in jazz/tap, voice and choreogrpahy

- opportunity to study with world-renown facuty

 

Here's a program descripton:

Musical Theatre
This intensive is designed for the beginning to intermediate actor in musical theatre who wants to broaden his or her understanding of the craftsmanship involved for the performer. It is comprised of daily coursework in dance, vocal production, song interpretation, acting and individual coaching. The intensive will culminate with a presentation of work for evaluation by industry professionals.

Course of study:
Choreography / Movement  4 hours per week
Jazz / Tap  6 hours per week
Voice Technique  4 hours per week
Song Interpretation  4 hours per week
Acting Exercises / Sensory Work  6 hours per week
Performance Master Class   4 hours per week

I hope you will all be able to donate as little or as much as you can to my campiagn!

 

Thank you all.

story:
Bedtime Solos By Jakob Holder

central standard theatre • kansas city @ the Edinburgh Festival Fringe

Central Standard Theatre makes its debut at the Edinburgh Fringe with a play from Jakob Holder, Bedtime Solos.

central standard theatre • kansas city is a company dedicated to innovative theatre partnerships with artists around the world. We are taking part in an international theatrical dialogue, helping to define ourselves as Americans and as artists.  Our culture, our heritage defined and celebrated - not just at home in the Heartland, but exported and showcased around the globe.  World class...  Expect nothing less.

CST is sending 3 artists to Edinburgh, Scotland to perform at the largest Arts festival on the planet.  Bob Paisley, Amy Kelly and Jordan Fox will present Jakob Holder's play from Aug 1-26 at the Assembly Roxy

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what it costs for us to take our show to Scotland:

  • $5000   Housing
  • $4500   Travel
  • $5000   Venue Rental
  • $3000   Food (and drink)
  • $2500   Publicity/Marketing

That's a whackload of simolians!

But let's get specific... We want your help putting a roof over our heads.  Housing is expensive and it could rain.  It is Scotland, after all.  The funds we're raising will keep us neat and tidy in our three bedroom flat... and a spare couch in the Parlor...(hint, hint)

  • A $25 pledge will get a a authentic Scottish Postcard
  • A $50 pledge gets you a Bedtime Solos Edinburgh Fringe Poster
  • A $100 pledge gets you a copy of the Bedtime Solos Script
  • A $500 pledge gets you credit as an Associate Producer
  • $1000 will credit you as an Executive Producer

The Impact

I think it's important to take Kansas City to the world... and bring the world to KC.  Exchanging ideas and cultures really can make us better people.  We have a lot to share and we want everyone to come along for the journey.

story:
Introduction

Hello my name is Luke Brady and I'm 23 year old actor from Dorking surrey.I am about to embark on one of the most exciting and Beneficial ventures of my career to date. Ive been lucky enough to have worked as an actor for the past 5 years, but in such a competitive industry,this is a personal and essential move i feel i need to ensure longevity and fingers crossed a  career. 

Campaign

  • Ive just been offered a place at The Royal Academy Of Dramatic Arts on its 3 year BA course starting this september!

  • The Competition for RADA is mammoth with over 3,300 applicants applying for only 27 places this year. Over a gruelling 10 month audition period spreading through 4 audition rounds.Being given the opportunity is still hard news to digest, but with term starting around the corner the reality of living in london as a student is very real! 

  • With your help it would really help break the costs down and make the bigger picture easier to tackle.

  • I am very fortunate as i qualify for a maintenance grant! which is essential due to RADAs demanding hours. 36 hours per week means that students are unable to work during term times as study then suffers.

Heres what i need

£5 - General stationery pens, pencils, notebooks etc.

£20 - A weeks student travel card - zone 1 18+

£50 - A week means i can dine at "The Ivy" once a week as part of character study...JOKE! Noodles and clearance meals im sure will be my true Michelin star cuisine. =)

£100 - This will go towards Practical equipment for the course, Jazz shoes, black leather sole shoes, track suits.

£150 - Rent a week.

£160 - RADA deposit (library use, locker, NUS card, photocopying etc)


Other Ways You Can Help

So thank you for taking the time to check out my page!

I know times are tough and not everyone will be able to make a contribution, but please if you could share my page around  any social network out there, Facebook,Twitter. Just sharing alone helps me out a huge deal, your efforts couldnt be more appreciated. =)  

Heres a link to more Information about what ive been up to.   

http://www.curtisbrown.co.uk/luke-brady/


Kind Regards. 

Luke Brady

story:
Eyestrings is committed to producing courageous and bold interpretations of the classics.  We rebel against convention to unleash the brutal, beautiful and visceral nature of these epic stories.

After our successful run of The Duchess of Malfi in 2012 we are now taking the show on the road around England. This is an incredibly exciting venture for Eyestrings and begins our journey to becoming a leading voice in classical touring theatre.

This will be made possible through the hard work of the Eyestrings Team and our fundraising campaign. This Indiegogo site is one of our many fundraising strands and allows you to donate as much as you can afford to in an very easy way.

We have also added some exclusive Eyestrings perks to express our gratitude.

A few clicks and you've helped in a massive way(!).

We understand that you may not be able to support financially, but if you believe in the cause we would greatly appreciate if you could forward this link onto people who you think might also be interested in the company and the production.

The Duchess of Malfi achieved great acclaim last year and we are excited to be giving it another life beyond London.

Thank you so much for your kind support.

We really could not do it without your help.

If you would like to remain Anonymous you can still claim your perk by emailing eyestrings@gmail.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here are some of things people had to say about The Duchess of Malfi  -

'This sort of daring, intelligent work is what fringe theatre should be all about'

The Stage

'Distinctive and Discomforting'

Exeunt

'Electrifying and beautifully real'

A Younger Theatre

'Eyestrings' The Duchess of Malfi is incredibly accomplished. The production is sophisticated, daring and alive and deserves to be seen by many more people.'

Declan Donellan, Artistic Director of Cheek by Jowl

A selection of our Audience comments

'What a sensational performance – we loved the energy and commitment & look forward to your next production.'

'Best working of the text I have ever seen.'

'Wonderful production! The tension was kept up throughout. And humour was found in the tragedy.'

 

And here is where we are going in 2013 -

September

 

  • Tues 3 - Sat 7 | SOUTHWARK PLAYHOUSE, LONDON 
  • Tuesday 17 | CORN EXCHANGE, NEWBURY
  • Wednesday 18 | HARLOW, PLAYHOUSE
  • Thursday 19 | FIRESTATION, WINDSOR
  • Saturday 21 | QUAY ARTS, NEWPORT, ISLE OF WIGHT
  • Wednesday 25 | OLD TOWN HALL, HEMEL HEMPSTEAD
  • Friday 27 | COLCHESTER, LAKESIDE
  • Saturday 28 | LOWESTOFT, THE SEAGULL
October
  • Tuesday 1 | NEW MILTON, FOREST ARTS CENTRE
  • Wednesday 2 | CHIPPING NORTON, THEATRE
  • Friday 4 | OXFORD, THE FIRESTATION
  • Saturday 5 | CONNAUGHT THEATRE, WORTHING
  • Sunday 6 | WELLS NEXT TO THE SEA
  • Tuesday 8 | THE MILL ARTS CENTRE, BANBURY
  • Sunday 6 | GULBENKIAN, CANTERBURY
  • Thursday 10 | MARLBOROUGH THEATRE, BRIGHTON
  • Friday 11 | TUNBRIDGE WELLS, TRINITY THEATRE
  • Saturday 12 | CORNERSTONE, DIDCOT

story:
Short Summary

Established in 1994 by Creative Director and Founder Sherese Campbell, Houston City Dance Studio is a non-profit dance school and performing arts organization that seeks to reflect the ethnic diversity of the Houston Metropolitan area. Since then, Ms. Campbell has been the driving force in teaching the school's dance students. The school boasts an internationally, ethnically, and culturally diverse body of students and alumni, with dancers hailing from Russia, China, Japan, Hungary, India, Nigeria, Mexico, Germany, and Italy, as well as various Houston neighborhoods. Ms. Campbell's commitment to dance education and instruction is evident in City Dance's comprehensive class schedule, featuring an array of ballet, jazz, modern, and tap offerings that cater to students of all ages and ability levels.

City Dance's professional company performs their vibrant mix of jazz, contemporary, and classical styles in theaters and at cultural events locally and internationally. The Company's performers are young adults of diverse ethnic, social, and cultural backgrounds. The Company's students are routinely expected to give their time and talent to the community by promoting the art of dance through community service at venues such as schools, retirement and assisted living facilities, hospitals and homeless shelters.

The professional company is excited to have the opportunity to travel to Edinburgh, Scotland for the Festival Fringe for the second year.  Last year the company performed works by Sherese Campbell and Jaimee Vilela, impressing the critics and gaining new fans across the globe.

This year, the company hopes to tour a larger selection of work by Sherese Campbell, Jaimee Vilela, Stephanie Sermas, Elijah Gibson, and Ballet Austin's James Fuller.  Participation in this festival requires the company to fund their entire trip, including housing and venue rentals.  This is why they need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

Houston City Dance needs a minimum $8,000 to help pay for plane tickets, housing, and venue rentals during the Festival Fringe.  The company is offering several thank you gifts for your help.  These gifts include: a postcard from the festival, a thank you note from the company, a signed photo of the company, special recognition in our Festival Fringe program, and tickets to a Houston City Dance concert.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute monetarily, we can still use your help.  Please share our campaign through your social media accounts.  If you would like to contribute in another way, please contact Houston City Dance at 713-529-6100 or email at citydance@sbcglobal.net

story:
What is Bullet Theatre Collaborative?

Bullet Theatre Collaborative is a creative team of young, professional theatre artists developing high-quality performance, design, and technical opportunities in the theatre community.


...In English

We like to work together to make cool shows for everyone else to enjoy and be a part of.

In fact, at its core, this group was started because we have a ton of super talented friends (performers, artists, designers, administrators, musicians, you name it) and we love to see them do what they do and it bums us out that they don't get to do it more often. There are just never enough opportunities... so we decided to create some ourselves.


Are We a Performance Group?

Not exactly. We're more of a consistent creative/production team that produces its own shows. We don't have a core group of actors, and every role in every show is cast through open auditions. 

Our first production will be Assassins at UCPAC's Hamilton Stage with performances running January 17th - January 26th.


Why We Need YOUR Support

Because we're brand spankin' new! Well, actually... that's not entirely true.

Although Assassins will be our first production under the name Bullet Theatre Collaborative, our core creative team has worked together to put up several successful shows in the past including Razia's Shadow at Playhouse 22 and Polaroid Stories at Kean University. But this is the first time we're shouldering all of the creative and production responsibilities on our own, and we hope to be able to continue to do so on a regular basis after the (anticipated) dazzling success of Assassins! But we can't do it without a large, wonderful community of folks who want to see us pull it off. That's you. (And you, and you, and you, and the rest of you's)

All of the money collected during this campaign will go toward funding Assassins, our first self-produced show. As some of you may know, producing a show from scratch is no slight endeavor. A great deal of funds are needed to secure the performance rights, build the set, rent and construct the costumes, design the lights, pay the musicians, and more. And we're still hoping to retain a budget for future performances! We're going to work our hardest, but we can't make it happen without you. 


So What Exactly Is This Fundraiser?

We're actually not even sure "fundraiser" is entirely the correct word for it. We're thinking of it more as a "service campaign".

We wanted to get away from the traditional sense of asking for your money. We've all done that before, it works fine, whatever, we don't like doing it. So instead, being the group of strapping young creative professionals that we are (ahem), we've decided to pool our talents and services and offer them to you guys for the next couple of months in exchange for your support! Your interest and belief in what we do is truly priceless, and you deserve anything and everything we have to offer. So we want to know... What Can We Do For YOU?

Browse the detailed perks along the right-hand side of the page to see what we have to offer! Take advantage of a variety of gifts and services including (but not limited to):

  • Web Design
  • Custom Built Furniture
  • Original Art 
  • Music Production
  • Headshot and Portrait Photography
  • A Song Written Just For You
  • Audition Coaching and Repertoire
  • Playbill Advertisement Space 
  • Tickets to BTC Shows as Well as Some of NJ's Best Regional Theatre
  • A Cameo Appearance in Our Production of Assassins
  • ...And Even More!

There is definitely a joke somewhere in bullet-pointing information on the Bullet Theatre Collaborative campaign page. We're just not sure what it is.


Other Ways You Can Get Involved

Tell your friends!

- Whether or not you're personally able to contribute to our campaign and take advantage of our services, we'd LOVE it if you could give us a shout out on your preferred social media platform and get the word out about what we're trying to do and all the stuff we're offering.

Maybe someone else you know has really been looking for someone to build them a new website, or needs a couple of songs recorded for a super bargain price. We're rolling up our sleeves and offering a lot of high-value services for low costs, so don't let anyone miss out on the action while it's still available.

Audition!

- Yessss, please! For the love of the theatre gods, do this. We're so excited to work with as many talented artists and performers as we can, whether we've already been working with you for years or we've never met you before in our lives.

Our first production will be Assassins at UCPAC's Hamilton Stage in Rahway, NJ. Open auditions will be taking place November 7th and 8th with callbacks on the 10th. For much more info on that, please visit www.facebook.com/events/576107922451747

Come See Our Shows!

- That's the whole reason we do 'em! We hope you enjoy our work and the products of your support as much as we enjoy presenting them to you.


Thanks so much for reading and contributing! Please head to the right side of the page and let us know what we can do for YOU!

Your interest and belief in what we do is truly priceless, and you deserve anything and everything we have to offer. So we want to know... What Can We Do For YOU?Browse the detailed perks along the right-hand side of the page to see what we have to offer! Take advantage of a variety of gifts and services including (but not limited to):
Web Design
Custom Built Furniture

Original Art 
Music Production

Headshot and Portrait Photography
A Song Written Just For You
Audition Coaching and Repertoire
Playbill Advertisement Space 
Tickets to BTC Shows as Well as Some of NJ's Best Regional Theatre
A Cameo Appearance in Our Production of Assassins

...And Even More! 


There is definitely a joke somewhere in bullet-pointing information on the Bullet Theatre Collaborative campaign page. We're just not sure what it is. 



Other Ways You Can Get Involved


Tell your friends! - Whether or not you're personally able to contribute to our campaign and take advantage of our services, we'd LOVE it if you could give us a shout out on your preferred social media platform and get the word out about what we're trying to do and all the stuff we're offering. 
Maybe someone else you know has really been looking for someone to build them a new website, or needs a couple of songs recorded for a super bargain price. We're rolling up our sleeves and offering a lot of high-value services for low costs, so don't let anyone miss out on the action while it's still available. 

Audition! - Yessss, please! For the love of the theatre gods, do this. We're so excited to work with as many talented artists and performers as we can, whether we've already been working with you for years or we've never met you before in our lives. 
Our first production will be Assassins at UCPAC's Hamilton Stage in Rahway, NJ. Open auditions will be taking place November 7th and 8th with callbacks on the 10th. For much more info on that, please visit www.facebook.com/events/576107922451747

Come See Our Shows!- That's the whole reason we do 'em! We hope you enjoy our work and the products of your support as much as we enjoy presenting them to you. 


Thanks so much for reading and contributing! Please head to the right side of the page and let us know what we can do for YOU!

story:
Short Summary

Hello Gracious Contributors,

  My name is Jamison Monella and I am recent graduate of Juniata College with a Bachelor's Degree in Theatre Performance and Art History. I have been acting since I was 9 years old and theater is not only my greatest passion in this life, but it is also one of the most essential pillars in human history as a whole. Without having an open and free space to explore the expansive issues of our society at large -- then we would never have been able to move forward.

  This moving forward is something I have experienced quite recently, as I left the comfort of my home in Pennsylvania and moved to New York City. The impetus behind my move was of course: theater. Mid-semester I was excited to accept two opportunities. The first being to perform in a production called Drones in the Planet Connections Theater Festivity. This production will be closing on July 9th and has made a fantastic run and had a warm reception. The second opportunity is the reason  you are reading the words on this webpage. In just under a month, on August 2 2016, I will be flying to Edinburgh, Scotland to perform as Hamlet in the largest theater festival of its kind in the entire world: The International Edinburgh Fringe Festival. At this particular festivity, the entire city is virtually converted into a performance space. Artists from all over the globe gather to perform, share their stories, and to network in one the most beautiful countries.

  Fortunately, the plane tickets and accommodations have been taken care of by an anonymous donor. However, assistance at this point in time is still needed. I have a day job working at Classic Harbor Line at Chelsea Piers and am also seeking a second job. Although I do have a source of income, this trip --which is inherently career enhancing -- may not be able to happen without your help. I am seeking funds to help pay for the sublets that I am currently living in, for food while I am on my trip, and for travel to and from the airports.

  If you can find the kindness and love to help out this starving artist, I would be eternally grateful. There is nothing more important to me than my career, and after a life dreaming of becoming a professional actor I can now say that I am living that dream. Thank you for reading and I hope to hear from you soon.

With love,

Jamison Monella

story:
Short Summary

We are thrilled to announce that dNaga has been invited to perform at this year’s World Parkinson Congress from September 20 to 23, 2016, in Portland, Oregon. There will be about 4000 attendees from all over the world at the Congress including researchers, medical professionals, people with Parkinson’s, their families and caregivers.

dNaga is an intergenerational dance company based in Oakland, California that includes adult dancers with Parkinson’s disease performing with high school dancers. We are an extension of the Dance for PD® program that began in 2001 at the Mark Morris Dance Group in Brooklyn. dNaga director and choreographer Claudine Naganuma has been offering Dance for PD®  classes in Oakland since 2007. Claudine is featured in Dave Iverson’s documentary about the dance program, “Capturing Grace”.

Our work is entitled Proteinology and it is inspired by the recent discovery of the misfolding protein. Our newest section, "Ode to the Sticky Protein and Momentary Lapses of Escapism" is performed to the music of the fantastic Portland group Pink Martini.

Collaborators and audience alike are inspired by the courage and grace of our dancers. For those with Parkinson’s disease, dancing provides an opportunity to creatively express and share the private struggles of living with PD. For our young dancers, the unique experience of working with dancers with PD is a precious opportunity to form bonds across the generations while creating art together.

Our collaborative choreography, from whimsy to solemn and back again, features personal narratives, current PD research, original sound scores, symbols, poetry and myth, all around the theme of living with Parkinson’s disease.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking funding to cover the costs of this project: In particular, we need to pay for flights and housing for our 10 member company, 5 dancers with Parkinson’s disease and 5 adults/youth will be traveling with our director, composer, stage manager and lighting designer!

As a supporter of dNaga’s World Parkinson’s Congress adventure, you will be associated with the cutting edge concept that exercise, and in particular, dance, provides relief for many PD sufferers. While a cure has yet to be found, dance brings movement, joy and community to those with this affliction.

Unless you prefer to remain anonymous, contributors’ names will be printed in the WPC program, projected on the backdrop of the stage during the performances at the WPC and listed on dNaga’s website.

    The Impact

    Your contribution will help us get to Portland and pay for housing (which is VERY EXPENSIVE!)  Our lighting designer (of two decades) will be travelling from Texas and our composer (also of two decades) will be bringing his MARIMBA LUMINA! (Buchla instrument). We also plan on having new costumes made!

    dNaga’s dancers have been creating and performing since 2001. We have presented work annually at Laney College Theater in Oakland, at Danspace in Oakland (our home studio), Z Space and SomARTS Cultural Center in San Francisco, Tapestry at the Mormon Temple Auditorium in Oakland, and several site specific dances. dNaga’s work has also been performed at the Mark Morris Dance Center in Brooklyn and the Mulberry Street Theater in New York City.

    Our dancers, those with Parkinson’s as well as our youth dancers, are dedicated, hardworking and aware of the profound meaning of the dance, the process, the community we are creating and its message to those with Parkinson’s, their families, caregivers, researchers and medical professionals

    Risks & Challenges

    For people with Parkinson’s, every day is a challenge. We live with tremors, unruly limbs, rigidity, extreme fatigue, balance issues, muscle and joint pains, and sometimes cognitive impairment. Despite this, we are devoted to the work we are creating and presenting. Most of us are either not working any longer or are “semi-retired”. This is why we need your help to fulfill this golden opportunity to perform at the 2016 World Parkinson’s Congress.

    Failure to reach our fundraising goals would have a huge impact on our performance and presence at the World Parkinson Congress. Burdened by medical costs, our dancers are not able to finance the project independently. Without your support, we will have to re-choreograph and adjust so that fewer dancers will be involved. Scaling down our production would put a huge damper on our ability to connect with attendees and share our stories.

    You may be wondering why we have such an early deadline! Coordinating housing, transport and other logistics for our dancers and collaborators requires early reservations and planning. Delays in the process will increase costs and create larger hurdles beyond what we already face.

    Help us create a successful performance at the World Parkinson Congress! Having all of our dancers onstage, opening their hearts to the audience and connecting with others in the same predicament will have an immeasurable benefit.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please help us spread the word to those who might be financially able to support us. Tag and share this campaign on social media. Send us your story of living with Parkinson’s disease.

    Use Indiegogo share tools.

story:
About The Show

THE HUMMM explores the soundscape of Chekhov’s Three Sisters and short stories.  Based on the belief that vibration carries meaning, our team uses sound as the driving force to unpack the subtlety and musicality of Chekhov’s most lonely women. Featuring four actresses, the show is set in a post-apocalyptic future where all the military men have died and only the women remain. Haunted by fading memories and the voices of their past loves, these women must find a way to survive on their own. Humming, whining, whispering, and clamoring — we wrap the audience in a  ‘Chekhovian polyphony,’ where the chords are made of ecstasy, anguish, and perpetual disillusion. Incorporating a wide range of music and media, and intensified by stylistic choreography and a live DJ, The Hummm creates an unprecedented aural and visual experience of the Three Sisters.

 

Who We Are

All of our core collaborators recently graduated from the A.R.T. Institute at Harvard University. United by our shared artistic vocabulary and inspired by our studies in both Russia and Poland, we have come together to make current, wild, and inventive theatre.  We love this project almost as much as we love each other!

For bios on all of our team members, visit www.thehummm.com. 

 

Impact

“Our business is to work and go on working, and our distant descendants will have any happiness that’s going.  I won’t have it, but my children’s children may.”  -Vershinin in Chekhov’s Three Sisters

While our team always intended to draw parallels between Chekhov’s turn-of-the-20th-century text and our own contemporary truths, igniting this discussion now feels more urgent. We have been particularly called to action by the 2016 presidential campaign; to ignore its outcome seems untruthful, and quite frankly, impossible.

Chekhov’s play poses essential questions about the consequences of inaction, and the challenge of moving forward in the face of hopelessness. We are more inspired than ever to explore his universal images and themes, and we hope you’ll join us in turning this social art to social act.

 

What We Need & What You Get

All funds raised through our Indiegogo campaign will contribute to the following:

  • Materials to build our set
  • Materials to build and/or purchase all needed props
  • Materials to build and/or purchase all needed costumes
  • Marketing expenses
  • Space rental for rehearsal in New York City

Perks for donating range from postcards, to dinner with the cast and creative team, to music lessons, to the role of Andrey in our show!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially.  If you’re not in a position to make a gift today, please help us out by sharing this page and spreading the word!

story:
Summary

My name is Nic Adams and I make poetry and theatre. For the last five years, I’ve been working as a stage manager and assistant director, mostly on experimental productions in New York City. But for the last five years, I’ve also been presenting productions of my own theatre at smaller venues.

My upcoming show, Icarus in the L.E.S., is a kaleidoscopic performance-poem delivered from the final bastions of the New York vanguard. The performance centers on the wax-winged hero – who did not die when he fell from the sky, but instead lives on – chasing his destiny and scouting out the divide between artistic achievement and personal happiness. Presented as a teched-out poetry reading, and brimming with sound and video design culled from the most psychically-charged bits of city living, the poem is performed by the soulful and unendingly charismatic Ronald Peet.

I am asking for your help to raise $500 towards funding this project. Icarus has been the recipient of many hours of free labor and thoughtful play given to me by performers, directors, and writers. Over the past few years, I have paid out of pocket for rehearsal space, costumes, and glittery makeup. I have composed a rich soundscore from field recordings I’ve made in my free time. And I’ve built something I’m very proud of out of these donations of time and thought! Now, however, I am attempting to craft Icarus into a repeatable, enjoyable work of live performance with an actor, Ronald Peet, scenery, lights, sound, and video and all of that takes time, money, and skill to create. I must now ask for your support to get me over this final hurdle.

This production represents a big transition in my career as an artist. For years I have been helping others as an assistant or stage manager to create their own astonishing, progressive, lively, and fun pieces of live performance. Getting the chance to produce Icarus at this level for an audience of artists I deeply admire means the world to me, and cannot happen without your help.

What We Need & What You Get

$500 is the fund I am asking this crowd to raise. This amount represents half of my costs for this show. This money is dedicated to paying the performer, shopping for and building the scenery of this play (Icarus is set in-between the aisles of a bodega – replete with an old TV, dried goods, and Bustelo coffee cans), paying for rehearsal space (always a really big expense), and boring-but-important things like printing, transportation, and contingency.

Starting at just $15, the perks for this show are one-of-a-kind, ranging from a high-quality show poster signed and numbered by the artist, to a handmade chapbook of the poem, signed by me. For higher-level donations, we’re offering a CD or digital download of the show with the original soundscore, and, at the highest level, I will come perform Icarus in the L.E.S. in its entirety at your home for a crowd of up to 20.

The Impact

Without getting too hokey, I love poetry. Like most people, I began reading poetry and remember feeling embarrassed at the language. It was too big, too grand. I didn’t have the words for the way I felt, but poetry did. Or it got closer. And I was jealous. As I continued reading poetry, I realized it wasn’t all big and grand. Some poetry was goofy, some was romantic. Some couldn’t be categorized as easily, but felt true. All of a sudden, I realized poetry gave me more words for the way I felt. I want to share that experience with others, and I think, mostly, it comes from creating a joyful live experience led by a mesmerizing performer. This is what I hope my performance-poetry can achieve. Your contribution to this campaign can help create a space and time for this experience.

I have been sharing my live poetry for a few years now at places like Small’s jazz club, Cloud City, Dixon Place, and other small venues. A consistent refrain I hear from my audiences is “I don’t think of myself as a poetry person, but your poetry was beautiful.” They also say that they didn’t think poetry could be so fun, funny, etc. and that mine was. This feedback leads me to believe that if people can be surprised by my poetry, they may return to it and others’ work to help them define their experiences.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge facing this – or any production – is time and space. I need the time and space to create and rehearse a thoughtful experience that will achieve my goals. And luckily, I have some help. I have been invited to perform at the venue, JACK, at no cost to the production. The co-producing company for this production is a group called Brooklyn Gypsies that has an excellent track record of presenting sold-out live events dedicated to social issues, poetry, and a kickass time. They will help offset the costs of marketing, promotion, venue rental, and insurance. But this will only get me part of the way there. I need your donations to help myself and the performer shape the poem into its most potent form, and there’s no better way to prepare for that other than renting a rehearsal room and picking apart the text.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate, but are looking for a way to help, the best thing you can do is buy a ticket. Check out this website (http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2729733) for tickets.

Other ways to help are by spreading the word on social media, email, and by telling people in person about this campaign.

Thank you so much for reading this far! I am so excited to share Icarus in the L.E.S. with you this winter!

Thank you so much for reading this far! I am so excited to share Icarus in the L.E.S. with you this winter!

story:
How ticketing works:

When you make a contribution, pick a perk on the right for tickets and we will contact you to make your reservation on one of these dates. You and your friends will be immediately placed on our guest list and will be used to sign audiences in come show day!

12th June (Monday)
13th June (Tuesday)
14th June (Wednesday)
15th June (Thursday)
17th June (Saturday)
18th June (Sunday)

Venue: Lepark on People's Park Complex Rooftop

Time: Arrive at 1900 for pre-show, show starts 2000
Duration: 2 hours+
Adapted and devised by 5toMidnight Singapore
Supported by NAC MATCHBOX and Tote Board Arts Fund

The Family

5toMidnight is an international network of theater collectives that train under a single ethos. The collective has established branches in Indonesia and Taiwan, the maiden production of the Singapore branch is the first installment in a five- part series of Chekhov's major works adapted into a single, connected universe. 

The Show

5toMidnight has taken a classic Russian play,and contextualized it for a Singaporean audience to examine how one man battles against the pressures of how difficult it is to be anything less than a model citizen in Singapore. Performed at what used to be the abandoned rooftop carpark of people's Park Complex, courtesy of Lepark, The Chekhov Cycle: Ivanov is a painful portrait of the struggle to survive in one of the most underrated venues of Singaporean nightlife. We've settled the logistical stuff, but we need your help to make sure we can eat!

This campaign is to raise funds to support the large, multiracial cast and creative team, and to offer opportunities for you, the audience, to engage in the creative process. We believe in community engagement in the creation of the work, while keeping prices as low as possible, to support large- scale, yet relevant work. Chekhov's major works have never been done in Singapore to the local taste, and in the local context, despite being a legendary playwright of the 20th century. 

Come have a night out with us and then Lepark afterwards with the team!

Come In

Contributions

By contributing to this production, you will be supporting a diverse range of artists, offering them a fair wage and promoting a more tightly involved culture of creating theater that priorities an audience's cultural context, and social situation. You will be promoting theater in unconventional spaces, and challenging the definition of what is needed to create an immersive theatrical event.  

Even after receiving basic funding to cover production costs, this campaign's contributions will go directly to the people that make this show. For every ticket sold, $1.50 will go to each person involved in the production, so we can offer the tickets at cost price, essentially at a 10% discount of the retail price. In addition to that, crowdfunding allows us to offer you opportunities to work hands- on with the company from training with the director on the play itself, to watching the show being built, and even a souvenir for yourself to remember this event. 

Whatever contributions we receive, big or small, will go directly to the actors (with the exception of the platform fee) so you will be directly paying the people you will see on stage with no one in between. 

On top of getting to watch the show, these are some of the rewards you'll receive: Discounts, workshops, being a part of our rehearsals, a DVD and more! 

 

Why Now?

The team working on this production come from a variety of backgrounds to train together as theater makers in order to create a culture that is inclusive, and empathetic to each others' circumstances, and the world they live in with an audience. 5toMidnight strives for true intercultural exchange between its various branches in order to fight ignorance, violence, and discrimination. Chekhov was a humanitarian, and his plays reflect not just 20th century Russian Society, but also 21st century Singaporean society because we still face the same issues, therefore, in the interest of artistic equality, we want you to come and not just see the show, but to have a conversation with us about why Chekhov's stories can be, if not, are important to us.

Since the formation of 5toMidnight, we have embarked to Italy, Indonesia, and Taiwan to develop international collaborations and seed projects for the near future and for many years down the line. We have brought Singaporeans, Indonesians and Taiwanese together, worked together for international festivals, such as the Makassar International Writers' Festival (Indonesia), for the Farm 2016 international residencies in Italy, and at Robert Wilson's Watermill Center in New York. This is our first time doing a completely local project, grown and set in Singapore, and we hope that your support on this production will create a culture where the arts are beautiful, useful, and indispensable. 

It is often said that there is no money in the arts. We don't believe that. If we can redefine what is enough for the artists to create high quality work for the audience to pay no more than they should, and come together to share an experience, then the arts stops being a high- class luxury activity and can return to what it felt like when our parents took us to watch wayang shows during festivals in our childhood. But as we have grown older, and become more "educated", and face realities of earning money, receiving a prestigious education, finding a job, owning a car, we risk losing the wonder of being a child living in a community. And why this can sound like a heartfelt speech, is because these are the barriers that the characters in the play grieve, celebrate, and fight about.

Go On 

By contributing to this campaign, even if you choose none of the rewards available, you will get a ticket to watch the show, and we hope that that is enough of a gift from us to you for the time that you have spent clicking on the Facebook link, giving us your hard- earned money, coming to Chinatown, and partaking in a production that we've not only worked hard for, but thoroughly enjoyed creating for you. 

Please help us spread the word by:
Talking about us!
Sharing on Facebook!
Tag us on instagram #tccivanov!
RSVP our Facebook event!
Drop us an email at fivehostiles@gmail.com for more information!


With lots of love,
5toMidnight

Please help us spread the word by:Talking about us!Sharing on Facebook!Tag us on instagram #tccivanov!RSVP our Facebook event!Drop us an email at fivehostiles@gmail.com for more information!

story:
Short & Sweet

The Negroes Are Congregating asks a lot of impolite questions about the ongoing effects of racism and how that ideology continues to exists in Canada and around the world. The Jamaican-Canadian writer, Natasha Adiyana Morris, infuses a taste of Toronto that incorporates accents, landmarks and a sort of local trivia often ignored by mainstream media. 

"Talking about race is exhausting and so I wanted to form my thoughts into live characters, displaying multiple sides of the race conversation. Some characters are full-on revolutionaries, others are complacent, there are parodies and plenty of satire but it ALL reflects uncomfortable truths."

The play first saw the light of day in 2015, as a 25-minute draft at the PIECE OF MINE Festival. The following year, four shows (including an encore) solidified its presence as one to watch. After much revision, it's been a favourable 2018 with acceptance into:

>  Black Theatre Network Conference July 26 – 30, 2018 (Memphis, TN)
> SummerWorks Festival | August 9 – 19, 2018 (Toronto, ON)
> Halifax Fringe | August 30 – September 9, 2018 (Halifax, NS)
> Atlanta Black Theatre Festival | October 5, 2018 (Atlanta, GA)

The only problem is...we're short funds. Traveling to Halifax is a pretty penny. We've put aside enough for accommodation and transportation for the five performance dates over a 9-day stay but the flight is a looming cost.

Your contribution will fill a much-needed gap. Just think, you could be backing the next Da Kink in My Hair?!

What We Need & What You Get

We've got one big cost and one big perk:

  • We need support to fly (4) people including 3 actors and the director/playwright from Toronto to Halifax. The total flight cost is $1,500.00
  • For your generous contribution, you will get admission to the upcoming 5th Annual PIECE OF MINE Festival!
  • If we don't raise our goal it'll be a crazy week of overtime to pay the difference.

The Crew

Playwright and Director Natasha Adiyana Morris is a play creator and performing artist based in Toronto, Canada. She is most recognized as the executive director of PIECE OF MINE Arts, an organization founded in 2013 that promotes work-in-development by Black artists, including the annual PIECE OF MINE Festival and Black Men in Theatre, and the educational youth program Living Black Genius. 

Our cast is comprised of natural talent and fresh on the theatre scene.

(Pictured L to R: Dennis W. Langley, Angaer Arop, and Angaer Arop)

  • David Delisca plays 'Male 1': Born in Port-Au-Prince, Haiti, raised in West Palm Beach, Florida, David is a spoken word poet, actor, and author. A versatile artist, he uses stories of the immigrant and diaspora experiences, as well as other various human realities, to bridge realms of communication. 
  • Dennis Langley plays 'Male 2': This year Dennis was cast in a Kleo Productions’ Amazing Grace musical starring Jully Black at the Rose Theatre and York Woods Theatre. His media company, DWL Entertainment, is growing to encompass film, comedy, and educational entertainment to empower the community and broaden diverse content.
  • Angaer Arop plays 'Female': Angaer is an Egyptian born, Toronto raised, South Sudanese, theatre practitioner. She strives to produce work through vessels that can be accessible to others and herself. Angaer aspires to constantly create her art in a fluid manner that mirrors her realities. As a resident artist at The Watah Theatre, Angaer is developing her first play. 

Produced by the incomparable Troy De Four.

We can't afford him but he is our saving grace.

Always on his toes, ready to create a workback schedule, edit copy and script, follow up with the client/agency, track the budget and update the project timeline, revise a video in premiere pro, finalize all rentals for the DOP, and send the call sheet 48 hours in advance with a 24hour reminder, pick up coffee, remind the producer and creative director of their meeting with the client or agency, AND SO MUCH MORE…..

Risks & Challenges

Going to Memphis was manageable back in July 2018 but how time flys! This time around we're thinking ahead and asking for help. This is not a 'starving artist' story but moreso hungry artists seeking opportunities outside of what is comfortable. And trust us, it's been uncomfortable at times but 1000% worth the sacrifice and results.

Other Ways You Can Help

If circumstances have your pockets on E, no sweat - we get it. All we ask from everyone who supports the show is to spread the word. We have 7 days and counting - every share COUNTS :)

  • Indiegogo share tools are super easy and our best friends.

Thank in advance for making our dream come true!!!
